source_subject: What causs a volcano to erupt?
source_text:
Magma rises from deep in the earth.
The magma goes into volcanos.
The volcanos pressure the magma upwards.
The pressure causes the magma to push through the surface of the volcano.
The lava cools.
The lava forms new rock.
New magma is pressured to the surface of the volcano.
The volcano bursts through the rock the formed after the last eruption.
target_subject: What causes an earthquake?
target_text:
Pressure builds under the Earth's crust.
The pressure causes the tectonic plates to move and collide.
The plates cause the Earth's crust to crack.
The pressure causes molten rock to be forced from the Earth's mantle.
The molten rock cools and forms new rock.
The pressure continues to build and the tectonic plates continue to move,
causing more cracks in the Earth's crust and more molten rock to be forced out.
target_mappings:
Magma : molten rock
Volcano : Earth's crust
Lava : cooled rock
Eruption : earthquake

The lava cools.

target_subject: What causes an earthquake?
target_text:
Tectonic plates move, causing pressure to build up underground.
The pressure can cause a fault line to break in the rock, releasing molten rock.
The molten rock is pushed upwards, breaking through the surface of the ground.
The lava cools and hardens, forming new layers of rock.
The plates continue to move, building up pressure again.
When it becomes too much, the molten rock is forced to the surface again, breaking through the hardened rock of the previous eruption.
target_mappings:
Magma : molten rock
Volcanos : ground
Pressure : tectonic plates
Lava : lava

target_subject: What causes a volcano to erupt?
target_text:
Pressure builds up deep in the Earth.
The pressure forces molten rock to rise from the mantle and enter the crust.
The molten rock, called magma, rises and collects in a magma chamber.
The magma chamber builds pressure and pressure is released through vents in the form of eruptions.
The eruption releases lava, ash, and gas into the atmosphere.
The lava cools and hardens, creating new landforms.
target_mappings:
Magma : molten rock
Volcanos : vents
Lava : lava, ash, and gas

source_subject: What happens during erosion by the ocean?
source_text:
Water from the ocean washes onto beaches in waves.
The waves contain sediment from the ocean.
The water and particles in it hit rocks and sand on the beach.
The wind and current sometimes push the water and particles harder.
Tiny parts of the rocks on the shore come off the larger rocks.
The waves pick up sand and small rocks from the beach.
The waves go back out into the ocean.
The waves carry the new particles with them.
Rocks and the beach look a little different.
target_subject: What happens during erosion by the rain?
target_text:
Rainfall on the land causes soil to become saturated.
The saturated soil begins to erode and break down.
The wind and rain can also cause the soil to erode faster, carrying away particles and sediment.
The rain and wind carry the particles and sediment and deposit them in other areas.
Over time, the land changes in shape and size as the soil is eroded away.
target_mappings:
Waves : rainfall
Ocean : land
Rocks and sand : soil
Wind and current : rain and wind

target_subject: What happens during erosion by the wind?
target_text:
Wind blows across a open field causing the topsoil to be picked up.
The wind carries the soil particles to a new location.
The wind and current sometimes push the soil particles harder.
The soil particles hit rocks, trees, and other objects in the field.
The soil particles are deposited into new locations.
The wind carries the new particles with it.
The field and the objects look a little different.

source_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
source_text:
Water from oceans, lakes, swamps, rivers, and plants turns into water vapor.
Water vapor condenses into millions of tiny droplets that form clouds.
Clouds lose these droplets through rain or snow, also caused precipitation.
Precipitation is either absorbed into the ground or runs off into rivers.
Water that was absorbed into the ground is taken up by plants.
Plants lose water from their surfaces as vapor.
The vapor goes back into the atmosphere.
Water that runs off into rivers flows into ponds, lakes, or oceans.
The water evaporates back into the atmosphere.
target_subject: What happens during the precipitation cycle?
target_text:
Gases in the atmosphere mix together and form tiny particles.
These particles mix with water vapor and form clouds.
The clouds grow and release droplets of water in the form of rain or snow.
The rain or snow falls to the ground and either evaporates or infiltrates the soil.
The infiltrated water flows into rivers and lakes, eventually reaching the ocean.
The ocean water evaporates and goes back into the atmosphere, beginning the cycle again.
target_mappings:
Water from oceans, lakes, swamps, rivers, and plants : gases
Water vapor : tiny particles
Clouds : clouds
Rain or snow : rain or snow
Evaporation : evaporation
Infiltration : infiltration

The vapor goes back into the atmosphere.
Water that runs off into rivers flows into ponds, lakes, or oceans.
The water evaporates back into the atmosphere.
target_subject: How does the atmosphere transfer energy?
target_text:
Heat energy from the sun is absorbed by the earth's surface.
This energy is then transferred to the atmosphere through convection.
The atmosphere is warmed and air rises, cooling as it moves higher.
The cooling air causes condensation, forming clouds.
Clouds release water vapor as precipitation, which falls to the ground.
The precipitation is either absorbed into the ground or evaporates back into the atmosphere.
The water that is absorbed by the ground is taken up by plants,
which then release it back into the atmosphere as vapor.
The vapor then condenses, forming clouds again and continuing the cycle.
target_mappings:
water from oceans, lakes, swamps, rivers, and plants : heat energy from the sun
water vapor : air
clouds : atmosphere
rain or snow : precipitation
plants : ground

target_subject: What happens during the energy cycle?
target_text:
Energy from the sun is captured by the land and ocean.
The energy is converted into heat, which then rises into the atmosphere.
Here, the warm air is pushed up to form clouds, and eventually causes rain or snow.
Rain or snow that falls on the ground is either absorbed into the soil or runs off into rivers.
The absorbed water is taken up by plants, which then release the water back into the atmosphere.
The water that runs off into rivers eventually finds its way to the ocean,
where it evaporates back into the atmosphere, completing the cycle.
target_mappings:

water vapor : heat
clouds : atmosphere

source_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
source_text:
Water from oceans, lakes, rivers, swamps, and plants turns into water vapor.
Water vapor forms droplets in clouds.
Water droplets in clouds become rain or snow and fall.
Some water goes into the ground.
Some water flows down streams into rivers and oceans.
target_subject: What happens during the hydrological cycle?
target_text:
Heat from the sun evaporates moisture from the ground and plants.
The water vapor rises and cools, forming clouds.
The clouds become heavy with the moisture and precipitation falls in the form of rain or snow.
Some of the water returns to the ground or is taken up by plants,
while the rest flows into rivers and eventually back to the ocean.
target_mappings:
Water : moisture
Oceans, lakes, rivers, swamps, and plants : ground and plants
Water vapor : water vapor
Droplets : clouds
Rain or snow : precipitation

target_subject: What is the greenhouse effect?
target_text:
Gases, such as carbon dioxide and methane, are released into the atmosphere by natural processes or man-made activities.
These gases absorb heat from the Sun.
The gases become warmer, creating a layer of warm air that keeps heat trapped inside the atmosphere.
This is known as the greenhouse effect.
The warm air creates wind and rain, which helps to regulate the Earth's temperature.

oceans, lakes, rivers, swamps, and plants : natural processes and man-made activities

clouds : atmosphere

target_subject: What happens during the hydrologic cycle?
target_text:

The water vapor then rises and cools in the atmosphere, forming clouds.
The clouds then condense and release precipitation, such as hail, snow, or rain.
Some of the precipitation is absorbed into the ground, eventually becoming part of the groundwater.
The rest of the precipitation flows into rivers and eventually returns to the oceans.

source_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
source_text:
Water is on the earth in oceans, other bodies of water, and living creatures.
Water evaporates from the earth.
Water accumulates in the sky.
The water forms clouds in the sky.
Large amounts of water end up in bigger clouds as more water evaporates.
The clouds become heavy from all the water.
The water falls back to earth as rain or snow from the clouds.
target_subject: What happens during the mineral cycle?
target_text:
Minerals are found in the earth's crust.
These minerals are released through weathering and erosion.
The minerals are carried by water and air to the ocean.
The minerals accumulate in the ocean and are then consumed by organisms.
Through respiration and decay, the minerals are released back into the atmosphere.
The minerals are carried by the wind and eventually settle back onto the earth's surface.
target_mappings:
Water : minerals
Evaporates : released
Sky : atmosphere
Clouds : carried by wind
Rain or snow : settle back onto the earth's surface

target_subject: What happens during the heat cycle?
target_text:

Heat radiates from the earth.
Heat accumulates in the sky.
The heat is trapped in the atmosphere by gases like CO2.
This causes temperatures to rise and large amounts of heat to become trapped in the atmosphere.
The heat is eventually released back to the earth as infrared radiation or in the form of storms.

target_subject: What happens during the atmospheric cycle?
target_text:
Heat from the sun enters the atmosphere through radiation.
The heat is absorbed by the surface of the Earth,
causing air molecules to rise as hot air.
As the air rises, it cools and condenses, forming clouds.
When the clouds become too heavy, the water droplets inside them fall as precipitation.
The precipitation can be in the form of rain, snow, hail, or sleet.
The water is eventually absorbed by the ground, evaporates, or runs off into bodies of water.

source_subject: How is sediment transported across the Earth?
source_text:
Sediment settles in a place due to gravity.
The sediment breaks down into small particles.
Wind or water picks up the sediment.
The sediment travels along the same route as the wind or water.
The sediment is deposited at new locations by the wind or water.
The sediment is picked up again by new wind or water.
The sediment travels further.
The sediment is deposited again in a new place.
target_subject: How is a seed transported across the Earth?
target_text:
A seed is released from its parent plant.
It is carried away by the wind or an animal.
The seed travels along the same route as the wind or animal.
The seed is deposited at new locations by the wind or animal.
The seed is picked up again by new wind or an animal.
The seed travels further.
The seed is deposited again in a new place.
target_mappings:
Sediment : seed
Gravity : wind or animal
Small particles : seed

target_subject: How does heat travel across the Earth?
target_text:
Heat rises up in the atmosphere.
The heat is then moved by wind currents.
The wind carries the heat in a certain direction.
The heat is then deposited in a new location.
The wind then picks up new heat and carries it to another location.
This process is repeated until the heat is eventually dissipated.

target_subject: How is moisture transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Air masses move across the Earth due to the Earth's rotation.
The air masses pick up moisture from the ocean and other sources.
The air masses transport the moisture over large distances.
The moisture is deposited in new places when the air masses reach cooler temperatures.
The air masses start to rise again, and the process is repeated.

source_subject: How are valleys formed?
source_text:
A large rocky area is formed.
The rocky area has a higher elevation than the surrounding areas.
Water from precipitation falls in the area.
The water forms a stream.
The stream flows towards lower elevation.
The stream becomes a river.
The river continues to flow along the same path for a long time.
The river erodes the rocky area that it touches.
The eroded area cuts deeply into the rock.
target_subject: How are sand dunes formed?
target_text:
A large area of sand dunes is formed.
The area has a higher elevation compared to the surrounding areas.
Wind blows consistently over the area.
The wind moves the sand and creates dunes.
The dunes are constantly shifting due to the wind.
The dunes become higher and higher over time.
The dunes erode the sand and create deep trenches.
target_mappings:
rocky area : sand dunes
water : wind
stream : shifting sand
river : higher and higher dunes
eroded area : deep trenches

The sand dune builds up over time due to the constant wind.
The sand dune becomes a large sand hill.
The wind continues to blow and erode the sand hill.
The eroded area creates a steep slope.

source_subject: How do caverns form?
source_text:
Limestone is located under the soil.
Rain picks up carbon dioxide as it falls to earth.
The rain falls on the soil over the limestone.
The carbon dioxide in the rain washes through the soil.
The carbon dioxide turns into acid.
The acid in the rain gets to the limestone below the soil.
The acid dissolves the limestone.
Acid continues to erode the limestone with more rain over time.
The eroded limestone sometimes forms caves.
target_subject: How do sand dunes form?
target_text:
Wind picks up sand particles.
The wind carries the sand particles to different locations.
The wind drops the sand particles in places with high wind speeds.
The sand particles pile up in places where the wind is blocked by obstacles or gets deflected.
The sand particles pile up and form sand dunes.
Wind continues to carry sand particles and add to the dunes with more sand over time.
The sand dunes sometimes form a dome-like shape with a hollow center.
target_mappings:

Acid : wind
Eroded limestone : sand dunes
Caves : dome-like shape with a hollow center

target_subject: How do sandstone arches form?

The wind blows against the soil over the sandstone.
The dust particles in the wind blow through the soil.
The dust particles act like abrasive sandpaper.
The sandpaper in the wind wears down the sandstone below the soil.
The sandpaper continues to erode the sandstone with more wind over time.
The eroded sandstone sometimes forms sandstone arches.

source_subject: How does igneous rock form?
source_text:
Volcanos contain magma.
The magma is very hot.
The magma rises toward the surface of the volcano.
The magma cools.
The magma starts to harden as it cools.
The magma is sometimes released from the volcano as lava.
The magma or lava becomes a hard rock as it solidifies.
target_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
target_text:
Sedimentary rocks are formed when sand, silt, and clay are carried away by water and deposited in layers.
The sediment is gradually compressed and cemented together.
The sediment is then hardened into rock over time.
Organisms like shells and bones are sometimes preserved in the sedimentary rock.
The pressure and heat of the layers of sediment cause the sediment to change into sedimentary rock.
target_mappings:
Magma : sand, silt, and clay
Lava : sediment
Hard rock : sedimentary rock

The magma rises toward the surface of the volcano.
The magma cools.
The magma starts to harden as it cools.
The magma is sometimes released from the volcano as lava.
The magma or lava becomes a hard rock as it solidifies.
target_subject: How do metamorphic rocks form?
target_text:
Metamorphic rocks are formed by heat and pressure.
Pressure and heat cause the rock to deform and deform the mineral composition of the rock.
The mineral composition changes and new minerals form as the rock is heated and compressed.
The newly formed minerals are held together by a process called recrystallization.
The rock hardens and becomes more dense, forming a new kind of rock.
target_mappings:
Magma : pressure and heat
Lava : rock
Solidifies : recrystallization

target_subject: How does metamorphic rock form?
target_text:
Metamorphic rocks form when existing rocks are subjected to high pressure and temperature.
This pressure and temperature causes the minerals in the existing rocks to be reorganized and new minerals to be formed.
This process may take a few million years and results in the formation of a new rock that is different from the existing rock.
target_mappings:
Magma : existing rocks
Lava : high pressure and temperature
Hard rock : new rock

target_subject: How does an aquifer form?
target_text:
Water passes through rocks and soil.
The water is filtered and trapped in the ground.
The water builds up creating a pool.
The pool of water is heated by the Earth's core.
The heated water evaporates, rises, and cools in the atmosphere.
The cooled water returns to Earth in the form of rain.
The rain accumulates and is filtered into the ground to form an aquifer.
target_mappings:

Lava : water
Igneous rock : aquifer

The organic material is broken down and chemically altered.
The new material is compressed and forms sedimentary rock.
The sedimentary rock is heated and the pressure increases.
The rock is then metamorphosed and forms metamorphic rock.

target_subject: How does coal form?
target_text:
Organic matter accumulates in swamps and bogs.
The organic matter is compressed by overlying layers of soil.
The organic matter slowly breaks down, due to anaerobic conditions.
Over time, the organic matter transforms into chemical compounds such as methane, ethane and propane.
The chemical compounds then undergoes a process of compression and heat, transforming into coal.
target_mappings:
Rocks : organic matter
Magma : chemical compounds
Lava : coal

target_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
target_text:
Weathering and erosion occur to rocks on the surface of the Earth.
The rocks break down into smaller pieces due to the effects of wind, water, and temperature.

The pieces are compressed and cemented together by pressure and sediment.

source_subject: What causes an earthquake to occur?
source_text:
The earth develops cracks deep beneath the surface.
The cracks get very long and big in some places.
The earth places pressure against the rocks on both sides of the cracks.
The pressure causes the rocks to press against each other very hard.
The cracks continue to develop.
The earth moves against itself on both sides of the cracks.
The pressure and movement around the cracks causes the rocks to crumble in some places.
A lot of energy is released.
The energy causes seismic waves.
The seismic waves move the earth in an earthquake.
target_subject: What causes an earthquake to occur?
target_text:
The Earth's plates move and grind against each other.
The plates become stuck at some points and the tension builds up.
Eventually, the pressure becomes too great and the plates slip, releasing energy.
This energy is released as seismic waves, causing an earthquake.

Pressure : tension
Movement : slip
Rocks : energy

source_subject: How do floods happen?
source_text:
There is a lot of rain or a dam breaks.
Water levels of a river or lake get higher.
Water builds up on the ground.
Water covers streets.
Water gets deep in some places.
Water goes into houses and other buildings.
The rain stops or the dam is repaired.
Water flows into streams.
The rest of the floodwater evaporates.
target_subject: How does a hurricane form?
target_text:
A hurricane forms when warm air from the ocean rises, cools off and condenses, forming a huge storm system with thunderstorms and strong winds.
The pressure from the storm system can cause the ocean to rise, flooding the nearby land.
The powerful winds from the storm can topple trees and buildings, and cause significant structural damage.
The rain from the storm can cause flash floods and mudslides, making flooding even worse.
The storm eventually dissipates, leaving behind the destruction it caused.

target_text:

The ash and dust form a cloud that blocks out the sun.
The ash and dust fall to the ground and cover the land.
The lava flows down the volcano, destroying everything in its path.
The lava is hot and can reach temperatures of up to 1,000 degrees Celsius.
The lava flows and covers more areas, destroying more land and buildings.
The eruption eventually stops and the area is left with destruction and destruction.

source_subject: How does sediment turn into sedimentary rock?
source_text:
Minerals fill spaces between bits of sediment.
The sediments become glued together.
The glued together parts become hard like cement.
The sediment becomes a big rock.
The rocks erode slowly.
The rocks come apart.
The rocks become smaller rocks.
The rocks continue to erode into smaller rocks.
The process starts again.
target_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
target_text:
Rainwater filters through the soil and accumulates in layers of sand and silt.
The sand and silt press together, and a sedimentary rock is formed.
The rock is then exposed to wind, water and other erosive forces, which cause it to break apart into small pieces.
The sediment is then moved by water and wind, and deposited in new locations.
The process then starts again.
target_mappings:

Sediment : sand and silt
Cement : sedimentary rock
Erode : erosive forces

target_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
target_text:
Rainfall and other forms of precipitation collect in rivers and oceans.
The water flows and carries pieces of sediment, such as soil, sand, and rock particles.
The particles settle on the bottom of the river or ocean, forming a layer of sediment.
Over time, the pressure from the overlying layers and the increased salinity of the water causes minerals to crystallize, cementing the sediment layers together.
The cemented sediment forms sedimentary rock.

target_subject: How does lava turn into igneous rock?
target_text:
Minerals fill spaces between bits of lava.
The lava cools and solidifies.
The solidified parts form a hard rock.
The rock erodes slowly.
The rock breaks apart into smaller rocks.
The rocks erode further into smaller rocks.
The process starts again.
target_mappings:
Sediment : lava
Cement : hard rock

source_subject: How are ravines formed?
source_text:
An area is at a higher elevation than the surrounding area.
Rain falls.
Water is in the area of high elevation.
The water creates a stream.
The stream moves towards lower elevation.
The stream continues along the same path for a long time.
The soil and rocks erode where the stream touches them.
The stream moves deeper into the soil.
The stream is smaller than the eroded area.
target_subject: How are sand dunes formed?
target_text:
The wind blows over the land, carrying with it particles of sand.
The sand collects in a certain area, forming a dune.
The dune is higher than the surrounding area.
As the wind continues to blow over the dune, the particles of sand are pushed further up the dune, increasing its height.
The dune continues to grow until it is eventually stabilized by vegetation.
target_mappings:
Higher elevation : higher than the surrounding area
Rain : wind
Stream : particles of sand
Erode : pushed further up the dune
Soil and rocks : vegetation

target_subject: How are valleys formed by glaciers?
target_text:
A glacier is a large mass of ice.
The glacier moves slowly from the higher elevation to lower elevation.
The glacier erodes the land as it moves, scraping away soil and rocks.
As the glacier moves, it creates a valley that is wider than the glacier itself.
The glacier continues to erode the land until it reaches the sea, leaving behind a U-shaped valley.

Gravity pulls the snow and ice from the mountain.
This creates a glacier.
The glacier moves downhill, carving the land along its path.
The glacier continues along the same path for a long time.
The rocks and soil are moved by the glacier as it moves.
The glacier moves deeper into the landscape.
The glacier is larger than the area that it has carved.

source_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
source_text:
Wind or water breaks small pieces off of a rock.
The wind or water deposits tiny rocks.
The rocks become known as sediment.
The layers of sediment are pressed together by other layers of sediment on top.
Minerals from the rocks in the sediment dissolve.
Minerals glue the sediment together into a single rock.
target_subject: How does igneous rock form?
target_text:
Molten rock, called magma, rises from the Earth's mantle.
The magma pushes its way up through the Earth's layers.
It cools as it rises, forming crystals and solidifying into rock.
The pressure from the other layers of rock on top of the magma helps it to cool faster.
The crystals become interlocked and form a single rock.
target_mappings:
wind or water : magma
sediment : crystals
layers of sediment : other layers of rock

source_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?

Wind or water breaks small pieces off of a rock.
The wind or water deposits tiny rocks.
The rocks become known as sediment.
The layers of sediment are pressed together by other layers of sediment on top.
Minerals from the rocks in the sediment dissolve.
Minerals glue the sediment together into a single rock.
target_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
target_text:
Volcanic eruptions eject molten rock, or magma, from the Earth's core.
As the magma cools, it forms fine crystals.
The crystals accumulate to form a rock known as igneous rock.
When the igneous rock is exposed to atmospheric conditions, it will erode and break down into small pieces.
These small pieces are carried away by wind and water and deposited elsewhere.
These pieces accumulate to form sedimentary rock.
target_mappings:
wind or water : volcanic eruptions
sediment : crystals
minerals : magma

Wind or water breaks small pieces off of a rock.
The wind or water deposits tiny rocks.
The rocks become known as sediment.
The layers of sediment are pressed together by other layers of sediment on top.
Minerals from the rocks in the sediment dissolve.
Minerals glue the sediment together into a single rock.
target_subject: How does igneous rock form?
target_text:
Magma or lava cools and hardens on the surface of the Earth.
The cooling and hardening forms small particles.
The particles are moved by wind and water and deposited in layers.
The layers of particles are pressed together by overlying layers.
Minerals from the particles dissolve and form a kind of glue.
The glue binds the particles together creating a single rock.
target_mappings:
Wind or water : magma or lava
Sediment : particles
Minerals : minerals

source_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?
source_text:
Wind and water erode rocks.
The wind and water pick up sediment that came off the rocks.
Sediment is carried to an area by the wind, water, air, or ice.
Sediment is deposited on the same spot many times.
The sediment piles on top of other sediment for a long time.
The sediment near the bottom is compressed by the weight of newer sediment.
The sediment becomes sedimentary rock as it is pushed together by the heavy weight.
target_subject: How does metamorphic rock form?
target_text:
Heat and pressure cause rocks to melt.
The heat and pressure pick up materials that are part of the rocks.
Materials are moved around by the heat and pressure.
The materials are deposited in the same area often.
The materials pile up on top of each other over time.
The materials near the bottom are compressed by the force of newer materials.
The materials become metamorphic rock as they are pressed together by the heavy force.
target_mappings:
wind and water : heat and pressure
sediment : materials
sedimentary rock : metamorphic rock

source_subject: How does sedimentary rock form?

Wind and water erode rocks.

Sediment is carried to an area by the wind, water, air, or ice.
Sediment is deposited on the same spot many times.
The sediment piles on top of other sediment for a long time.
The sediment near the bottom is compressed by the weight of newer sediment.
The sediment becomes sedimentary rock as it is pushed together by the heavy weight.
target_subject: How does metamorphic rock form?
target_text:
Molten rock is created by the collisions of tectonic plates deep beneath the Earth's surface.
The molten rock is pushed to the surface by the pressure of the plates.
As the molten rock rises, it cools and hardens, forming a volcanic mountain.
In time, this mountain may erode away due to wind, water, and ice, leaving behind rock fragments.
These rock fragments are transported to other areas and deposited, eventually piling up and becoming compressed by the weight of the new rock.
Over time, this rock is transformed into metamorphic rock.
target_mappings:
wind and water : wind, water, and ice
sediment : rock fragments
sedimentary rock : metamorphic rock

Sediment is deposited on the same spot many times.
The sediment piles on top of other sediment for a long time.

The sediment becomes sedimentary rock as it is pushed together by the heavy weight.
target_subject: How does metamorphic rock form?
target_text:
Magma cools and hardens to form rocks.
The cooling magma contracts and cracks.
Water, wind, and ice carry away debris that broke off from the original rock.
The debris is carried to an area and deposited multiple times.
The debris accumulates over a long period of time and is compressed by the weight of the other debris.
This pressure causes the debris to become metamorphic rock.
target_mappings:
Wind and water : water, wind, and ice
Sediment : debris
Sedimentary rock : metamorphic rock

source_subject: How are mountains formed?
source_text:
Tectonic plates beneath the earth rub against each other.
The rocks around the cracks crumble.
An earth quake happens.
The force of the earthquake is large.
Rocks are pushed up out of the earth by the force.
These rocks become volcanos.
The volcanos erupt many times.
The size of the rocky area grows.
The volcano becomes dormant.
The volcano and its eruptions become a mountain.
target_subject: How are mountains formed?
target_text:
The Earth's molten core is constantly moving and shifting.
These movements cause the Earth's crust to move as well.
When two plates of the Earth's crust meet, they can push against each other in different directions, creating folds in the crust that eventually become mountains.
Wind and water can then erode the mountain, carving it into its current shape.
target_mappings:
Tectonic plates : plates of the Earth's crust
Earthquake : movements of the Earth's core
Rocks : folds in the crust
Volcanos : wind and water

target_subject: How do mountains erode?
target_text:
Wind and water erode the rock of a mountain over time.
The wind carries away tiny pieces of rock.
The water carries away larger pieces of rock.
The wind and water continue to erode the mountain and the area surrounding it.
The mountain gradually gets smaller and the area around it gets larger.
Eventually, the mountain will become a plain.
target_mappings:

target_subject: How are valleys formed?
target_text:
Floating chunks of ice break off glaciers.
The chunks of ice are pushed along by the currents.
The chunks of ice are carried to different areas.
The chunks of ice melt forming bodies of water.
The bodies of water can be small or large.
Rivers form from these bodies of water.
The rivers carve into the earth, forming valleys.
The valleys become deeper over time.
The sides of the valleys grow higher and higher.
These sides become the mountains.

source_subject: What happens during photosynthesis?
source_text:
Carbon dioxide enters the leaf through the stomates.
Water is absorbed by the plant and transported to the leaves.
Sunlight is captured by the plant.
Energy in the form of ATP is made from the sun's energy.
Carbon dioxide, water, and ATP form sugars via the Calvin cycle.
Oxygen is given off as a byproduct.
Oxygen leaves the leaf through the stomates.
Water is reused or it leaves the leaf.
The sugars can be used by the plant to make cellulose.
target_subject: What happens during the energy cycle?
target_text:
Heat enters the atmosphere through the sun’s radiation.
The heat is absorbed by the atmosphere and is transformed into energy.
This energy is distributed to the Earth’s surface.
The energy is stored in various forms, such as infrared radiation,
heat and other forms of energy.
The energy is used to drive different weather processes, such as cloud formation and wind.
target_mappings:
Carbon dioxide : heat
Sunlight : sun's radiation
ATP : energy
Calvin cycle : forms of energy (infrared radiation, heat, etc)
Oxygen : cloud formation
Sugars : wind

target_subject: How does an air conditioner works?
target_text:
Heat energy enters the house through the windows.
The air is cooled by the air conditioner.
The air conditioner uses electricity to cool the air.
The electricity is converted to mechanical energy.
The mechanical energy is used to rotate the fan blades.
The fan blades create a circulation of air in the house.
The air is cooled and circulated throughout the house.
The heat energy is expelled from the house with the exhaust fan.

target_subject: How does a solar panel works?
target_text:
Light enters the solar panel through the photovoltaic cells.
Electricity is generated from the solar panel.
The electricity is stored in a battery.
The electricity is converted into usable alternating current by an inverter.
The alternating current is used to power electrical devices.
The electricity can be fed into the electrical grid or stored for later use.

source_subject: What happens during photosynthesis?
source_text:
Chloroplasts in the leaf of the plant traps light from the sun.
The roots absorb water and minerals from the soil.
This combination of water and minerals flows from the stem into the leaf.
Carbon dioxide enters the leaf.
Light, water and minerals, and the carbon dioxide all mix together.
This mixture forms sugar (glucose) which is what the plant eats.
Oxygen goes out of the leaf through the stomata.
target_subject: How does an insect hear?
target_text:
The antennae of an insect catches vibrations in the air.
The antennae sends the vibrations to the brain.
The brain interprets the vibrations as sound.
The vibrations also stimulate the insect's muscles.
This combination of sound and muscle stimulation causes the insect to take action.
The insect uses its wings to fly away, or its legs to escape.

target_subject: How does a satellite dish work?
target_text:
The antenna on a satellite dish collects signals from satellites in space.
The signals are focused on the feedhorn.
The feedhorn converts the signal into electrical waves.
The electrical waves travel through a cable and into the receiver.
The receiver amplifies the signal and sends it to the TV.
The TV uses the signal to create images and sound.

Tectonic plates smash together.
The edges of the plates crumple up.
The ridges are mountain ranges.
Magma is forced to the surface.
Magma forms a volcano.
target_subject: How are hills formed?
target_text:
Winds and ocean currents erode the surface of the earth, wearing away at the land.
The material erodes and is deposited elsewhere.
As the material accumulates, the land is built up, forming hills and ridges.
Over time, the hills and ridges are built up, creating mountains.

target_subject: How are deserts formed?
target_text:
Winds pick up sand and dust.
The wind carries the sand and dust, depositing it in different places.
The sand and dust accumulates, forming dunes.
The dunes grow and move, creating sand ridges.
The sand ridges may form an entire desert.

source_subject: How are mountains formed?
source_text:
Movements of tectonic plates causes the creation of volcanoes.
These volcanoes erupt.
Volcanic mountains are formed from the eruption.
Sometimes tectonic plates crash into one another or ride over one another.
These plates sometimes fold and buckle, which forms Fold Mountains.
Sometimes fault blocks are raised or tilted, and they form Block Mountains.
target_subject: How are valleys formed?
target_text:
Movement of glaciers can cause the formation of valleys.
The glaciers slowly erode the rock and soil of the land.
The erosion causes the land to slowly sink and form a valley.
Sometimes the glaciers create huge crevasses and move large portions of the land, creating cliffs and other landforms.
Glaciers can also drop large amounts of sediment causing the area to become a flat meadow or a marsh.

target_subject: How do rivers and lakes form mountains?
target_text:
When water accumulates in large quantities,
it can form large bodies of water, such as rivers and lakes.
Winds and currents can cause the water to move, eroding the land and forming valleys.
The land can become so eroded that it forms a canyon.
The flow of the water can also cause sediment to collect and form a delta.
These changes in the land can lead to the formation of mountains.

target_subject: How are mountains formed?
target_text:
The Earth's crust is made up of several plates.
When these plates move and collide, they create a force that pushes the land upwards.
This force pushes the land to form mountains.
The mountains can form when the plates move towards each other, away from each other, or slide along each other.
The force of the plates' movement can fold and uplift the land, creating Fold Mountains.
The force of the plates' movement can also create large blocks of land, which are tilted and raised, forming Block Mountains.

source_subject: Describe the process of evaporation
source_text:
Water is exposed to heat energy, like sunlight.
The water temperature is raised above 212 degrees fahrenheit.
The heat breaks down the molecules in the water.
These molecules escape from the water.
The water becomes vapor.
The vapor evaporates into the atmosphere.
target_subject: Describe the process of melting
target_text:
Ice is exposed to heat energy, like a flame.
The temperature of the ice is raised above 32 degrees fahrenheit.
The heat breaks down the molecules in the ice.
These molecules escape from the ice.
The ice becomes liquid.
The liquid melts and is absorbed into the ground.

212 degrees : 32 degrees
vapor : liquid

source_subject: What do lungs do?
source_text:
You breathe oxygen into your body through the nose or mouth.
The oxygen travels to the lungs through the windpipe.
The air sacs in the lungs send the oxygen into the blood stream.
The carbon dioxide in the blood stream is transferred to the air sacs.
The lungs expel through the nose or mouth back into the environment.
target_subject: What does the heart do?
target_text:
The heart pumps oxygen-rich blood to the body through arteries.
The oxygen is distributed to the organs and tissues of the body.
The organs and tissues use the oxygen to produce energy.
The carbon dioxide generated from the energy production is transported back to the heart through veins.
The heart pumps the carbon dioxide-rich blood to the lungs for expulsion into the environment.
target_mappings:
Breathing : pumping
Oxygen : oxygen-rich blood
Windpipe : arteries
Air sacs : organs and tissues
Carbon dioxide : carbon dioxide-rich blood

target_subject: What do roots do?
target_text:
The roots of a plant absorb water and minerals from the soil.
The water and minerals travel through the stem and leaves.
The leaves use the energy of sunlight to create glucose through the process of photosynthesis.
The glucose is sent to the other parts of the plant.
The roots absorb the excess water and minerals and send it back to the soil.

source_subject: How do bats use echolocation?
source_text:
Bats fly through an area.
The bat makes sounds with their mouth or nose.
The sound waves travel away from the bat.
The sound waves hit objects.
The sound waves bounce off the objects back towards the bat.
The bat hears the sound waves echoing off the objects.
The bat knows where the objects are because of where the sound echoed from.
The bat doesn't hurt itself by hitting the objects.
target_subject: How do submarines use sonar?
target_text:
A submarine travels through an area.
The submarine sends out sonar pulses.
The sonar pulses travel away from the submarine.
The sound waves hit objects.
The sound waves bounce off the objects back towards the submarine.
The submarine picks up the sound waves echoing off the objects.
The submarine knows where the objects are because of where the sound echoed from.
The submarine avoids hitting the objects.
target_mappings:

Mouth or nose : sonar pulses
Sound waves : sound waves
Objects : objects

target_subject: How do drivers use headlights?
target_text:
A driver operates a car through an area.
The driver uses the car's headlights to illuminate the area.
The light waves travel away from the car.
The light waves hit objects.
The light waves bounce off the objects back towards the car.
The driver sees the light waves reflecting off the objects.
The driver knows where the objects are because of where the light reflected from.
The driver can see the objects and avoid hitting them.

source_subject: How do bats use echolocation?
source_text:
Bats fly through an area.
The bat makes sounds with their mouth or nose.
The sound waves travel away from the bat.
The sound waves hit objects.
The sound waves bounce off the objects back towards the bat.
The bat hears the sound waves echoing off the objects.
The bat knows where the objects are because of where the sound echoed from.
The bat doesn't hurt itself by hitting the objects.
target_subject: How do dolphins use echolocation?
target_text:
A dolphin swims through the ocean.
The dolphin makes clicks with its mouth.
The sound waves travel away from the dolphin.
The sound waves hit objects such as fish or rocks.
The sound waves bounce off the objects back towards the dolphin.
The dolphin hears the sound waves echoing off the objects.
The dolphin knows where the objects are because of where the sound echoed from.
The dolphin can safely navigate around the objects.
target_mappings:

Mouth or Nose : mouth
Objects : fish or rocks

source_subject: How do the lungs work?
source_text:
Air enters the nose or mouth and travels through the windpipe into the lungs.
The lungs have a series of smaller and finer tubes and sacs.
Air reaches the smallest and finest air sacs called alveoli.
Oxygen travels from the alveoli into the blood.
Oxygen-rich blood is carried to the heart.
Oxygen-rich blood is pumped throughout the body by the heart.
Cells take in the oxygen rich blood and release carbon dioxide rich blood.
The carbon dioxide rich blood travels to the lungs.
Carbon dioxide travels through the throat and is exhaled.
target_subject: How does a river work?
target_text:
The water enters the river from its source.
The river flows through a series of channels and pools.
The water reaches the smallest and deepest pools called eddies.
The current from the eddies carries the water downstream.
The river water is then used by plants and animals to survive.
The water passes through the wetlands, absorbing pollutants.
The water is then filtered and discharged back into the river.
target_mappings:
Air : water
Windpipe : channels
Alveoli : eddies
Oxygen-rich blood : current
Heart : downstream
Carbon dioxide rich blood : pollutants
Throat : wetlands

The water travels to the nozzle, where it is released.

The oxygen is returned to the atmosphere.

source_subject: Describe the process of recycling an aluminum can
source_text:
You place aluminum cans and other products into recycling bins.
Your town or a private company collect and transport the aluminum to a recycling facility.
The aluminum is sorted and cleaned at the central recycling facility.
The aluminum is melted down to remove coatings and inks.
The melted aluminum is formed into large formations called ingots.
The ingots are transported to another facility and rolled out to make them easier to manipulate.
The ingots can now be turned into new aluminum products.
target_subject: Describe the process of recycling a plastic bottle
target_text:
You place plastic bottles and other products into recycling bins.
Your town or a private company collect and transport the plastic to a recycling facility.
The plastic is sorted and cleaned at the central recycling facility.
The plastic is melted down to remove contaminants and dirt.
The melted plastic is formed into large formations called pellets.
The pellets are transported to another facility and extruded to make them easier to manipulate.
The pellets can now be turned into new plastic products.
target_mappings:
aluminum cans : plastic bottles
ingots : pellets

source_subject: How do muscles work?
source_text:
Muscles work by expanding and contracting.
A muscle fiber gets a signal from its nerve.
Proteins and chemicals release energy to either contract the muscle or relax it.
When the muscles contracts the bones connected to he muscle are pulled closer together.
When the muscle relaxes the bones move farther apart.
target_subject: How do levers work?
target_text:
Levers work by moving around a pivot point.
The lever is moved by an external force.
The force is used to move the lever around the pivot point in either direction.
When the lever moves in one direction, the two ends of the lever move closer together.
When the lever moves in the other direction, the two ends of the lever move farther apart.

source_subject: How does rain occur?
source_text:
Water droplets in clouds collide.
Become bigger drops.
Ice particles also grow in clouds.
Drops and ice particles get heavier.
Drops fall to the ground.
Ice particles fall from the clouds.
Ice particles fall through warmer air and melt.
Ice reaches the ground as rain drops.

Drops fall to the ground.

target_text:
Dust particles in the atmosphere collide.
These particles become bigger and heavier.
The particles become too heavy to stay in the atmosphere and fall to the ground.
The particles settle on the ground and form a layer of dust.
With time, the dust particles are compressed to form a layer of rock.

source_subject: How does rain occur?
source_text:
Water evaporates because of the sun.
Water vapor rises into the air as it evaporates.
Water vapor forms clouds as it mixes with dust and impurities.
Clouds become heavier and larger over time.
Clouds eventually become too heavy to stay in the sky.
Some water vapor exits clouds as rain.
target_subject: How does snow occur?
target_text:
Heat from the sun causes ice to evaporate on Earth's surface.
Water vapor rises into the atmosphere and mixes with dust and impurities.
This mixture of vapor and dust forms clouds.
As the clouds become heavier and larger, they may collide with other clouds or reach higher temperatures.
The clouds eventually become too heavy or reach a high enough temperature, causing the water droplets to condense and form precipitation.

target_subject: How does snow occur?

The heat causes the minerals to evaporate and rise into the air.
As the minerals mix with dust and other particles, they form dust clouds.
The dust clouds become heavier over time as more minerals are added.
When the dust clouds become too heavy, they descend back to the ground in the form of snow.

source_subject: How are clouds formed?
source_text:
Warm air rises.
Then it expandes and cools.
Some of the vapor condenses onto tiny pieces of dust that are floating in the air.
Forms a tiny droplet around each dust particle.
Billions of these droplets come together they become a visible cloud.
target_subject: How is haze formed?
target_text:
A rock is heated by the sun.
The heat causes the rock to expand and the molecules to move faster.
The molecules collide with each other and become electrically charged.
The electrically charged molecules attract other molecules and form tiny particles.
Millions of these particles form a visible haze in the sky.

source_subject: How does a battery-operated sewing machine work?
source_text:
Electricity from the battery makes the machine needle move.
A needle with thread goes down from the machine.
Goes through a piece of cloth.
A hook rotates underneath.
The hook captures the thread.
The hook loops the thread around another thread.
Two threads interlock around the fabric.

source_subject: How do dams help stop flooding?
source_text:
A dam is built in an area prone to flooding.
A large amount of rain occurs.
The water builds up behind the dam.
The dam opens its floodgates when it starts to get full.
The water flows into a river below the dam.
The dam closes its gates.
The dam will occasionally open its gates again to gradually release more water.
Eventually all of the floodwater will be slowly released into the river without causing any flood damage.
target_subject: How do levees help stop flooding?
target_text:
A levee is constructed in an area prone to flooding.
A large amount of rain occurs.
The water builds up around the levee.
The levee is designed with floodgates that can be opened when it starts to get full.
The water flows away from populated areas towards a river or lake.
The floodgates close when the water level drops.
The levee will occasionally open its gates again to gradually release more water.
Eventually all of the floodwater will be slowly released without causing any flood damage.
target_mappings:
Dam : levee
Floodgates : floodgates

source_subject: How does echolocation work?
source_text:
Bats and other animals produce a high-pitched tone.
The sound travels in waves, as sound does.
The sound "bounces" off of a nearby object.
The sound wave returns to the bat.
The bat hears the echoed sound.
Folds in the bat's ear and adaptations in the bat's brain enable it to determine the size, shape, and position of the other object via the properties of the returned sound waves.
Other animals use echolocation in generally similar ways.
target_subject: How does reflection work?
target_text:
Light is emitted from a source, such as a flashlight.
The light travels in waves, as light does.
The light "bounces" off of a nearby object.
The light wave returns to the source.
The source sees the reflected light.
The properties of the returned light waves enable it to determine the size, shape, and position of the other object.
Other sources use reflection in generally similar ways.
target_mappings:

High-pitched tone : Light
Echolocation : Reflection

target_subject: How does radar work?
target_text:
Radar systems send out radio waves.
The radio waves travel in a straight line, as radio waves do.
The radio waves "bounce" off of a nearby object.
The radio wave returns to the radar system.
The radar system detects the echoed radio wave.
Properties of the returned radio waves enable it to determine the size, shape, and position of the other object
Radar is used in many areas, including aviation, military, and navigation.

target_text:

source_subject: How do rings form inside the trunk of a tree?
source_text:
The growing season starts.
Bark grows on a tree.
The inside of the tree grows.
The bark is pushed out around the tree trunk.
The bark leaves a ring.
The growing season slows down and ends.

Snow accumulates on the ground.
Ice forms as temperatures drop.
The ice accumulates around rocks and trees.
The ice pushes the rocks and trees apart, leaving a gap.
The ice melts as temperatures rise and the winter season ends.

source_subject: How do rings form inside the trunk of a tree?
source_text:
The inner portion of the ring is formed during rapid spring growth.
The tree's growth slows as the seasons change.
The ring's outer growth is more dense.
The growth of the tree pushes out the bark of the tree.
The tree stops growing quickly in the winter.
This seasonal "pause" in growth results in distinct rings in certain tree types.
target_subject: How do layers form inside a planet?
target_text:
The core of the planet is formed during rapid growth of the planet.
Gravitational forces cause the planet to slow down as it continues to grow.
The outer layers of the planet are more dense.
The pressure from the core pushes out the crust of the planet.
The growth of the planet slows in the cold void of space.
This seasonal "pause" in growth results in distinct layers in certain planets.

source_subject: Describe the process of breathing.
source_text:
You breathe in through your nose or mouth.
The air travels through your windpipe.
Into your lungs.
Inside your lungs are tiny air sacs.
The air sacs transfer the oxygen into your blood.
The oxygen travels through your blood stream.
The carbon dioxide from your blood stream is transferred to your air sacs.
You breathe out and expel the carbon dioxide from your lungs.
target_subject: Describe the process of plant growth.
target_text:
A seed is planted in the soil.
The seed absorbs water and nutrients from the soil.
The seed begins to sprout and sends down its roots into the soil.
The roots absorb more water and nutrients.
The sprout grows and sends a shoot up to the surface of the soil.
The shoot takes in sunlight and begins to photosynthesize.
The plant uses the energy from the sunlight to produce food and grows leaves, stems, and flowers.
target_mappings:

nose/mouth : soil
windpipe : water and nutrients
lungs : roots
air sacs : shoot
blood stream : sunlight
carbon dioxide : energy

source_subject: Describe the process of breathing.
source_text:
You breathe in through your nose or mouth.
The air travels through your windpipe.
Into your lungs.
Inside your lungs are tiny air sacs.
The air sacs transfer the oxygen into your blood.
The oxygen travels through your blood stream.
The carbon dioxide from your blood stream is transferred to your air sacs.
You breathe out and expel the carbon dioxide from your lungs.
target_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis.
target_text:
A tree takes in carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
The carbon dioxide travels through the leaves of the tree.
Inside the leaves are chloroplasts.
The chloroplasts conduct photosynthesis, converting the carbon dioxide into oxygen.
The oxygen travels through the leaves and is released into the atmosphere.
The tree also produces glucose from the process.
target_mappings:
Breathe in : take in carbon dioxide
Nose or Mouth : atmosphere
Windpipe : leaves
Lungs : chloroplasts
Air sacs : conduct photosynthesis
Oxygen : oxygen
Carbon Dioxide : glucose

You breathe out and expel the carbon dioxide from your lungs.
target_subject: Describe the water cycle.
target_text:
Water evaporates from the surface of a lake.
The water molecules float up into the atmosphere.
The water molecules travel through the air and condense in the clouds.
The clouds become heavy with water and the water droplets form.
The droplets fall down to the ground as rain.
The rain is absorbed by the soil and flows down into the lake.
target_mappings:
Breath in : Water evaporates
Windpipe : atmosphere
Lungs : clouds
Air sacs : water droplets
Blood stream : soil
Breath out : rain

source_subject: Describe the process of breathing.
source_text:
You inhale air through your nose and mouth.
The air travels down into your lungs.
Oxygen from the air goes into your bloodstream.
Oxygen circulates throughout the body due to the heart's pumping.
Carbon dioxide travels from the blood into the lungs.
Carbon dioxide travels from the lungs up the windpipe.
Carbon dioxide is exhaled.
target_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis.
target_text:
A tree takes in carbon dioxide through its leaves.
The carbon dioxide is then used in photosynthesis.
Water and energy from the sun is also used in the process.
Oxygen is created as a byproduct of photosynthesis.
The oxygen is then released into the air.
target_mappings:
Inhale air : take in carbon dioxide
Oxygen : oxygen
Bloodstream : air
Heart : sun
Lungs : leaves
Windpipe : tree
Carbon dioxide : carbon dioxide

target_subject: Describe the process of digestion.
target_text:
You eat food through your mouth.
The food travels down your esophagus into your stomach.
Nutrients from the food go into your bloodstream.
The nutrients circulate throughout the body due to the heart's pumping.
Waste products travel from the blood into the intestines.
The waste products travel from the intestines through the rectum.
The waste products are excreted.

target_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis.
target_text:
A plant absorbs water through its roots.
The water is then transported up through the stem and leaves.
Minerals from the soil are taken into the plant, providing essential nutrients.
The water and minerals are used in photosynthesis.
Carbon dioxide is taken in through the leaves.
The plant uses the sunlight and carbon dioxide to produce oxygen and glucose.
The oxygen is released into the atmosphere, while the glucose is stored in the plant.

source_subject: How does recycling work?
source_text:
People separate different materials to be recycled.
The recyclable materials go to a recycling center.
The recycling center further separates the materials.
Large equipment compacts the materials into bales.
The recyclable materials are shipped to other recycling centers.
The other recycling centers further process the materials that center specializes in.
The materials are purchased by manufacturers.
The manufacturers process the recycled materials the same way they would use new materials.
The recycled materials are incorporated into new products.
target_subject: How does composting work?
target_text:
People separate different materials to be composted.
The compostable materials are put into a compost bin.
The compost bin is placed in a location with suitable temperature and moisture.
Microorganisms break down the compostable materials into compost.
The compost is spread in the garden or used by farmers.
The compost is an organic fertilizer that helps plants to grow.
The compost can also be used to improve soil structure and increase water retention.
target_mappings:
Recycling center : compost bin
Bales : compost
Process : break down
Manufacturers : garden or farmers
Processed materials : organic fertilizer

target_subject: How does scrap recycling work?
target_text:
Scrap cars are taken to a junkyard.
The junkyard separates the cars into different categories such as engines, tires, metals, and plastics.
The parts are then further broken down into individual parts.
Large equipment then compacts the scrap into cubes.
The scrap cubes are shipped to other scrap yards.
The other scrap yards further process the materials that center specializes in.
The materials are then purchased by manufacturers.
These manufacturers process the scrap the same way they would use new materials.
The scrap is then incorporated into new products.

Recycling centers : junkyards
Bales : cubes

Resources are collected.
The resources are separated into different categories.
Any unusable items are discarded.
The items are then sent to different locations for further processing.
The items are placed into a machine to make raw materials.
The raw materials are then shipped to factories to be used to make products.

source_subject: How does an electromagnet work?
source_text:
Wire is wrapped around a piece of metal.
Current is sent through the wire.
A magnetic field is produced by the current.
This magnetic field in the wire interacts with certain particles in the central metal part.
The piece of metal becomes magnetized.
The magnetism remains until the current is shut off.
target_subject: How does an electromagnet work?
target_text:
A coil is wrapped around a piece of iron.
Electricity is sent through the coil.
The electricity creates a magnetic field around the iron.
The magnetic field from the coil interacts with the iron, causing it to become magnetized.
The magnetism remains until the electric current is shut off.
target_mappings:
Wire : coil
Current : electricity
Metal : iron

target_subject: How does a solar panel work?
target_text:
Light is focused on a solar panel.
Photons from the light interact with electrons in the solar panel.
This interaction causes the electrons to move and generate an electric current.
The electric current is then used to power devices or stored in a battery.
The electricity is produced as long as light is focused on the solar panel.

source_subject: How do you make ice cubes?
source_text:
Put water in an ice cube tray.
Put the ice cube tray in the freezer.
Wait 5 to 6 hours.
Take the ice cube tray out of the freezer.
Bend the tray slightly to get the ice cubes out and into a drink.
target_subject: How do you make popsicles?
target_text:
Fill a popsicle mold with juice or a smoothie.
Place the popsicle mold in the freezer.
Wait for 4 to 6 hours.
Take the popsicle mold out of the freezer.
Dip the mold in warm water for 10 seconds to get the popsicles out.
target_mappings:
Ice cube tray : popsicle mold
Ice cubes : popsicles
Water : juice or smoothie

Place the tray in the freezer.
Close the freezer door.

target_subject: How do you bake a cake?
target_text:
Gather the ingredients for the desired recipe.
Mix the ingredients together in a bowl.
Grease and line a baking tin with parchment paper.
Pour the mixture into the baking tin.
Place the baking tin on the center rack of the preheated oven.

source_subject: Describe the process of pollution causing bad effects on the enviroinment.
source_text:
Pollution enters natural water sources such as rivers and lakes.
The pollution negatively affects the water quality.
The pollution negatively affects the health of plants and animals.
The plants and animals have shorter, less healthy lives.
The plants and animals do not reproduce very well.
The number of plants and animals decreases over time.
The quality of water gets worse and worse as there are no plants or animals to clean it.
Eventually there is nothing living in the water and it is unusable.
target_subject: Describe the process of deforestation causing bad effects on the environment.
target_text:
Deforestation occurs when forests are cleared for development or agriculture.
The loss of trees leads to soil erosion and the destruction of habitats for wildlife.
The destruction of habitats leads to a decrease in biodiversity in the area.
The wildlife in the area have to relocate or die.
The soil erosion leads to the release of sediment into water sources such as rivers and lakes.
The sediment changes the water's chemistry, making it unusable for drinking or irrigation.
The loss of biodiversity and the destruction of water sources can have long term negative effects on the environment.
target_mappings:
Pollution : deforestation
Natural water sources : forests
Plants and animals : wildlife
Clean : relocate

target_text:

The air pollution negatively affects the air quality.
The air pollution negatively affects the health of humans and animals.
The individuals have shorter, less healthy lives.
The individuals do not reproduce very well.
The number of individuals decreases over time.
The air quality gets worse and worse as there are no individuals to clean it.
Eventually there is nothing living in the air and it is unusable.

target_subject: Describe the process of pollution causing bad effects on the environment?
target_text:

The pollution negatively affects the health of humans, animals, and plants.
Humans, animals, and plants experience shorter and less healthy lives.
The polluted air makes it difficult for humans, animals, and plants to reproduce.
The number of humans, animals, and plants decrease over time.
The quality of air gets worse and worse as there are no humans, animals, or plants to clean it.
Eventually the air is too polluted and it is unsafe to breathe.

source_subject: What happens during respiration?
source_text:
Cells obtain glucose and oxygen.
The glucose and oxygen create carbon dioxide.
The cells release energy.
The cells don't have enough oxygen to repeat this.
The cells obtain more oxygen from the air.
The cells repeat this process.
target_subject: What happens during combustion?
target_text:
An internal combustion engine takes in air and gasoline.
The air and gasoline create combustible gases.
The engine releases energy.
The engine does not have enough air and fuel to continue this process.
The engine obtains more air and fuel from the fuel tank.
The engine then repeats this process.
target_mappings:

Carbon dioxide : combustible gases
Cells : engine

target_text:
The sun radiates energy, which is captured by solar panels.
The solar panels convert the solar energy into electrical energy.
The electrical energy flows through wires and enters a battery.
The battery stores the energy until it is needed.
The energy is then released as electrical current and used to power different devices.

source_subject: Describe how bacteria can cause disease.
source_text:
Someone is infected with bacteria.
That bacteria begins to grow and reproduce inside the cells.
The dividing bacteria begin to make toxins.
Those toxins damage your cells.
Disease symptoms may begin.
target_subject: Describe how a virus can cause disease.
target_text:
Someone is infected with a virus.
The virus begins to replicate inside the cells.
The replicating virus begins to produce proteins.
These proteins can interfere with the functioning of the cells.
Disease symptoms may begin.
target_mappings:
Bacteria : virus
Toxins : proteins

This damage can result in symptoms of the disease.

source_subject: Describe how bacteria can cause disease.
source_text:
Bacteria enter the body.
Bacteria start to divide and grow.
The uncontrolled growth takes away resources from other cells.
Other cells cannot function properly.
We feel unwell.
The growth and division of bacteria produce toxins.
Toxins harm the body.
The body tries to react to the toxins.
The body's natural defenses can sometimes cause us to feel unwell.

The replication of viruses produce toxins.

The body tries to react to the toxins.
The body's natural defenses can sometimes cause us to feel unwell.

source_subject: How do you use a skateboard?
source_text:
Place your non dominate foot on the front of the skateboard.
Push off with your other foot on the ground.
Keep pushing with your dominate leg.
When comfortable put both feet on the skateboard.
Balance your body as you roll on the skateboard.
target_subject: How do you ride a bicycle?
target_text:
Sit on the bike seat.
Place one foot on the pedal.

source_subject: How does weathering cause rocks to break apart?
source_text:
Particles in the environment interact with rocks.
The particles remove small pieces of the rock each time they touch the rocks.
The particles continue to hit, brush against, or grow against the rocks.
The rock eventually is broken apart by this contact.
The pieces of the rock are now small rocks.
The rock pieces are worn away into smaller and smaller pieces by the same forces.
target_subject: How does a tree break apart rocks and soil?
target_text:
A tree is exposed to the elements of nature.
The wind blows and causes the branches to sway.
The sun's rays create heat and dryness.
The rain and snow add moisture to the tree.
The tree grows under these conditions.
The tree's roots dig deep into the ground.
The roots spread out, eventually breaking apart rocks and soil.

Rocks : tree
Small pieces of the rock : branches

The plants remove nutrients from the soil each time they take root and grow.

The soil is now less fertile.
The soil continues to be depleted by the same forces.

source_subject: What happens during weathering?
source_text:
Rain falls on wood.
The rain seeps into the wood surface.
It permeates the wood.
When rain evaporates it leaves the wood.
It takes the finish of the wood with it.
The wood begins to lose it's luster.
It begins to look bad.
It has pieces of paint missing from the rain.
It gets worse when it rains.
It eventually will have no paint left.
target_subject: How does wind erosion work?
target_text:
Wind blows across rocks.
The wind erodes the surface of the rock.
It erodes away the material on the rock.
The wind carries away the eroded material.
The surface of the rock begins to get smoother.
Smaller pieces of rock fall off and get carried away.
The rock loses its sharp edges and begins to look weathered.
It eventually becomes much smoother and more rounded.

Wood : Rocks

Over time, the rocks may become unrecognizable due to the weathering effects of the wind.

source_subject: How do green plants get the energy they need?
source_text:
Sunlight shines on plants.
Cells with chlorophyll in them capture the light energy.
Plants absorb carbon dioxide through their stoma.
Plants absorb water through their roots and other parts of themselves.
Plants absorb minerals through their roots.
Plants convert these inputs into sugars.
Sugars can be used as energy sources.
Oxygen and water are also produced.
Excess water and oxygen are released through stoma and other parts of the plant.
target_subject: How does a solar panel get energy?
target_text:
Heat radiates from the sun onto a solar panel.
Photovoltaic cells capture the energy from the sunlight.
The cells convert the energy into direct current.
An inverter changes the direct current into alternating current.
The alternating current is then sent to a battery for storage.
The electricity can then be used for powering appliances and other electrical devices.
target_mappings:
Sunlight : heat from the sun
Chlorophyll : photovoltaic cells
Stoma : inverter
Roots : battery
Carbon dioxide : direct current
Minerals : alternating current
Sugars : electricity

source_subject: Describe how acid rain can affect the environment.
source_text:
Acid rain flows through soil.
Chemicals from the acid rain kill plants and trees.
The acid rainwater flows into rivers and streams.
The chemicals kill fish.
The chemicals kill animals that drink the water.
Nitrogen builds up.
Nitrogen destroys fish and shellfish populations.
target_subject: Describe how climate change can affect the environment.
target_text:
Carbon dioxide is released into the atmosphere from burning fossil fuels.
The carbon dioxide traps heat from the sun, causing an increase in global temperatures.
The increase in temperature causes the polar ice caps to melt.
This melting of the polar ice caps causes sea levels to rise.
Sea levels rising causes coastal flooding, erosion of shorelines, and increased salinity in estuaries.
This flooding and erosion affects the natural habitats of land and aquatic animals, leading to species loss.
target_mappings:
acid rain : carbon dioxide
chemicals : heat
plants : polar ice caps
fish : sea levels
animals : land and aquatic animals

target_subject: Describe how smog can affect the environment.
target_text:
Smog from factories and power plants enters the atmosphere.
The smog reduces the amount of sunlight that reaches the earth.
The reduced sunlight causes the temperature to decrease.
The decreased temperature affects the growth of plants and trees.
It also causes habitats to change, affecting the survival of animals.
The smog also leads to respiratory illnesses in humans.

target_subject: Describe how air pollution can affect the environment.
target_text:
Smoke from factories rises into the atmosphere.
The smoke contains pollutants like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide.
The pollutants react with water vapor to form acid rain.
The acid rain falls on the ground, damaging the soil and killing plants.
The acid rain also flows into rivers and streams, killing the fish and other aquatic life.
The pollutants can also enter the food chain, damaging the health of animals and humans.

source_subject: Describe how acid rain can affect the environment.
source_text:
Acid rain makes waters acidic.
Causes them to absorb aluminum from soil.
The water runs off from the soil into lakes, streams, etc.
Fish and their eggs die.
Frogs and plants die.
Insects and other wildlife die.
The ecosystem is out of balance, causing further problems.
target_subject: Describe how air pollution can affect the environment.
target_text:
Air pollution contaminates the air, causing smog and other forms of air pollution.
The air pollution is made up of gases, smoke, and tiny particles.
The air pollution can be breathed in by people and animals.
This can cause health problems, including asthma and other respiratory illnesses.
The air pollution also causes damage to trees, plants, and other vegetation.
It can also damage buildings and other man-made structures.
The air pollution can also affect the climate, leading to changes in temperature and weather patterns.

source_subject: How do plants obtain and use water?
source_text:
Plants obtain water through the soil they are growing in.
The plants roots absorb the water from the soil.
Transport the water to the parts of the plant where the water is needed.
The plant uses the water as part of the photosynthesis process.
The plant creates food, called glucose, for itself.
The plant uses water to circulate the glucose around the plant to deliver the glucose to where it's needed.
target_subject: How do animals obtain and use food?
target_text:
Animals obtain food from the environment.
Their digestive system absorbs the nutrients from the food.
These nutrients are transported to the parts of the body where they are needed.
The nutrients are then used by the body for energy and to build and repair cells.
The nutrients are also used to create hormones and other essential molecules.
The animals use the food to circulate these essential molecules around the body to deliver them to where they are needed.
target_mappings:
water : food
soil : environment
roots : digestive system
glucose : nutrients
photosynthesis : energy and cell repair

They search for food and use their senses to identify what they can eat.
The animals then use their claws, teeth, or beaks to capture and prepare the food.
Once the food is ready, the animals ingest it and it is digested in their digestive system.
The nutrients are then transported to the cells of the body to be used for energy and growth.

The plant uses water to circulate the glucose around the plant to deliver the glucose to where it's needed.
target_subject: How do animals obtain and use food?
target_text:
Animals obtain food through different sources like hunting, scavenging, or gathering.
They transport the food back to their home to consume it.
The food is broken down into energy molecules which are then used for a variety of activities.
The energy molecules are used to move, reproduce, and produce other molecules that are necessary for the animal's growth and development.
The energy molecules are also used to maintain the animal's body temperature.

Air travels into the body.
Air reaches the lungs.
The lungs absorb the oxygen from the air.
The oxygen is transported by hemoglobin.
Red blood cells are made of hemoglobin.
Blood has a lot of red blood cells.
The heart moves the blood throughout the body.
Blood can bring the oxygen to different cells in the body.

source_subject: How does a virus infect an animal?
source_text:
The virus finds an animal cell.
The virus attaches to the cell's surface.
The cell swallows the virus.
The virus' RNA is released into the cell.
The cell mistakenly reads the virus' RNA instead of its own.
The cell creates new viruses.
The animal cell releases the new viruses.
The new viruses can infect more cells.
target_subject: How does a parasite infect a host?
target_text:
The parasite finds a host organism.
The parasite attaches to the host's surface.
The host organism is invaded by the parasite.
The parasite's genetic information is released into the host.
The host mistakenly reads the parasite's genetic information instead of its own.
The host creates new parasites.
The host organism releases the new parasites.
The new parasites can take over more hosts.

Animal cell : host organism
RNA : genetic information

source_subject: How does a virus cause disease?

The virus replicates and spreads.
The virus causes symptoms in the body as the immune system tries to expel the virus.

The species causes disruption in the environment as the native species were part of the food chain.

source_subject: How does a coal-powered power station generate electricity?
source_text:
Coal is crushed.
The coal is burned at high temperatures inside a boiler.
The heat generated converts water to steam.
The steam spins propeller blades in the turbine.
The spinning turbine rotates coils in the generator.
The rotating coils produce electricity.
The electricity can be sent through the power grid.
target_subject: How does a wind turbine generate electricity?
target_text:
The wind blows over the blades of a wind turbine.
The spinning blades turn a gearbox connected to a generator.
The generator produces electrical current.
The electrical current is converted to high voltage for long-distance transmission.
The electricity is sent through the power grid.
target_mappings:

Steam : spinning blades
Turbine : gearbox

target_subject: How does a nuclear-powered power station generate electricity?
target_text:
Nuclear fuel is loaded into a reactor core.
The fuel is bombarded with neutrons.
The bombardment causes the fuel to break down and release energy.
The energy is absorbed by the coolant in the reactor.
The coolant flows through pipes to the turbines.
The turbines spin and rotate the shafts in the generator.
The rotation of the generator produces electricity.
The electricity is sent through the power grid.

source_subject: How does a coal-powered power station generate electricity?
source_text:
The coal is pulverized to a very fine powder.
The coal powder is mixed with hot air and blown into the firebox of the boiler.
Water pumped through pipes inside the boiler is turned into steam by the heat.
The pressure of the steam pushing against a series of giant blades turns the turbine shaft.
Turbine shaft is connected to the shaft of the generator.
The magnets inside the generator spin within wire coils to produce electricity.

The uranium powder is mixed with a cooling agent and placed in a reactor vessel.
The reactor vessel is exposed to neutrons that cause a nuclear reaction.
The heat produced by this reaction is used to boil water and create steam.
The pressure of the steam pushes against the blades of a turbine, turning the turbine shaft.
The turbine shaft is connected to a generator shaft, which creates a magnetic field.
The magnetic field produces electricity.

source_subject: How does the human auditory system work?
source_text:
Sound waves enter your outer ear.
Travel through ear canal to your ear drum.
Eardrum vibrates with the incoming sound.
Send the vibrations to three tiny bones in your middle ear.
Bones in your middle ear amplify the vibrations.
Send them to your inner ear.
The vibrations activate tiny hair cells in your inner ear.
The hair cells release neurochemical messengers.
Your auditory nerve carries the message to your brain.
The brain translates the message so you can understand.
target_subject: How does the human visual system work?
target_text:
Light enters the eye through the pupil.
It travels through the lens and is focused on the retina.
The retina converts the light into electrical signals.
These electrical signals are sent through the optic nerve to the brain.
The brain interprets the signals and the person can see.
target_mappings:
Sound waves : light
Ear drum : pupil
Bones in middle ear : lens
Hair cells : retina
Auditory nerve : optic nerve
Brain : brain
