source_subject: How does the human auditory system work?
source_text:
Something makes a sound and makes sound waves.
Sound waves are "collected" by the the outer ear.
Sound waves travel through the middle ear.
Sound waves hit the eardrum.
Vibrations from the eardrum cause very small bones in the inner ear to move.
The small bones in the inner ear give information about sound to the cochlea.
The cochlea helps turn the sound vibrations into nerve signals.
The brain can take these nerve signals and can register a sound to you because of them.

The signals travel through the optic nerve to the brain.
The brain interprets the signals and builds a mental picture of what's being seen.

source_subject: How does a broken bone get treated and healed?
source_text:
A blood clot forms in the break.
Cells in the clot keep foreign objects out.
Cells create a soft callous.
Minerals are added to the callous.
The callous hardens because of the minerals.
The callous is removed by other cells.
Excess bone is removed.
The bone is restored to its initial shape and strength.
target_subject: How does the immune system fight viruses?
target_text:
The immune system identifies an underlying virus in the body.
The body sends white blood cells to fight the virus.
The white blood cells form a protective barrier around the virus.
The body produces antibodies to further combat the virus.
The antibodies bind to the virus, preventing it from replicating.
The virus is eventually destroyed and removed from the body.
The body is restored to its original healthy state.

Soft callous : protective barrier
Minerals : antibodies
Callous : virus
Excess bone : virus

source_subject: How does coal get from the ground to a power station?
source_text:
Coal is harvested from a coal mine.
The coal is transported either by train or truck to power station.
The coal is burned in a furnace.
Water is turned into steam in the boiler.
The steam is cooled in cooling towers.
The steam turns the turbines.
The generator makes electricity.
The electricity is sent through transformers.
target_subject: How does oil get from the ground to a power station?
target_text:
Oil is extracted from an oil well.
The oil is transported by pipeline or tanker to a refinery.
The oil is heated and separated into different components.
The components are cooled and sent through distillation towers.
The different components are then sent to storage tanks or to a loading terminal.
The oil is then transported to a power station or other end user.

Mine : Well

Furnace : refinery

source_subject: Describe how perspiration helps to keep someone cool.
source_text:
As the sweat evaporates the sweat sheds molecules into the air.
The sweat changes into a gas.
Heat is drawn from the sweat.
This process draws heat from the body.
The evaporation also cools the remaining sweat on the body.
target_subject: Describe how transpiration helps to keep a plant cool.
target_text:
As the water evaporates from the leaves of a plant, molecules enter the air.
The water changes into a gas.
Heat is taken from the surrounding air.
This process draws heat away from the plant.
The evaporation also cools the remaining water in the leaves of the plant.
target_mappings:

body : plant

source_subject: How do bees pollinate plants?
source_text:
A bee visits a flower.
The pollen from that flower sticks to the bee.
The bee flies to another flower of the same type.
The pollen that was stuck to the bee gets brushed onto the pistil of the flower.
The flower is pollinated.
Will begin to develop seeds and fruit.
target_subject: How do birds pollinate plants?
target_text:
A bird visits a tree.
The seeds from that tree stick to the bird's feathers.
The bird flies to another tree of the same type.
The seeds that were stuck to the bird are brushed onto the tree's branches.
The tree is pollinated.
Will begin to develop flowers and fruit.

Pollen : seeds

Pistil : branches

source_subject: How do bees pollinate plants?
source_text:
Bees land on flowers to gather nectar.
Little hairs on the bees legs attach to pollen sacs from the stamens of the flowers.
When the bees fly away, the pollen goes with the bees.
The bees land on other flowers.
The pollen sacs are rubbed off onto the stigma of the new flower.

Little hooks on their beaks attach to the fruits from the branches.
When the birds fly away, the fruits go with the birds.
The birds land on other trees.
The fruits are dropped off onto the branches of the new tree.

source_subject: What happens during the rock cycle
source_text:
Wind and water cause erosion and weathering to the rocks.
Eroded rock particles are carried away by wind or by rain, streams, rivers, and oceans.
Rock particles sink to the bottom of rivers and oceans creating a layer of sediment.
Layers of sediment stack up compacting the bottom layers.
Minerals fill in the gaps in the sediment eventuality becoming sedimentary rocks.
Rocks buried deep underground exposed to high heat and pressure become metamorphic rock.
Metamorphic rocks underground melt to become magma.
Magma flows from volcanoes in the form of lava.
Lava cools and forms igneous rock.
Igneous rock begins being weathered and eroded by water and wind.
target_subject: What happens during the fossil cycle?
target_text:
Plants, animals, and bacteria decay when they die.
This decomposition process breaks down the organic matter into small particles.
The particles are taken away by wind or by rain, streams, rivers, and oceans.
The particles settle to the bottom of rivers and oceans, forming a layer of sediment.
The layers of sediment stack up, compacting the bottom layers.
Minerals fill in the gaps in the sediment, eventually becoming sedimentary rock.
The sedimentary rock is heated and compressed underground, transforming it into metamorphic rock.
Metamorphic rocks underground melt to become magma, which is spewed out of the volcanoes in the form of lava.
The lava cools and forms igneous rocks that are eventually broken down by wind and water, beginning the cycle again.
target_mappings:
Rocks : organic matter
Erosion and weathering : decomposition
Sedimentary rocks : sedimentary rock
Metamorphic rocks : metamorphic rock
Magma : magma
Lava : lava
Igneous rocks : igneous rock

target_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
target_text:
The sun's energy causes water to evaporate and rise.
The water vapor rises and cools, forming clouds.
The clouds create precipitation in the form of rain, snow, or hail.
The rain, snow, and hail make their way to the ground and into bodies of water.
This water evaporates again and the cycle repeats.
target_mappings:
Wind and water : sun's energy
Eroded rock particles : water vapor
Sediment : clouds
Sedimentary rocks : precipitation
Metamorphic rocks : ground and bodies of water
Magma : evaporation

source_subject: What happens during the rock cycle
source_text:
Wind and water cause erosion and weathering to the rocks.
Eroded rock particles are carried away by wind or by rain, streams, rivers, and oceans.
Rock particles sink to the bottom of rivers and oceans creating a layer of sediment.
Layers of sediment stack up compacting the bottom layers.
Minerals fill in the gaps in the sediment eventuality becoming sedimentary rocks.
Rocks buried deep underground exposed to high heat and pressure become metamorphic rock.
Metamorphic rocks underground melt to become magma.
Magma flows from volcanoes in the form of lava.
Lava cools and forms igneous rock.
Igneous rock begins being weathered and eroded by water and wind.
target_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
target_text:
The sun's energy evaporates water from the oceans, rivers, and lakes.
The water vapor rises into the atmosphere and is carried by the winds to other regions.
The water vapor cools and forms clouds.
The clouds precipitate in the form of rain, snow, sleet, or hail.
The precipitation falls back to the earth’s surface and collects in bodies of water.
The cycle then starts over again.
target_mappings:
Wind & water : Sun's energy
Eroded rock particles : Water vapor
Sediment : Clouds
Metamorphic rocks : Precipitation
Magma : Bodies of water

source_subject: What happens during the rock cycle
source_text:
Rock begins as magma from a volcano.
The magma cools.
Crystals form and the magma become igneous rocks.
The igneous rocks break down into sediment.
Become sedimentary rocks.
If subjected to heat and/or pressure from plate-tectonic activity the sedimentary rocks become metamorphic rock.
The metamorphic rocks melt.
Become magma again.
target_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
target_text:
Water begins as vapor in the atmosphere.
The vapor cools and condenses into clouds.
Water droplets form in the clouds and become rain or snow.
The rain or snow falls to the ground and collects in bodies of water or on land.
The water is absorbed by plants and evaporates into the atmosphere.
The evaporated water returns to the clouds and begins the cycle again.
target_mappings:
Magma : vapor
Igneous rocks : clouds
Sediment : rain or snow
Sedimentary rocks : bodies of water or land
Metamorphic rocks : plants
Melting : evaporating

The metamorphic rocks melt.
Become magma again.
target_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
target_text:
Rain falls on the ground and is collected in the ocean.
The water evaporates and is carried by the wind to the clouds.
The water droplets in the clouds become larger and form precipitation.
The precipitation falls back to the ground and is collected in the ocean again.
The water evaporates and is repeated in a cycle.
target_mappings:
magma : rain
igneous rocks : water
sediment : water droplets
metamorphic rocks : precipitation

source_subject: What happens during the rock cycle

Rock begins as magma from a volcano.
The magma cools.
Crystals form and the magma become igneous rocks.
The igneous rocks break down into sediment.

target_subject: What happens during the water cycle?
target_text:
Water from the ocean evaporates, becoming water vapor in the atmosphere.
The water vapor condenses and forms clouds.
The clouds move over land, releasing their moisture in the form of rain or snow.
The precipitation falls to the ground, where it is absorbed into the soil.
The water flows into rivers and streams, eventually making its way back to the ocean.
The water evaporates again and the cycle continues.

source_subject: How does acid rain form?
source_text:
Human industry produces chemical compounds.
Chemical compounds rise into the air.
Chemical compounds mix with elements in clouds.
The affected rain falls to the earth.
The affected rain can harm natural and man-made objects because of its acidic content.
target_subject: How does acid rain form?
target_text:
Volcanoes erupt, releasing large amounts of ash and sulfur dioxide into the atmosphere.
The ash and sulfur dioxide mix with oxygen and water vapor in the atmosphere and form aerosols.
These aerosols rise up in the atmosphere and form clouds.
The ash and sulfur dioxide mix with the water droplets in the clouds, forming sulfuric acid.
The sulfuric acid in the clouds falls to the earth as acid rain.
target_mappings:
Human industry : volcanoes
Chemical compounds : ash and sulfur dioxide
Elements in clouds : oxygen and water vapor
Affected rain : acid rain

Human industry produces chemical compounds.
Chemical compounds rise into the air.
Chemical compounds mix with elements in clouds.
The affected rain falls to the earth.
The affected rain can harm natural and man-made objects because of its acidic content.
target_subject: How does acid rain form?
target_text:
Volcanic eruptions emit sulfur dioxide and other gases into the atmosphere.
The gases mix with atmospheric elements to form particles.
The particles mix with water vapor to form clouds.
Once the clouds reach their saturation point, they release rain containing sulfuric and nitric acids, which can damage crops, forests, and buildings.

affected rain : rain containing sulfuric and nitric acids

target_subject: How does acid rain form?

Volcanic eruptions release sulfur dioxide and other compounds into the atmosphere.
These compounds mix with oxygen and water vapor to form sulfuric acid and other acids.
The wind can carry the acids for hundreds of miles.
When the acids fall to the earth, they are called acid rain.
Acid rain can damage buildings, plants, and aquatic life.

source_subject: How does acid rain form?
source_text:
Chemicals like sulfur dioxide and nitrogen are released into the air.
These substances rise into the high atmosphere.
They react with water and oxygen.
This creates a more acidic rain.
The rain with the high acid content falls.
target_subject: How does ground-level ozone form?
target_text:
Carbon dioxide and other pollutants are released into the air.
These substances rise into the high atmosphere.
They react with sunlight and oxygen.
This creates ozone, a more toxic form of oxygen.
The ozone gets carried down to the ground.

target_subject: How does smog form?
target_text:
Dust and other particles are released into the air.
These particles rise into the atmosphere, where they meet with air pollutants like ozone.
The particles and pollutants combine to form smog.
The smog then descends back to the ground, impacting air quality and visibility.

target_subject: How does global warming occur?
target_text:
Greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane are released into the air.
These substances rise into the high atmosphere.
They trap heat and prevent it from escaping.
This causes global temperatures to rise.
The rising temperatures can affect weather patterns.

source_subject: Describe the process of desalination
source_text:
Salt water is contained in a factory or plant.
The water is boiled to a very high tempature.
The salt becomes seperated from the water.
The salt is removed.
The water is able to be drank at this point.

target_text:
Ores are contained in a mine.
The ores are heated to a very high temperature.
The minerals in the ore become seperated from the ore.
The minerals are collected.
The ore is then discarded.

Sugar is contained in a plant or factory.

source_text:
The salt water is heated.
As the saltwater is heated the water becomes a gas.
The salt particles sink to the bottom of the container.
Gaseous water is piped into another container.
Allowed to cool.
The salt particles are left behind in the first container.
The second container contains fresh water.
target_subject: Describe the process of water purification
target_text:
The polluted water is pumped into a filtration system.
The filtration system removes the pollutants from the water.
The clean water is then collected and piped into another container.
The pollutants are separated and disposed of safely.
The clean water is cooled.
The clean water is then available for use.

target_subject: Describe the process of desalination
target_text:
A solution of salt and water is placed in an evaporation pond.
The sun heats up the solution and the water evaporates.
The salt particles sink to the bottom of the pond.
The water vapor is then directed to a condensation chamber.
The water vapor condenses to form fresh water which is collected at the bottom of the chamber.
The salt particles are left behind in the evaporation pond.

target_text:
The raw sewage is treated with chemicals.
As the sewage is treated, the solid particles settle to the bottom of the tank.
The treated water is then pumped into another tank.
The water is allowed to cool and the solid particles are left behind in the first tank.
The second tank contains treated water.

source_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
source_text:
The organism must die to begin the process.
The soft tissue decomposes.
The bones are left behind.
Scavengers tear the body apart and move the bones elsewhere.
Wind and rain also scatter the bones further.
The bones left behind will weather and become buried by sand and soil.
The proteins in the bone are replaced with minerals that are dissolved in the soil.
This creates a rock-like substance called a fossil.
Water and wind erosion wear away the layers of soil on top of the fossil.
This makes discovery of the fossil possible.
target_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
target_text:
The organism must die to begin the process.
The soft tissue decomposes.
The shells are left behind.
Scavengers move the shells to other locations.
The shells are also scattered by wind and water.
The shells left behind will become buried by sand and sediment.
The proteins in the shells are replaced with minerals that are dissolved in the sediment.
This creates a stone-like object called a fossil.
Wind and water erosion wear away the layers of sediment on top of the fossil.
This makes discovery of the fossil possible.
target_mappings: Bones : shells

target_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
target_text:
The organism must die to begin the process.
The soft tissue decomposes.
The body is exposed to air and sunlight.
Scavengers spread the remains around.
The proteins in the remains are replaced with minerals that are dissolved in the air.
This creates a hard substance called amber.
Wind and sun erosion wear away the layers of dirt on top of the amber.
This makes discovery of the amber possible.

target_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
target_text:
The organism must die to begin the process.
The body starts to decay and the soft tissues are consumed by scavengers.
The bones and teeth of the organism are the only things that remain.
The bones and teeth are then scattered by the wind, water, and other animals.
The bones and teeth eventually become buried in sand and soil.
The proteins in the bones and teeth are eventually replaced by minerals that are dissolved in the soil.
This creates a rock-like substance called a fossil.
Wind and water erosion then wear away the layers of soil and sediment on top of the fossil.
This makes it possible to discover the fossil.
target_mappings:
Soft tissue : body
Bones : bones and teeth
Scavengers : wind, water, and other animals
Wind and rain : wind and water erosion

source_subject: Describe the process of global warming
source_text:
Suns heat enters atmosphere.
Green house gases enter from the earth.
Heat is trapped in atmosphere.
Different things on earth are hotter.
The overall planet is hotter.
target_subject: Describe the process of global warming
target_text:
Greenhouse gases enter the atmosphere from various sources on Earth.
These gases trap heat and prevent it from escaping into space,
causing the Earth's temperature to rise.
As the temperature rises, different parts of the Earth become warmer and the overall global temperature rises.
This phenomenon is known as global warming.
target_mappings: Sun's heat : greenhouse gases

source_subject: Describe the process of global warming
source_text:
Suns heat enters atmosphere.
Green house gases enter from the earth.
Heat is trapped in atmosphere.
Different things on earth are hotter.
The overall planet is hotter.
target_subject: Describe the process of global warming
target_text:
Greenhouse gases are released into the atmosphere by activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
These gases absorb and trap heat from the sun,
causing temperatures to rise around the world.
The warmer temperatures cause ice caps to melt and sea levels to rise.
This leads to extreme weather events such as floods and droughts,
which can cause significant damage to ecosystems and people.
target_mappings:
Sun's heat : greenhouse gases
Earth : activities like burning fossil fuels and deforestation
Atmosphere : absorb and trap heat from the sun
Different things on earth : warmer temperatures
Overall planet : extreme weather events

Different things on earth are hotter.
The overall planet is hotter.
target_subject: Describe the process of climate change
target_text:
Greenhouse gases enter the atmosphere from the Earth's surface.
These gases absorb infrared radiation from the Sun and trap the heat in the atmosphere.
This increase in temperature causes the Earth's climate to change.
It affects weather patterns and sea levels, leading to extreme weather events, droughts, and floods.
target_mappings:
Sun's heat : infrared radiation
Greenhouse gases : Greenhouse gases
Atmosphere : atmosphere
Earth : Earth's surface

source_subject: Describe the process of global warming
source_text:
Human beings burn fossil fuels (oil, gas, etc.).
Carbon dioxide from the burning fossil fuels enter the atmosphere.
The make-up of the atmosphere changes.
Some energy from the sun cannot escape back through the changed atmosphere.
The earth begins to heat because of the extra trapped energy.
Human beings cut down trees.
Human beings do not re-plant the trees.
Trees cannot help take the extra carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
The extra trapped energy starts to change the earth's short term weather.
Eventually the long-term climate patterns start to change.
target_subject: Describe the process of global warming
target_text:
Human beings cause air pollution by releasing pollutants into the air.
These pollutants can come from factories, burning of fossil fuels, and other industrial activities.
The pollutants enter the atmosphere, leading to a change in the makeup of the air.
Some of the energy from the sun is trapped by the new atmosphere, leading to an increase in the temperature of the Earth.
Deforestation also contributes to global warming since trees help absorb some of the pollutants in the air.
With fewer trees, more pollutants are trapped in the air, leading to further changes in the Earth's short-term weather and long-term climate patterns.
target_mappings:
Fossil fuels : pollutants
Trees : trees

source_subject: Describe the process of global warming

Trees cannot help take the extra carbon dioxide from the atmosphere.
The extra trapped energy starts to change the earth's short term weather.
Eventually the long-term climate patterns start to change.
target_subject: Describe the process of global warming
target_text:
Humans emit pollutants into the atmosphere.
These pollutants are often in the form of gases, such as carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen oxide.
These gases increase the amount of energy trapped in the atmosphere, resulting in an increase in the average temperature of the earth's surface.
The increase in the average temperature of the earth's surface leads to the melting of polar ice caps, rising sea levels, and an increase in extreme weather events.
Humans continue to pollute the atmosphere, further exacerbating global warming.
target_mappings:
Fossil fuels : pollutants
Carbon dioxide : carbon dioxide, sulfur dioxide, and nitrogen oxide
Trees : polar ice caps

target_subject: Describe the process of ocean warming
target_text:
Humans overfish the oceans.
The fishing boats remove more fish than can be replaced.
Fish stocks are depleted.
The balance of the aquatic ecosystem is disrupted.
The food chain is affected and species have difficulty reproducing.
The ocean's temperature starts to rise because of overfishing.
Coral bleaching occurs and aquatic habitats are destroyed.
The ocean's ability to absorb carbon dioxide is decreased.
The excess carbon dioxide remains in the atmosphere and contributes to global warming.
target_mappings:
Fossil fuels : overfishing
Carbon dioxide : carbon dioxide
Trees : fish stocks
Extra energy : ocean temperature

source_subject: Describe the process of the greenhouse effect
source_text:
Solar radiation reaches Earth's atmosphere.
Some is reflected back into space.
The rest of the energy is absorbed by land and oceans, heating the Earth.
Heat radiates from Earth to space.
Some of this heat is trapped by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
Human activities such as burning fuel are increasing the amount of greenhouses gases.
This causes more heat radiation to stay trapped in our atmosphere.
The Earth's temperature rises.
target_subject: Describe the process of the aerosol effect
target_text:
Light from the sun reaches Earth's atmosphere.
Some is reflected back into space.
The rest of the energy is absorbed by land and oceans, warming the Earth.
Heat radiates from Earth to space.
Some of this heat is trapped by aerosols in the atmosphere.
Human activities such as burning fuel are increasing the amount of aerosols.
This causes more heat radiation to stay trapped in our atmosphere.
The Earth's temperature rises.
target_mappings: Greenhouse gases : aerosols

source_subject: Describe the process of the greenhouse effect

Some is reflected back into space.
The rest of the energy is absorbed by land and oceans, heating the Earth.
Heat radiates from Earth to space.
Some of this heat is trapped by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
Human activities such as burning fuel are increasing the amount of greenhouses gases.
This causes more heat radiation to stay trapped in our atmosphere.
The Earth's temperature rises.
target_subject: Describe the process of the cloud effect
target_text:
Heat is generated from the Earth's core and reaches the atmosphere.
Some of this heat is reflected back into space.
The rest of the energy is absorbed by the air and water, creating thermal energy.
Thermal energy radiates from Earth to space.
Some of this thermal energy is trapped by clouds in the atmosphere.
Volcanic eruptions and other natural events cause more clouds to form, trapping more thermal energy.
The Earth's temperature rises.
target_mappings:
Solar radiation : heat
Greenhouse gases : clouds

The Earth's temperature rises.
target_subject: Describe the process of the ozone layer
target_text:
Heat from the Earth's core reaches the surface, where it is released into the atmosphere.
Some of this heat is reflected back into space, while the rest is trapped in the atmosphere by a layer of ozone.
Human activities such as burning fossil fuels release compounds like carbon dioxide, which further contribute to the layer of ozone, trapping more heat in the atmosphere and causing global temperatures to rise.
target_mappings:
Solar radiation : heat from Earth's core
Greenhouse gases : layer of ozone
Burning fuel : burning fossil fuels

source_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis
source_text:
Sunlight hits chloroplasts in the plant.
The energy from the sunlight causes an enzyme in the plant to break apart the water.
The water breakes into oxygen, hydrogen, and electrons.
Hydrogen, along with electrons energized by light, converts NADP into NADPH.
Oxygen diffuses out of the plant as a waste product of photosynthesis.
target_subject: How does a car engine works?
target_text:
A car engine is powered by gasoline.
The gasoline enters the engine, where it is combined with air.
The air and gasoline are ignited by spark plugs, creating an energy-rich fuel.
The fuel is then exploded in the cylinders, creating energy.
The energy is used to power the engine, causing the crankshaft to move.

Chloroplasts : engine
Enzyme : spark plugs
Hydrogen : fuel

target_subject: Describe the process of combustion
target_text:
Electrons flow through a wire.
The electrons energize the wire, causing a spark.
The spark heats up the spark plug.
The heat causes a reaction between the gas and oxygen in the spark plug.
The reaction creates energy and waste products.
The energy is used to power the vehicle.
The waste products are released into the atmosphere.

target_subject: Describe the process of fractional distillation
target_text:
Heat is applied to a mixture of chemicals.
The energy from the heat causes the chemical compounds to break apart.
The compounds break down into their individual elements.
These elements, energized by the heat, combine to form new chemical compounds.
The newly formed compounds are then separated from the mixture.

source_text:
Sunlight strikes the chlorophyll molecules in the plant.
Is trapped.
Plant also takes in water and carbon dioxide from the environment.
The plant forms glucose.
The plant releases oxygen into the atmosphere.
target_subject: Describe the process of solar energy production
target_text:
Solar panels capture light from the sun.
The light is converted into electrical energy.
The energy is stored in a battery.
The energy can then be used to power lights, appliances, and other electronic devices.
The energy can also be sent back to the electrical grid for a profit.

target_subject: How does a solar panel work?
target_text:
The sun's energy hits the photovoltaic cells, made of semi-conductive material.
The electrons are released and flow as a direct current.
The direct current is then converted into usable alternating current by an inverter.
The alternating current can then be fed into the electrical grid or stored for later use.

Chlorophyll molecules : photovoltaic cells
Glucose : Direct current

source_subject: Describe the process of digestion
source_text:
Food is taken into the mouth.
The food is chewed.
Saliva mixes with the food and starts breaking it down.
The chewed food travels down the esophagus to the stomach.
The stomach secretes acid.
Grinds and mixes the food.
The food moves to the small intestine.
The small intestine uses enzymes to further break down the food.
The food passes into the colon.
The food is expelled from the body.

The understanding is then used to answer questions related to the book.
The reader is able to recall the information or use it to form new ideas.

Esophagus : brain
Stomach : process
Small intestine : connections
Colon : recall

source_subject: Describe the process of hibernation
source_text:
An animal eats a lot of food to fatten up.
The animal finds or builds a suitable place to hibernate where they can stay warm and protected.
The animal moves into their den.
Their heart rate and breathing slow down to conserve energy.
They emerge from the den when the weather is warming up again.
target_subject: Describe the process of migration
target_text:
A bird prepares for migration by eating a lot of food to fatten up.
The bird finds a suitable place to rest and prepares to fly.
The bird takes off and flies to their destination.
Their heart rate and breathing speed up to conserve energy.
The bird arrives at a new destination and builds a nest.
target_mappings:

Den : suitable place to rest and prepare to fly
Emerge : take off and fly

source_subject: Describe the process of hibernation
source_text:
Animals eat a lot during good (warm, clear) weather.
Animals gain weight.
The season changes to one with bad (cold, snowy) weather.
Animals find a place to hibernate.
Animals enter a type of "sleep" (hibernation).
Body processes slow down.
The animal's heart rate and breathing rate slow.
The animal loses weight more slowly than usual.
The animal is able to survive not eating or drinking without hurting itself.
target_subject: Describe the process of migration
target_text:
Birds fly south during cold weather.
The birds gain energy by eating before they start their journey.
The birds form flocks and fly together in the same direction.
The birds use the stars, landmarks, and the Sun to help guide them.
Their metabolism slows down drastically to conserve energy.
The birds use thermals to help them gain altitude and gliding to cover long distances.
The birds will find a place to rest, such as in a tree or on the ground, to rest and regain energy.
target_mappings:

Gain weight: gain energy
Hibernation : migration
Heart rate : metabolism
Lose weight : conserve energy

source_text:
Body temperature rises.
The brain tells blood vessels to dilate.
The sweat glands become active.
Moisture is released from the pores.
The moisture evaporates.

source_subject: Describe how a flashlight works
source_text:
Batteries are put in a flashlight.
The flashlight is turned on.
Two contact strips touch one another.
A circuit is completed between the batteries and the lamp.
The lamp in the flashlight begins to glow.
The reflector in the flashlight directs the lamp's beam.
A straight beam of light is generated.
The flashlight is turned off.
The circuit is broken.
The beam is no longer visible.
target_subject: Describe how a fan works
target_text:
A power source is connected to a motor.
The motor is turned on.
Current flows through the motor's windings.
The magnetic field within the windings creates a force.
The force causes the motor to turn.
The motor shaft is connected to a propeller or a fan.
The propeller or fan spins, producing a continuous flow of air.
The motor is turned off.
The flow of air is no longer generated.
target_mappings:

Lamp : motor
Reflector : propeller or fan
Contact strips : windings

source_subject: How do solar eclipses occur?
source_text:
The moon orbits the earth.
The earth orbits the sun.
The moon comes between the sun and the earth.
The sun is totally blocked.
A solar eclipse is occurring.
target_subject: How do lunar eclipses occur?
target_text:
The earth orbits the sun and the moon orbits the earth.
The moon comes between the sun and the earth.
The moon casts a shadow on the earth.
The shadow blocks the sun and causes a lunar eclipse.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a frog
source_text:
A frog lays eggs in the water.
Tadpoles develop inside of the eggs.
The eggs hatch.
The tadpoles eat and grow.
The tadpoles grow legs and form into frogs.
The frogs leave the water.

target_text:
A butterfly lays eggs on a leaf.
Caterpillars develop inside of the eggs.
The eggs hatch.
The caterpillars eat and grow.
The caterpillars form chrysalis and transform into a butterfly.
The butterfly emerges from the chrysalis and flies away.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a frog
source_text:
An adult frog spawns eggs in water.
These eggs hatch into tadpoles and continue to live in the water.
The tadpoles grow developing external gills and a longer tail.
The tadpole begins storing food in the tail.
The tadpole develops hind legs and lives off food stored in the it's tail.
The front legs appear and the tadpole's tail shortens.
The tadpole now looks like a young frog.
The young frog continues to grow to adulthood.

source_text:

It then emerges as a butterfly and begins to fly.
The butterfly continues to grow to adulthood.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a rabbit
source_text:
Baby rabbits are born alive.
Rabbits are (only occasionally) nursed by their mothers.
Many of the babies do not survive.
Larger and stronger rabbit do manage to survive.
Rabbits quickly become able to have babies of their own.
The rabbit lifecycle continues.
The amount of rabbits stays reasonable because of predators and low survival rates for their young.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a bee
target_text:
Baby bees are hatched from eggs.
The eggs are laid by a queen bee and cared for by worker bees.
The larvae are fed honey and pollen and are kept warm by the heat of the hive.
As they mature, the larvae spin cocoons and become pupae.
From the pupae, adult bees emerge.
Adult bees take on the roles of queen, drones or workers.
The number of bees stays balanced due to predators and low survival rates of their young.

target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a frog
target_text:
Frogs are born as tadpoles.
Tadpoles feed on algae and other small organisms in the water.

Frogs then hunt and feed on insects, spiders, and other small animals.

The fruit releases seeds.
The seeds become new plants.

The eggs become new butterflies and the original butterfly dies.

target_subject: How do plants absorb water and nutrients?

The water and nutrients are recycled and the process continues.

source_subject: How do lungs work?
source_text:
You breathe in.
Diaphragm and other muscles expand to allow room for your lungs to fill.
The air flows into the narrow bronchioles in the lungs.
From the bronchioles to the alveoli.
The oxygen enters into the bloodstream.
Is switched with the carbon dioxide in the bloodstream.
The carbon dioxide enters through the alveoli.
Through the narrow bronchioles.
Into the lungs.
The carbon dioxide is exhaled out of the body.

You eat food.

The food moves from the esophagus to the small intestine.
From the small intestine to the large intestine.
The nutrients enter into the bloodstream.
Vitamins and minerals are switched with the waste in the bloodstream.
The waste enters through the large intestine.
Through the small intestine.
Into the stomach.
The waste is expelled from the body.

target_text:

The blood flows through the veins and arteries, carrying oxygen and nutrients to different parts of the body.
The blood also carries away waste products, such as carbon dioxide, which is removed when the blood reaches the lungs.
The heart then pumps the oxygenated blood back to the body.

target_subject: Describe how the brain works
target_text:
The brain receives sensory information from the eyes, ears, nose, and skin.
The information is processed through neurons in the brain.
The brain filters out the important information and stores it.
The brain then sends out signals to the muscles, organs, and glands to act on the information.
Unnecessary information is discarded and forgotten.

source_subject: Describe how the liver works
source_text:
The liver removes toxins from the blood.
Liver also cleans blood that has just been enriched with vitamins and minerals during digestion.
Liver processes the good stuff into forms that the rest of the body can use.
Waste or stuff your body doesn't need can be carried by bile back into the intestine or into the kidneys.
The liver also produces a digestive juice called bile that helps the body absorb fat into the bloodstream.
The liver also stores extra carbohydrates as glycogen for the body to use as fuel when needed.
target_subject: Describe how the heart works
target_text:
The heart pumps oxygenated blood throughout the body.
The oxygenated blood carries vitamins and minerals that are essential for the body's functions.
The heart also carries away waste products and toxins from the body.
The heart pumps blood to the lungs, where it is oxygenated, and to the kidneys, where the waste is filtered and expelled.
The heart also pumps blood to the muscles, providing them with the energy needed for physical activity.
target_mappings:
toxins : waste products
bile : oxygenated blood
digestive juice : vitamins and minerals
glycogen : energy

The brain produces hormones that help regulate the body's functions.
The brain can also store memories, allowing us to learn from our experiences.
The brain also helps coordinate movement, allowing us to perform different actions.
The brain can even control automatic responses, such as breathing.

target_text:
The lungs take in oxygen from the air and filter out pollutants.
The lungs also filter out bacteria and other harmful particles from the air we breathe.
The oxygen is then circulated to the rest of the body via the bloodstream.
Carbon dioxide and other waste gases are expelled when we exhale.
The lungs also help regulate the body temperature by controlling the amount of heat that is released from the body.

source_text:
Food enters the body.
Food begins to be processed by the digestive system.
The pancreas releases enzymes to aid digestion.
Digested food affects the amount of sugar in the blood.
The pancreas releases one hormone to lower the blood sugar (glucose) level.
The pancreas releases another hormone to raisethe blood sugar (glucose) level.

source_subject: How does the body control its blood sugar level?
source_text:
Food enters the body.
The food is broken down.
Sugars from the food enter the bloodstream.
Blood sugar must be within a particular range to avoid damaging many organs.
Sometimes the brain tells the pancreas the blood sugar (glucose) is too low.
The pancreas releases glucagon to change the blood sugar to a better level.
Sometimes the brain tells the pancreas the blood sugar (glucose) is too high.
The pancreas releases insulin to change the blood sugar to a better level.
target_subject: How does a car control its fuel-air ratio?
target_text:
A car engine needs fuel to run.
The fuel is first broken down into combustible gases.
These gases enter the engine and must be within a particular ratio to run efficiently.
Sometimes the car's computer detects the combustible gases are too low.
The fuel injectors release more fuel to change the combustible gases to a better ratio.
Sometimes the car's computer detects the combustible gases are too high.
The fuel injectors reduce the amount of fuel to change the combustible gases to a better ratio.
target_mappings:
Glucose : combustible gases
Pancreas : fuel injectors
Glucagon : more fuel
Insulin : reduce the amount of fuel

source_subject: How do you make wine?
source_text:
Grapes are grown.
A selection of grapes are gathered.
The grapes are washed.
The stems are removed from the grapes.
The grapes are crushed and added to a fermation container.
Yeast is added to the container.
The yeast eats the sugar in the yeast, releasing alcohol.
target_subject: How do you make beer?
target_text:
Malt is made by soaking grains in water.
The grains are then dried and heated to activate enzymes that turn the grains' starches into sugars.
The malt is then added to hot water to steep, releasing the sugars and creating the wort.
The wort is boiled with hops to add flavor, then cooled and placed into a fermenter.
Yeast is added to the fermenter, which eats the sugars and releases alcohol and carbon dioxide.
The mixture is then left to ferment, before it is bottled or kegged.

Yeast : yeast
Fermentation container : fermenter
Sugar : sugars

source_subject: How does a steam engine work?
source_text:
Coal is heated in the boiler.
The water tank over the boiler is heated.
Creates steam.
The steam is funneled to the piston.
Piston uses the steam as energy.
The piston causes the crankshaft to move.
target_subject: How does a wind turbine work?
target_text:
A wind turbine is installed on a tall tower.
The wind turns the blades of the turbine.
The blades turn a shaft connected to a generator.
The generator converts the mechanical energy of the spinning turbine into electrical energy.
The electricity is sent to a transformer and then to a power grid.

source_subject: How does a steam engine work?
source_text:
Coal is loaded into the firebox.
The boiler produces steam under high pressure.
The steam generated in the boiler flows down into a cylinder.
Just ahead of the wheels, pushing a tight-fitting plunger, the piston.
The piston is connected to one or more of the locomotive's wheels through a kind of arm-elbow-shoulder joint called a crank and connecting rod.
As the piston pushes, the crank and connecting rod turn the locomotive's wheels and power the train along.
An outlet valve opens and the piston pushes the steam back through the cylinder and out up the locomotive's chimney.
target_subject: How does a gasoline engine work?
target_text:
A gasoline-powered car starts with gasoline entering the engine.
The gasoline is mixed with air and then compressed by the pistons in the engine.
The spark plugs then ignite the compressed gasoline and air, producing an explosion.
This explosion causes the pistons to move, which in turn turn the crankshaft, producing energy.
The crankshaft is connected to the drive shaft and eventually to the wheels, which causes the car to move.
The exhaust is expelled through the exhaust pipe.
target_mappings:
Coal : gasoline
Firebox : engine
Steam : air
Piston : pistons
Crank and connecting rod : crankshaft
Outlet valve : spark plugs
Chimney : exhaust pipe

The gear box also helps to reduce the strain on the turbine.

target_subject: How does a jet engine work?

source_subject: Describe the steps in a storm forming
source_text:
Warm weather causes water to evaporate.
The water rises up in the air.
It starts to cools down.
The water starts to condense.
It forms into clouds.
When there is enough moisture in the clouds it starts to rain.
target_subject: Describe the steps in a thunderstorm forming
target_text:
High temperatures cause air to rise.
The air cools down and water vapor starts to condense.
The condensation forms clouds.
The clouds grow as more water vapor condenses and the clouds become darker.
The clouds become so heavy that drops of rain start to fall from the sky.

When the air cools enough, it can no longer hold the moisture and precipitation falls.
The precipitation can be in the form of snow, rain, or hail, depending on the temperature.
The precipitation eventually reaches the ground and the storm is complete.

source_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a butterfly
source_text:
A butterfly starts as an egg.
The egg hatches.
A larva emerges.
The larva eats and grows.
The larva sheds its skin.
The larva enters a chrysalis.
The pupa grows inside the chrysalis.
The adult butterfly exits the chrysalis.
The adult butterfly is now fully grown.
The adult butterfly lays more eggs.

The adult frog lays more eggs.

target_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a bee
target_text:
A bee lays an egg.
A larvae matures inside of the egg.
The larva hatches from the egg.
The larva eats and grows.
The larva spins a cocoon around itself and forms into a pupa.
The adult bee forms inside of the cocoon.
The mature bee emerges from the cocoon.
The bee mates.
The female bee lays eggs.
target_mappings:
Butterfly : Bee
Caterpillar : Larva
Coccoon : Cocoon

source_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a butterfly
source_text:
A butterfly lays an egg.
A larvae matures inside of the egg.
The caterpillar hatches from the egg.
The caterpillar eats and grows.
The caterpillar spins a coccoon around itself and forms into a pupa.
The butterfly forms inside of the coccoon.
The mature butterfly emerges from the coccoon.
The butterfly mates.
The female butterfly lays eggs.
target_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a frog
target_text:
A frog lays eggs.
The eggs hatch into tadpoles.
The tadpoles feed and grow.
The tadpoles grow legs and arms and become a froglet.
The froglet matures and grows into an adult frog.
The adult frog mates.
The female frog lays eggs and the cycle begins again.
target_mappings:
Butterfly : Frog
Egg : Eggs
Larvae : Tadpoles
Caterpillar : Froglet
Coccoon : No Mapping
Pupa : No Mapping
Mature butterfly : Adult frog

source_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a butterfly
source_text:
EGG.
ITS LAID ON A LEAF OR PLANT.
THE EGG HATCHES.
THE LARVA COMES OUT(CATERPILLAR).
IT BEGINS TO EAT ON THE LEAF THAT IS WAS BORN ON.
CONTINUES TO EAT TO GROW QUICKLY.
AFTER ITS GROWN TO FULL LENGHT IT FORMS INTO A PUPA.
UNDERGOES METAMORPHOSIS TO BECOME BUTTERFLY.
AFTER HE BUTTERFLY IS FOMED IT PUMPS BLOOD INTO ITS WINGS TO GAIN STRENGHT TO BE ABLE TO FLY.
TH EBUTTERLFY IS FIANLLY ABLE TO FLY AWAY.
target_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a spider
target_text:
SPIDER.
ITS LAID ON A WEB OR IN A NEST.
THE EGG HATCHES.
THE LARVA COMES OUT (SPIDERLING).
IT BEGINS TO EAT ON THE FLY THAT IS WAS BORN ON.
CONTINUES TO EAT TO GROW QUICKLY.
AFTER ITS GROWN TO FULL LENGHT IT FORMS INTO A PUPA.
UNDERGOES METAMORPHOSIS TO BECOME SPIDER.
AFTER THE SPIDER IS FOMED IT PUMPS BLOOD INTO ITS LEGS TO GAIN STRENGHT TO BE ABLE TO WALK.
THE SPIDER IS FINALLY ABLE TO WALK AROUND.
target_mappings:
Egg : Egg
Leaf or plant : Web or nest
Caterpillar : Spiderling
Fly : Fly
Butterfly : Spider

AFTER HE BUTTERFLY IS FOMED IT PUMPS BLOOD INTO ITS WINGS TO GAIN STRENGHT TO BE ABLE TO FLY.
TH EBUTTERLFY IS FIANLLY ABLE TO FLY AWAY.
target_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a frog
target_text:
FROG.
ITS LAID ON A STONE OR IN A POOL OF WATER.
THE EGG HATCHES.
THE LARVA COMES OUT (TADPOLE).
IT BEGINS TO EAT ON THE ALGAE THAT IS WAS BORN ON.
CONTINUES TO EAT TO GROW QUICKLY.
AFTER ITS GROWN TO FULL LENGTH IT FORMS INTO A METAMORPH.
UNDERGOES METAMORPHOSIS TO BECOME FROG.
AFTER THE FROG IS FORMED IT PUMPS BLOOD INTO ITS LEGS TO GAIN STRENGTH TO BE ABLE TO JUMP.
THE FROG IS FINALLY ABLE TO JUMP AWAY.

target_subject: Describe the lifecycle of a frog
target_text:
FROG.
ITS LAID AS EGGS IN THE WATER.
THE EGGS HATCH INTO TADPOLES.
THE TADPOLES EAT ALGAE AND AQUATIC PLANTS.
AS THE TADPOLES GROW, THEY DEVELOP LEGS AND LOSE THEIR TAIL.
THEY MOVE ONTO LAND AND BECOME FROGLETS.
THE FROGLETS GROW INTO ADULT FROGS.
THE ADULT FROGS MATE AND LAY EGGS IN THE WATER.

source_subject: Describe how acid rain can affect the environment.
source_text:
Acid rain is produced by chemicals that reach into the atmosphere.
Falls onto the ground.
The acid rain starts scouring rocks.
Destroys vegetation.
The lack of vegetation alters the surrounding environment.
target_subject: Describe how air pollution can affect the environment.
target_text:
Air pollution is caused by the release of pollutants into the atmosphere.
The pollutants linger in the air, blocking the sun's rays and reducing the amount of sunlight that reaches the ground.
This lack of sunlight can cause a decrease in plant growth, leading to a decrease in biodiversity in the area.
Animals and humans can also suffer from the effects of air pollution, such as respiratory conditions or even cancer.
target_mappings:
Acid rain : air pollution
Chemicals : pollutants
Scouring rocks : blocking sun's rays
Vegetation : plant growth

source_subject: Describe how acid rain can affect the environment.
source_text:
Acid rain leaches aluminum from clay particles in soil.
Aluminum flows into streams and lakes.
Acid rain dissolves minerals and nutrients in soil.
Washes them away so plants can't benefit from them.
PH in soil and water gets affected which can kill plants and animals.
Acid rain in fog at higher elevations can strip foliage off trees.
target_subject: Describe how smog can affect the environment?
target_text:
Smog contains pollutants like NO2, ozone and particulate matter.
These pollutants can reduce visibility and cause respiratory problems.
Smog can irritate lungs, leading to coughing and chest pain.
Smog can also lead to premature death and an increase in heart and lung ailments.
Smog can damage plants, crops, and trees by blocking out sunlight and reducing plant growth.
Smog can also damage buildings, monuments and other structures.
target_mappings:
Acid rain : Smog
Aluminum : Pollutants
Soil and water : Lungs
Nutrients : Sunlight
Plants and animals : Plants, crops and trees
Foliage : Buildings, monuments and other structures

target_subject: Describe how air pollution can affect the environment.
target_text:
Air pollution causes smog and haze to form in the atmosphere.

The pollutants can also form acid rain, which damages crops, erodes buildings and monuments, and affects aquatic life.

source_subject: Describe how bacteria can cause disease.
source_text:
Skin is cut or damaged.
Bacteria enters through the wound.
The bacteria reproduces and spreads.
Causes symptoms.
The bacteria is either fought off or becomes a disease.

The virus enters the cell and reproduces.
The virus can cause changes in the cell.

The organism's immune system either fights off the virus or the virus causes a disease.

source_subject: Describe how kidneys work
source_text:
Kidneys filter waste out of blood.
Composition of blood is regulated.
Volume of water in blood is kept constant.
PH is kept at a constant level.
Kidneys help regulate blood pressure.
Kidneys stimulate the making of red blood cells.
Calcium levels are maintained.

target_text:
The liver filters toxins out of the blood.
It regulates the composition of the blood.
It helps to maintain the volume of water in the blood.
It helps to keep the pH of the blood constant.
It helps to regulate blood pressure.
It helps to stimulate the making of white blood cells.
It helps to maintain calcium levels in the blood.

source_subject: Describe how kidneys work
source_text:
Waste products are deposited in the blood.
Blood is carried to the kidneys through the renal arteries.
The kidneys contain filters inside.
The filters capture the waste products.
The waste is combined with water to make urine.
The urine leaves the kidney and is collected in the bladder.
The cleaned blood is returned to the body.
target_subject: Describe how air filtration works?
target_text:
Pollutants are released into the air.
The pollutants are spread over a large area by the wind and clouds.
The air passes through filters, such as trees and plants, which capture the pollutants.
The pollutants then settle on the ground.
The pollutants are absorbed into the soil or evaporate into the atmosphere.
The cleaned air is returned to the environment.
target_mappings:
Waste products : pollutants
Blood : air
Renal arteries : wind and clouds
Kidneys : filters, such as trees and plants
Urine : pollutants
Bladder : soil or atmosphere

target_text:
Waste products are produced in the body.
The waste is carried to the liver through the hepatic veins.
The liver contains filters inside.

The waste is combined with bile to make bile acids.
The bile acids leave the liver and are collected in the gallbladder.
The cleaned blood is returned to the body.

target_subject: How does an internal combustion engine work?

Air is drawn in through an intake valve.
The air travels to the combustion chamber.
The fuel is injected into the cylinder.
The spark plug ignites the fuel, causing combustion.
The combustion creates energy and exhaust.
The exhaust is expelled from the engine through the exhaust valve.

source_subject: Describe how oxygen reaches cells in the body
source_text:
The human body takes a breath inward.
Air is transported to the lungs.
Air reaches the alveoli, the smallest air sacs in the lungs.
In the alveoli, air passes into the blood within small capillaries.
The gaseous oxygen in the air dissolves into the capillary blood.
The dissolved oxygen is picked-up by red blood cells.
The red blood cells bind the oxygen via a protein called heme.
Red blood cells circulate throughout the body and reach the various tissues.
Within small capillaries, the heme release the oxygen.
The oxygen can then reach the cells within the tissue.
target_subject: Describe how oxygen reaches animals from plants
target_text:
The water is taken in through the root system of a plant.
The water is transported to the leaves.
The water is broken down into hydrogen and oxygen in the leaves.
The oxygen is then released into the air through the stomata.
The oxygen is then taken in by the air and can be breathed in by humans and other animals.
target_mappings:
Human body : root system of a plant
Air : water
Alveoli : leaves
Capillaries : stomata
Heme : oxygen

target_subject: Describe how nutrients reach cells in a plant
target_text:
Nutrients enter the roots of a plant.
The nutrients are transported through the plant's xylem vessels.
The vessels reach the leaves of the plant.
The nutrients are then absorbed by the mesophyll cells in the leaves.
The nutrients can now be used by the leaf cells.
The nutrients can also be transported to other parts of the plant.

target_subject: Describe how oxygen is released into the atmosphere
target_text:
A plant takes in carbon dioxide from its environment.
The carbon dioxide is transported to the leaves.
In the leaves, the carbon dioxide is absorbed into the cells.
The carbon dioxide then enters the Calvin cycle, a process of photosynthesis.
The Calvin cycle produces sugar molecules, releasing oxygen as a byproduct.
The oxygen is then released into the atmosphere.

source_subject: Describe how oxygen reaches cells in the body
source_text:
Air goes into the lungs.
The lungs remove oxygen from the air.
Oxygen diffuses from alveoli in the lungs to the bloodstream.
Hemoglobin in red blood cells attaches to the oxygen.
Red blood cells carry oxygen all around the body.
Oxygen diffuses into cells from capillaries.
target_subject: Describe how nutrients reach cells in the body
target_text:
Nutrients enter the body via the digestive system.
The nutrients are absorbed in the small intestine and enter the bloodstream.
Molecules like proteins and enzymes are transported to the cells.
The proteins are then distributed to different parts of the body.
The enzymes are used to break down and process the nutrients within the cells.
The cells use the nutrients to produce energy and other essential molecules.

source_subject: Describe how the liver works
source_text:
The liver takes in blood from the rest of the body.
The liver uses enzymes to clean the blood.
The cleaned blood is expelled.
The liver creates bile from the items filtered.
The liver takes energy and stores it as glycogen.
The bile is sent to the intestines.

The brain creates memories from the sensory information.
The brain stores the memories for later recall.
The memories are used to inform decisions and behavior.

source_text:
The pancreas detects chemical changes in the stomach.
The pancreas creates juices that help digest food.

source_subject: Describe how the pancreas works
source_text:
Over 99% of the exocrine pancreas cells produce digestive juices.
They secrete digestive juice "externally" into the small intestine.
There are enzymes for breaking down fats, proteins , and carbohydrates.
Digestive juices flows from the pancreas through an excretory duct into the small intestine.
When the blood sugar levels rise, as they might after a meal, insulin is released.
When blood sugar levels are too low, the pancreas releases glucagon into the bloodstream.
target_subject: How does the endocrine system works?
target_text:
The brain constantly monitors the body's levels of hormones.
When a hormone is low, the brain sends signals to the endocrine glands to produce more.
The endocrine glands then secrete hormones into the bloodstream.
These hormones act as messengers, traveling through the body to target organs and tissues.
The hormones help to regulate the body's metabolism, growth, and development, among other things.

target_subject: Describe how the brain works
target_text:
The brain is composed of billions of neurons that communicate with each other through synapses.
Neurons secrete neurotransmitters, which are chemicals that carry signals from one neuron to another.
Neurotransmitters can be inhibitory, meaning they reduce the chance of a nerve impulse from passing through a synapse, or excitatory, meaning they increase the chance of a nerve impulse from passing through a synapse.
When the brain perceives a stimulus, the neurons are activated, and the neurotransmitters are released, allowing the neurons to communicate and the brain to process information.

target_subject: Describe how the liver works
target_text:
The liver is responsible for producing bile.
Bile is a liquid that helps break down fat, allowing it to be digested.
Bile is produced in the liver, stored in the gallbladder, then secreted into the small intestine.
The liver also produces and secretes cholesterol, which is essential for producing hormones, building cell membranes, and making vitamins.
When the body needs energy, it releases glucose from the liver into the bloodstream, and when there is too much glucose, it stores it in the form of glycogen in the liver.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a bird
source_text:
An egg is laid by a mother bird.
A baby bird forms within the egg if it is fertilized.
The baby bird begins pecking out of the egg.
The baby bird is unable to fly to get food.
The mother bird must feed the baby bird food.
The bird grows stronger and grows wings.
The bird is able to fly.
The bird is able to leave the nest and find food.
The bird is able to reproduce.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a butterfly or moth
target_text:
A caterpillar hatches from an egg.
The caterpillar grows and molts several times.
It feeds on leaves or other plants.
The caterpillar builds a cocoon or chrysalis.
The caterpillar goes through the process of metamorphosis.
It emerges as a butterfly or moth.
The butterfly or moth feeds on nectar and mates.
The butterfly or moth lays eggs and eventually dies.

egg : egg
baby bird : caterpillar
mother bird : butterfly or moth
wings : cocoon or chrysalis
nest : process of metamorphosis
food : nectar

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a human
source_text:
A sperm meets an egg in the uterus of a woman.
The sperm implants itself into the egg.
The sperm and egg form a zygote on the wall of the uterus.
The fetus grows and develops.
The woman gives birth to a baby.
The baby is raised by parents until it is able to take care of itself.
The person goes out into the world and finds a job.
The person meets other people and has a life.
The person gets a career, and gets married.
The person retires and eventually passes away.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a plant
target_text:
A seed is planted in soil.
The seed absorbs nutrients and water from the soil.
The seed germinates and grows into a seedling.
The seedling grows into a young plant and forms leaves, stems, and roots.
The young plant continues to grow and produces flowers.
The flowers are pollinated resulting in the production of fruits and seeds.
The fruits and seeds are dispersed to other locations and the process repeats itself.

The embryo becomes a fetus.
The fetus grows for approximately 9 months.
The woman gives birth to a baby.
The baby grows into a child.
The child becomes an adult.
The adult mates with another adult.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a plant
target_text:
Seeds are produced by a mature plant.
The seeds disperse to new areas via wind or animals.
The seeds germinate, grow into sprouts, absorb nutrients from the soil and develop into young plants.
As the young plants grow, they develop leaves, stems, and roots and the process of photosynthesis starts.
The young plants continue to grow and develop, building a strong root system and producing more leaves, eventually becoming adult plants.
These adult plants are capable of reproducing by producing flowers, pollination and producing more seeds.

target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a bee
target_text:
A bee collects pollen from a flower.
The pollen is taken back to the hive.
The pollen is added to the comb.
The pollen is converted into honey.
The honey is stored in the comb.
The honey is used to feed the larvae.
The larvae form into pupae.
The pupae become adult bees.
The adult bees leave the hive to continue the cycle.

source_text:

The caterpillar completes its metamorphosis and has turned into a butterfly.
The adult butterfly emerges out of the chrysalis and flys away!.

source_subject: Describe the process of desalination
source_text:
Solution caves are formed in limestone and similar rocks by the action of water.
After a rain, water seeps into cracks and pores of soil and rock.
The water percolates beneath the land surface.
Some of the water reaches a zone where all the cracks and pores in the rock are already filled with water.
Rainwater absorbs some carbon dioxide as it passes through the atmosphere and even more as it drains through soil and decaying vegetation.
The water combines chemically with the carbon dioxide.
A weak carbonic acid solution is formed.
This acid slowly dissolves calcite, forms solution cavities, and excavates passageways.
target_subject: How does desalination work?
target_text:
Desalination is a process that removes salt from seawater, making the water suitable for drinking and irrigation.
Saltwater enters a facility through intake pipes.
The saltwater passes through a filtering system that removes particles and organisms.
It is then pressurized and heated in order to separate the salt from the water.
The salty water is then pushed to the top of a membrane where the salt is filtered out.
The filtered, freshwater is then collected at the bottom of the membrane and sent to storage tanks.
target_mappings:
Limestone and similar rocks : saltwater
Water seeps into cracks and pores : filtering system
Weak carbonic acid solution : pressurized and heated
Calcite : salt
Solution cavities and passageways : storage tanks

The water combines chemically with the carbon dioxide.

This acid slowly dissolves calcite, forms solution cavities, and excavates passageways.
target_subject: How does desalination work?
target_text:
Desalination is the process of removing dissolved salts from seawater or ocean water.
The process involves pumping the seawater or ocean water into a membrane filter.
The membrane filter then removes the dissolved salts and minerals from the water.
The membrane filter works by allowing the water molecules to pass through and trapping the larger salt and mineral molecules.
The membrane is then flushed to remove the trapped salts, and the purified water is collected for use.

water seeps into cracks and pores of soil and rock : pumped into a membrane filter
carbon dioxide : dissolved salts and minerals
calcite : water molecules

target_subject: How does desalination work?
target_text:
Desalination is the process of removing salt from seawater.
Saltwater is pumped into a facility and passed through a filter to remove particulate matter.
The filtered water is then sent to a reverse osmosis unit where it is pressurized and passed through a membrane that removes the salt and other dissolved solids.
The filtered water is then collected and stored for use.

source_subject: Describe the process of evaporation
source_text:
A liquid is heated from an external source.
The heat causes the molecules in the liquid to increase in energy.
As the molecules absorb more energy, they start to move faster.
As the molecules are moving faster they are increasing in temperature.
When the molecules reach a certain temperature, the boiling point, they change from liquid to gas state.
As the liquid molecules go into a gaseous state, they float out into the atmosphere.
When all the liquid has turned to gas, it has evaporated completely, leaving no liquid behind.
target_subject: Describe the process of melting
target_text:
A solid is heated from an external source.
The heat causes the molecules in the solid to increase in energy.
As the molecules absorb more energy, they start to move faster.
As the molecules are moving faster, they are increasing in temperature.
When the molecules reach a certain temperature, the melting point, they change from solid to liquid state.
As the solid molecules go into a liquid state, they become liquid on the surface.
When all the solid has turned to liquid, it has melted completely, leaving no solid behind.
target_mappings:
Liquid : solid
Boiling point : melting point
Gaseous state : liquid state

source_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
source_text:
An organism dies.
Water seeps into the remains.
Minerals dissolved in the water form crystals.
Crystalized minerals cause the remains to harden.
The minerals form a fossil.
target_subject: Describe the process of coal formation
target_text:
A tree dies.
The wood is exposed to extreme temperatures, causing it to dry out.
The tree is buried in the ground and subjected to intense pressure.
The pressure and heat cause the wood to break down and form coal.
The coal is eventually excavated, providing an energy resource for human use.
target_mappings:

Remains : wood
Minerals : pressure and heat
Crystalized minerals : breakdown
Fossil : coal

Minerals dissolved in the water form crystals.
Crystalized minerals cause the remains to harden.
The minerals form a fossil.
target_subject: Describe the process of fossil fuel formation
target_text:
A tree falls and decomposes.
Microorganisms break down the remains of the tree.
Carbon dioxide and methane are released in the process.
The carbon dioxide and methane are absorbed into the atmosphere.
The tree is turned into fossil fuels.
target_mappings:

Water : microorganisms
Crystals : carbon dioxide and methane
Fossil : fossil fuels

The minerals form a fossil.
target_subject: Describe the process of forming a diamond
target_text:
A diamond forms deep within the Earth.
Pressure and heat slowly transform the carbon into diamond.
The diamond crystallizes over time to create its unique shape.
Once the diamond is formed, it is moved to the surface of the Earth by volcanic activity.
The diamond is then mined and cut to make a gemstone.
target_mappings:
Organism : carbon
Water : pressure and heat
Crystals : diamond
Fossil : gemstone

source_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
source_text:
Animals and plants die in soft soil or mud.
Sediment builds up over the remains.
The remains decompose, leaving only trace amounts.
The remaining parts over the years are replaced with mineral.
A fossil is formed.
target_subject: Describe the process of crystal formation
target_text:
Crystals form when a liquid evaporates.
The liquid contains ions that form lattices.
The ions form over the surface of the liquid in layers.
As the liquid evaporates further more and more layers form.
Eventually a solid crystal is formed.

target_subject: Describe the process of meteorite formation
target_text:
An asteroid collides with a planet causing a crater.
Impact melts the rocks and material get ejected from the center.
The material cools down and hardens.
The crater is filled by sediment over the years and the material is replaced with mineral.
A meteorite is formed.

target_subject: Describe the process of metamorphism
target_text:
Metamorphic rocks are formed when existing rocks are exposed to extreme pressure or heat.
The existing rocks undergo physical and chemical changes, forming new minerals and a denser rock.
The new rock is more compact and more resistant to weathering, allowing it to remain in its new form for a longer period of time.
The process can take millions of years, but eventually, a metamorphic rock is formed.
target_mappings:
Soft soil or mud : existing rocks
Remains : physical and chemical changes
Mineral : new minerals
Fossil : metamorphic rock

source_subject: Describe the process of fossilization
source_text:
A plant dies.
The remains of the plant are buried very fast in sediment.
The soft parts of the plant decay.
The hard parts of the plant are replaced with minerals.
The sediment turns into rock.
The rock erodes.
The fossil appears on the surface of the ground.
target_subject: How is lumber processed?
target_text:
A tree is cut down.
The tree is transported to a sawmill.
The tree is cut into lumber.
The lumber is dried in a kiln.
The lumber is shaped and smoothed with a planer.
The lumber is cut into boards.
The boards are stained and finished.
The lumber is assembled into furniture.

target_text:

The vaporized comet slowly cools and condenses.

The dust particles eventually settle on the ground.
The minerals crystallize and form a meteorite.

source_subject: Describe the process of hibernation
source_text:
The animal eats large quantities of food that will be stored as fat.
Winter comes and the animal finds a place to hibernate.
Over a period of days, the animal's heart rate and breathing rate drop slowly.
Electrical activity in the brain almost ceases completely, though some areas remain active.
The animal has entered hibernation mode.
target_subject: Describe the process of migration
target_text:
A bird flies south in the fall as the days become shorter and the temperature colder.
The bird finds a place to rest and store food.
Its body temperature decreases and it begins to slow its metabolism.
The bird's heart rate, respiration rate, and body temperature decrease.
It enters a state of torpor, where its body functions are slowed and minimal energy is used.
The bird has entered a state of migration.
target_mappings:
Eats food : flies south
Hibernation mode : torpor
Heart rate : heart rate
Breathing rate : respiration rate
Electrical activity in the brain : body functions

target_subject: Describe the process of fledging
target_text:
The bird builds a nest and lays eggs.
The eggs are incubated for a few weeks.
The eggs hatch and the chicks are born.
The chicks grow rapidly, being fed by the mother.
At a certain age, the chicks are ready to leave the nest.
They begin to flutter their wings and gain strength, eventually being able to fly.
The chicks have entered the fledging stage.

target_subject: Describe the process of dormancy
target_text:
The plant stores energy from the sun in its leaves.
Winter comes and the plant enters a dormant state.
The leaves turn brown and fall off, the stems and branches become bare.
The plant's metabolism slows down drastically.
The plant preserves its energy until the temperature increases and it can start growing again.
The plant has entered a dormant state.

source_subject: Describe the process of perspiration
source_text:
The body's temperature increases over 98.6 degrees F.
The hypothalamus in the brain sends a message to the body.
Sweat glands in the skin receive the message.
The sweat glands start combining water and chemicals to make sweat.
The sweat leaves the skin through pores.
target_subject: Describe the process of perspiration
target_text:
The temperature of the body rises above 98.6 degrees F.
The brain sends a signal to the skin.
The sweat glands receive the signal and start producing sweat.
The sweat is composed of water and salts.
The sweat is released from the pores in the skin.

target_subject: Describe the process of air conditioning
target_text:
The room temperature rises above the desired level of 68 degrees F.
The thermostat sends a signal to the air conditioning unit.
The compressor of the air conditioner receives the signal.
The compressor starts to mix freon with other chemicals.
The cooled air is sent through the ducts and released into the room.

target_subject: Describe the process of shivering
target_text:
The body's temperature rises above 98.6 degrees F.
The hypothalamus in the brain sends a message to the body.
The muscles receive the message.
The muscles start to contract and relax rapidly.
The energy released by the muscles produces heat that is expelled from the body.

source_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis
source_text:
Carbon dioxide passes through stomata in the leaves.
Water is absorbed through roots.
Chloroplast cells in leaves contain chlorophyll.
Chlorophyll absorbs energy from sunlight.
Energy splits water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen.
Oxygen gets released into atmosphere.
Hydrogen and carbon dioxide used to create glucose.
Glucose is food for plants.
target_subject: How does a solar power system works?
target_text:
The sun's energy is captured by solar cells.
The solar cells convert the sun's energy into electricity.
The electricity passes through wires and is used to power a motor.
The motor drives a generator, which creates mechanical energy.
The mechanical energy is converted into electrical energy and dispersed through the electrical grid.
This electricity is then used to power home appliances, lights, and other devices.

target_subject: How does an air conditioning system work?
target_text:
Heat is absorbed by the radiator.
The radiator transfers the heat through coolant liquid.
The coolant liquid passes through a compressor.
The compressor compresses the heat and transfers it to the condenser.
The condenser then releases heat through coolant vapor.
The vapor is then condensed back into liquid form and sent back to the radiator.
This cycle continues until the desired temperature is achieved.

target_text:
Heat passes through the fins of a radiator.
Coolant is pumped through the engine and absorbs the heat.
The coolant is circulated through the radiator which contains aluminum fins.
The aluminum fins absorb the heat and dissipate it into the air.
The coolant is then returned back to the engine to absorb more heat.
The cycle continues until the engine reaches its desired temperature.

source_subject: Describe the process of photosynthesis
source_text:
Carbon dioxide from the air passes through small pores (holes) in the leaves. These pores are called stomata.
Water is absorbed by the roots and passes through vessels in the stem on its way to the leaves.
Chlorophyll absorbs the sun's energy.
It is this energy that is used to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen.
Oxygen is released from the leaves into the atmosphere.
Hydrogen and carbon dioxide are used to form glucose or food for plants.
target_subject: What is the greenhouse effect?
target_text:
Heat from the sun passes through the atmosphere and reaches Earth's surface.
Earth's surface absorbs the energy and radiates it back into the atmosphere.
The atmosphere traps some of the energy in the form of heat.
This energy warms the atmosphere and the surface of the Earth, creating a greenhouse effect.
The greenhouse effect helps regulate the temperature of the Earth and keeps it warm enough for life to exist.
target_mappings:
Stomata : atmosphere
Hydrogen and oxygen : heat
Carbon dioxide : atmosphere
Glucose : greenhouse effect

target_subject: How does an electrical system work?
target_text:
Electricity from the grid passes through wires.
These wires are connected to outlets.
An appliance is plugged into the outlet.
The appliance's electrical components absorb the energy from the electricity.
The energy is used to power the appliance.
Heat is released from the appliance as a byproduct.
The electricity is then recycled back into the grid.

target_subject: Describe the water cycle
target_text:
Heat from the sun is absorbed by the surface of the ocean.
The surface water evaporates, creating clouds.
The clouds move around the globe and eventually the water droplets form precipitation.
The precipitation falls back to the ground, providing moisture for plants and animals.
The cycle continues with the water evaporating again, forming more clouds and more precipitation.

source_subject: Describe the process of planting crops.
source_text:
Seeds are sown into the ground.
The earth where the seeds are planted is given water and fertilizer.
The seeds start to grow and become seedlings.
The plants are given water.
The seedlings grow into plants.
Weeds growing near the plants are removed.
The plants grow to maturity.
target_subject: Describe the process of releasing animals into the wild.
target_text:
Animals are bred in captivity.
The animals are given food and a safe environment.
The animals start to grow and develop into young animals.
The young animals receive special care and nutrition.
The animals grow into adults.
Invasive species are removed from the environment.
The animals are released into the wild.

source_subject: Describe the process of pollution causing bad effects on the enviroinment.
source_text:
One type of air pollution is the addition of carbon dioxide gas into the air.
Some scientists believe that releasing too much carbon dioxide into the atmosphere is one of the causes of global warming.
This upsets the balance of the carbon cycle.
The ozone layer helps protect us from harmful rays from the sun.
It is getting damaged from air pollution such as methane gas from livestock and CFCs from spray cans.
Acid rain is created when gasses such as sulfur dioxide get high into the atmosphere.
The wind can blow these gasses for miles and then they get washed out of the air when it rains.
This rain is called acid rain and can damage forests and kill fish.
target_subject: Describe the process of deforestation causing bad effects on the environment.
target_text:
The process of deforestation can lead to soil erosion.
The trees in the forest help hold the soil in place.
Without them, the soil can easily be washed away by rain or wind.
This can cause mudslides and floods, which can damage houses and other structures.
The soil can also be polluted by runoff from nearby farms or factories, which contain chemicals that can harm wildlife and plants.
These pollutants can also contaminate nearby water sources, making them unsafe for drinking and other uses.
target_mappings:
Carbon dioxide : trees
Ozone layer : soil
Methane gas : runoff
CFCs : chemicals
Sulfur dioxide : wind
