Spark plug : generator
Combustion : mechanical energy
Exhaust valve : power grid

source_subject: How do icebergs form?
source_text:
You start with a glacier.
Through warming or other methods a chunk is taken off the glacier.
The chunk drifts into the sea.
And it settles where it can remain in its state.
It is considered an iceberg.
target_subject: How do boulders form?
target_text:
You start with a volcano.
Through magma or other methods, lava is released from the volcano.
The lava flows down the mountain and turns into solid rock.
The solidified rock is then broken off and pushed away by glaciers.
It is considered a boulder.
target_mappings:
Glacier : Volcano
Chunk : Lava
Sea : Mountain
Iceberg : Boulder

You start with a glacier.
Through warming or other methods a chunk is taken off the glacier.
The chunk drifts into the sea.
And it settles where it can remain in its state.
It is considered an iceberg.
target_subject: How do snowbanks form?
target_text:
A snowflake starts to form when water vapor condenses around a dust particle in the atmosphere.
More and more water vapor condenses around the dust particle and forms a snowflake.
The snowflake eventually falls to the ground.
When the snow accumulates and is compacted together by the weight of the snow, it forms a snowbank.
The snowbank can remain in its state for a long time until it melts due to warming or other methods.
target_mappings:
Glacier : snowflake
Chunk : dust particle
Sea : ground
Iceberg : snowbank

target_subject: How does volcanic ash form?
target_text:
You start with a volcano.
Through a violent eruption, pieces of the volcano are thrown into the air.
The pieces fall back to the ground, cooling when mixed with the surrounding air.
The cooled pieces settle where they can remain in their state.
These pieces are considered volcanic ash.
target_mappings:
Glacier : volcano
Chunk : pieces
Settle : settle
Iceberg : volcanic ash

source_subject: How does insulin help the body?
source_text:
A person eats food.
The person's blood sugar level rises.
The pancreas receives a signal to release insulin.
Insulin is released into the bloodstream.
Insulin signals cells to absorb sugar.
The cells absorb sugar from the bloodstream.
The cells use the sugar as energy.
target_subject: How does oxygen help the body?
target_text:
A person breathes in oxygen.
The oxygen enters the lungs and travels to the bloodstream.
The oxygen is distributed to the cells throughout the body.
The cells use the oxygen to produce energy.
The cells break down glucose with the help of oxygen.
The cells utilize the energy released from glucose breakdown.
target_mappings:
Insulin : oxygen
Blood sugar level : lungs
Bloodstream : cells

target_subject: How does the immune system work?
target_text:
A person gets a vaccine.
The person's body produces antibodies.
The immune system receives a signal to activate the B-cells.
B-cells are released into the bloodstream.
B-cells signal the body to produce memory cells.
Memory cells are produced and stored in the body.
The memory cells recognize and fight against the disease.
target_mappings:
Insulin : B-cells
Blood sugar : antibodies
Cells : memory cells

target_subject: How does adrenaline help the body?
target_text:
A person exercises.
The person's heart rate increases.
The brain receives a signal to release adrenaline.
Adrenaline is released into the bloodstream.
Adrenaline signals muscles to absorb glucose.
The muscles absorb glucose from the bloodstream.
The muscles use the glucose to produce energy.

source_subject: How does insulin help the body?
source_text:
You eat food.
Your stomach digests the food.
Sugars from food enter your bloodstream.
Insulin helps turn sugars into energy.
Insulin helps your body store the energy in fat, muscle and liver cells.
target_subject: How does oxygen help the body?
target_text:
You breathe in air.
Your lungs absorb oxygen.
Oxygen enters your bloodstream.
Red blood cells transport oxygen to all of your body.
The oxygen is used to produce energy for your cells.
The energy helps your body perform its daily activities.

Sugars : oxygen

You breathe in oxygen.
Your lungs absorb the oxygen.
Oxygen enters your bloodstream.
Hemoglobin helps transport the oxygen throughout your body.
Hemoglobin helps your body absorb the oxygen in organs and tissues.

target_subject: How does sodium help the body?
target_text:
You drink water.
Your body absorbs the water.
The water moves through the body's cells.
Sodium helps regulate the amount of water in your cells.
Sodium helps your body maintain the right balance of water in your cells.

source_subject: How do forests form?
source_text:
A tree produces seeds.
The seeds are dispersed by wind, animals, etc.
The seeds reach the ground.
Grow into new trees.
These new trees produce seeds.
The process repeats itself over and over.
target_subject: How do plants form?
target_text:
Dust particles are carried by the wind.
The dust particles settle on a land.
The land is enriched with the dust particles.
New vegetation sprouts from the dust particles.
The vegetation develops into plants.
The plants reproduce and form a forest.
target_mappings:
tree : vegetation
seeds : dust particles
wind/animals : wind

source_subject: How do forests form?
source_text:
A tree produces seeds.
The seeds are dispersed by wind, animals, etc.
The seeds reach the ground.
Grow into new trees.
These new trees produce seeds.
The process repeats itself over and over.
target_subject: How do mountains form?
target_text:
A mountain is formed by the collision of two tectonic plates.
The pressure of the collision causes the land to push up and form mountains.
Erosion from wind and water wears away the surface of the mountain over time.
The eroded material is carried away by rivers and deposited in valleys.
The deposition of sediment builds up in the valleys, creating new land.
The process repeats itself over and over.
target_mappings:
Tree : tectonic plates
Seeds : pressure
Wind, animals : erosion
Ground : rivers
New trees : valleys

The seeds reach the ground.
Grow into new trees.
These new trees produce seeds.
The process repeats itself over and over.
target_subject: How do mountain ranges form?
target_text:
A mountain range is formed when two tectonic plates collide.
The collision of the two plates causes the ground to fold, buckle, and rise up.
This creates a range of mountains.
Erosion then further shapes the mountains over time.
The mountains are then populated with plants and animals, forming a forest.
The process repeats itself over and over.
target_mappings:
Tree : tectonic plates
Seeds : ground
Wind, animals : collision
New trees : mountains
Forests : plants and animals

source_subject: How do forests form?
source_text:
Networks of trees start forming.
The trees die off.
The dead material provides nutrients for more trees.
The rising trees provide shelter.
And more organisms begin to thrive.
The ecosystem known as a forest is made.
target_subject: How do coral reefs form?
target_text:
A coral reef starts forming.
Small coral polyps begin to adhere to rocks or other hard surfaces.
The polyps begin to secrete a hard calcium carbonate skeleton.
The coral reef builds up as more polyps join the reef.
The coral reef attracts a variety of marine life.
The ecosystem known as a coral reef is made.
target_mappings:
Trees : coral polyps
Dead material : calcium carbonate skeleton
Rising trees : the coral reef
Organisms : marine life

Individual coral colonies start to form.
The colonies grow and expand, creating a network of coral.
The coral colonies provide a homes for small fish and other organisms.
The coral colonies help protect the shorelines from waves and storms.
The ecosystem known as a reef is made.

Coral reefs begin to form.

source_subject: How do forests form?
source_text:
Grass and small plants grow in an area.
These plants die.
The soil gains organic material.
The soil becomes more fertile.
Larger plants are able to be supported.
Trees eventually grow.
target_subject: How do deserts form?
target_text:
Small rocks and particles settle in an area.
These rocks are slowly worn away by water and wind.
The soil gains sediment and other particles.
The soil becomes more fertile.
Small plants and grasses start to grow.
Larger plants and trees eventually grow.

target_subject: How do sand dunes form?

Small stones accumulate in an area.
Wind and water erode the stones.
The erosion creates smaller pieces of sand.
More sand gets collected in the area.
This sand builds up and forms dunes.
As more sand accumulates, dunes become higher.

target_text:

The ocean floor gains organic material.
The ocean floor becomes more hospitable for larger marine life.
Fish, crabs, and other animals start to populate the area.
Eventually, coral begins to form and create a reef.

source_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
source_text:
A fuel source must produce heat.
Heat is used to create steam.
Steam will be used to power turbines.
Turbines will work together with magnets to generate electricity.
Electricity or moving electrons will then flow through wires.
The wires will carry electrons to homes and businesses remotely.
target_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
target_text:
A nuclear reactor must contain a source of nuclear fuel.
The fuel is used to heat water and create steam.
The steam is used to turn turbines, which are connected to an electric generator.
The generator produces electricity and transfers it to the power grid
through transmission lines.
The electricity is then sent to homes and businesses remotely.
target_mappings:
Fuel source : nuclear fuel
Heat : water

source_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
source_text:
A fuel source must produce heat.
Heat is used to create steam.
Steam will be used to power turbines.
Turbines will work together with magnets to generate electricity.
Electricity or moving electrons will then flow through wires.
The wires will carry electrons to homes and businesses remotely.
target_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
target_text:
A nuclear fuel source must be used to produce heat.
Heat is used to create a nuclear reaction.
The nuclear reaction releases particles that are used to power a generator.
The generator works together with magnets to generate electricity.
Electricity or moving electrons will then flow through wires.
The wires will carry electrons to homes and businesses remotely.

target_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
target_text:
Nuclear fuel must be used to generate heat.
Heat is used to produce a nuclear reaction.
Nuclear reaction releases energy in the form of gamma rays and neutrons.
Neutrons are used to create a chain reaction.
The chain reaction produces heat which is used to create steam.
Steam is used to power turbines, which produce electricity.
The electricity is then sent through wires to homes and businesses.

source_subject: How does a nuclear power plant work?
source_text:
Nuclear plants use uranium-235, which is unstable.
Uranium-235 splits, releasing energy and neutrons.
The neutrons hit other atoms, splitting them.
This continues until the reaction is self-sustaining.
Rods containing uranium are used in the power plant.
Control rods slow or accelerate the reaction.
Heat from the fission turns water into steam.
The steam drives a turbine.
The turbine drives a generator.
The generator creates electricity.
target_subject: How does a solar panel work?
target_text:
Solar panels are made up of photovoltaic cells.
These photovoltaic cells capture the sunlight and convert it into direct current electricity.
The direct current electricity travels through an inverter, which converts it into alternating current electricity.
The electricity can then be fed into the electrical grid or be stored in batteries for later use.

Control rods : inverter

target_subject: How does a wind turbine works?
target_text:
Wind turbines use blades that spin in the wind.
The blades turn a shaft, producing kinetic energy.
The kinetic energy is converted into electrical energy by a generator.
Control panels regulate the amount of electricity produced.
The electrical current is sent to an electrical grid, which is responsible for distributing the electricity.
The electrical grid sends the electricity to customers who need it.

source_subject: Describe how a message travels from one person to another over via telephone
source_text:
You speak into the receiver on your phone.
Sound waves move parts inside the receiver.
Movement causes the magnet inside to produce eletricity.
Electricity is transferred through  a wire or cable.
A membrane in the other persons phone is vibrated by the magnet in their telephone.
Sound is produced.
They hear you.
target_subject: Describe how a message travels from one person to another over the internet
target_text:
You type a message into your computer.
The message is encoded into binary data.
The binary data is sent over a network of wires and cables.
The data reaches the recipient's computer.
The binary data is decoded into the original message.
The recipient reads the message.

source_subject: How is a black hole formed?
source_text:
Stars burn mass.
The star burns until it runs out of fuel.
The star can no longer support its weight.
The layers of hydrogen press down on the core.
The core gets smaller and smaller under the pressure.
The pressure causes gravity to get stronger.
The gravity becomes so powerful that nothing can escape it.
Anything that gets close to it, is drawn into it by its gravity.
Light is drawn into it.
Light can not escape.
target_subject: How is a planet formed?
target_text:
A planet is formed when the gravity of a star pulls a cloud of gas and dust together.
The gas and dust start clumping together, forming larger and larger pieces.
These pieces collide and stick together, forming a larger and larger body.
The gravity of the planet becomes stronger, pulling in more and more material from the surrounding area.
Eventually, the planet pulls in so much material that it can no longer support its own weight and collapses in on itself.
The gravity of the planet becomes so strong that nothing can escape it, not even light.
target_mappings:
Star : star
Hydrogen : gas and dust
Core : planet
Light : light

The pressure causes gravity to get stronger.

Anything that gets close to it, is drawn into it by its gravity.
Light is drawn into it.
Light can not escape.
target_subject: How is a black hole formed?
target_text:
A star explodes in a supernova.
The shockwave of the explosion causes the star to disperse most of its material into space.
The star's core collapses in on itself due to its own gravity.
The collapse causes the core to become incredibly dense, creating a gravitational field that is so strong that not even light can escape it.
The star's core becomes a black hole.

target_subject: How is a volcano formed?
target_text:
A volcano erupts when molten rock and other materials escape from within the Earth.
The molten rock is heated by the Earth's core, reaching temperatures of up to 2000°C.
The pressure from the expanding gases and lava causes the surface of the volcano to break, releasing the lava and other materials.
The lava then flows from the volcano, sometimes reaching distances of up to 10km.
The eruption of a volcano can also cause ash clouds, mud flows, and other dangerous phenomena.
target_mappings:
Stars : Earth's core
Burn mass : molten rock
Gravity : pressure
Light : lava
Black hole : volcano

source_subject: Describe how squirrels prepare for winter.
source_text:
Squirrels try to eat as much as possible.
Squirrel gains weight and fat.
Squirrel also hides food in or near its den.
Squirrels also grow a thicker coat as the weather gets colder.
Squirrel lives off of its excess body fat.
Squirrel uses its food stores in the winter.
target_subject: Describe how migratory birds prepare for winter.
target_text:
Migratory birds prepare for winter by increasing their food consumption and storing fat.
Birds also build up their feathers to create a thicker coat to keep warm.
They also fly to warmer climates where food is more abundant.
The birds use the stored body fat for energy during long flights and when food is scarce.
They also store food near their nests to sustain themselves during winter.

Grow a thicker coat : build up feathers

target_subject: Describe how bees prepare for winter.
target_text:
Bees prepare for winter by gathering nectar and pollen.
Bees store the nectar and pollen in the hive and use it as a food source during the colder months.
Bees also use the honeycomb and bee wax to insulate their hive and keep the temperature inside their hive warm.
Bees also form a cluster around the queen bee to keep her warm in the winter.

target_text:

Bears gain extra weight and store fat in preparation for winter.

Bears grow thick fur to keep them warm during the cold months.
Bears live off of their excess body fat and stored food during the winter.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a tree.
source_text:
The primary root breaks from the seed.
A shoot develops with a leaf.
The shoot breaks through the soil as a seedling.
The tree becomes a sapling when it gets taller than 3 ft.
The mature tree produces flowers or fruit.
Seeds are produced from the flowers or fruit.
A dead or dying tree is known as a snag.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a butterfly.
target_text:
A caterpillar hatches from an egg.
The caterpillar feeds on the leaves of a host plant.
The caterpillar molts several times as it grows.
Once it reaches maturity, it creates a cocoon.
The caterpillar undergoes metamorphosis inside the cocoon.
An adult butterfly emerges, which will mate and lay eggs.
The life cycle of the butterfly is complete when the adult butterfly dies.
target_mappings:
seed : egg
shoot : caterpillar
seedling : cocoon
sapling : adult butterfly
flowers/fruit : mate and lay eggs
snag : adult butterfly dies

target_text:

The larva feeds and grows.
The larva transform into juvenile fish.
The juvenile fish grows into adult fish.
The adult fish mate and produces eggs.
The adult fish dies and the cycle starts again.

source_subject: How does a microwave oven work?
source_text:
The magnetron converts electricity into radio waves.
The radio waves go through a wave guide.
The radio waves go into the food compartment.
Microwaves bounces off the metal walls of the food compartment.
Microwaves pass through the food.
Microwaves make the molecules in the food move more quickly.
The food heats up.
target_subject: How does a speaker work?
target_text:
A transistor amplifies electrical signals.
The electrical signals pass through a resistor.
The electrical signals reach the speaker.
The speaker diaphragm vibrates in response to the electrical signals.
The vibrations create sound waves in the air.
The sound waves travel outward from the speaker and reach the person's ears.
The person can hear the sound.

target_subject: How does a solar panel work?
target_text:
The solar panel converts sunlight into electricity.
The electricity passes through an inverter.
The inverter converts the direct current into alternating current.
The alternating current is sent through wires to a breaker box.
The breaker box controls the current and distributes it to different parts of the house.
The electricity is used to power the electrical appliances in the home.

target_subject: How does a power plant works?
target_text:
The turbine is driven by a flow of air.
The air passes through a compressor to increase its pressure.
The compressed air is then sent to the combustion chamber, where it mixes with fuel and is ignited.
The hot gasses produced by the combustion are forced through the turbine blades, causing them to spin.
The spinning turbine is connected to a shaft, which powers an electrical generator.
The generator then converts the energy into electricity.

source_subject: Describe the process of the greenhouse effect
source_text:
The sun gives off radiation.
The radiation is aborbed by the Earth.
Some of the radiation goes back into space.
Some is trapped by the atmosphere.
If too much heat is trapped.
Global warming occurs.
target_subject: Describe the process of the greenhouse effect
target_text:
The Earth gives off infrared radiation.
The radiation is absorbed by greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.
This energy is captured and is not able to escape.
The atmosphere warms up and the temperatures on the surface of the Earth increase.
As the temperatures continue to rise, more greenhouse gases are released, creating a positive feedback loop.
This leads to a further increase in temperatures, which is known as the greenhouse effect.
target_mappings:
sun : Earth
radiation : infrared radiation
atmosphere : greenhouse gases

If too much heat is trapped.
Global warming occurs.
target_subject: Describe the process of the lunar heat island effect
target_text:
The moon reflects light from the sun.
The light is absorbed by the Earth.
Some of the light is reflected back into space.
Some is trapped by the Earth's atmosphere.
If too much light is trapped, the temperature of the Earth increases.
This phenomenon is known as the lunar heat island effect.
target_mappings:
Radiation : light
Global warming : lunar heat island effect

target_subject: Describe the process of the ozone layer
target_text:
The Earth is surrounded by an ozone layer.
The ozone layer absorbs ultraviolet radiation from the sun.
Some of the radiation is reflected back into space, but some is trapped in the atmosphere.
When too much of the radiation is trapped in the atmosphere, the temperature of the Earth increases, causing global climate change.

May come from different sources.
The particles remain suspended in the ocean.

Stays trapped in our ocean.
The ocean's temperature may become warmer this way.

target_subject: Describe the process of the greenhouse effect

These particles can come from a variety of sources, such as volcanoes and human activities.
The particles remain suspended in the atmosphere and scatter incoming sunlight, creating a warming effect.
These particles also absorb infrared radiation from the Earth's surface, trapping the heat and energy and creating a further warming effect.
This process is known as the greenhouse effect, and it can cause the Earth's temperature to rise over time.

target_subject: Describe the process of the water cycle
target_text:
The ocean absorbs and stores a large amount of solar energy.
This energy is distributed throughout the ocean and is transferred to the atmosphere through evaporation.
The evaporated water vapor traps the heat in the atmosphere and warms the earth.
This process is known as the water cycle, which helps regulate the temperature of the planet.

source_text:
Greenhouse gases are released into the air by human activities.
The earth changes energy from the sun into heat.
Heat rises from the ground.
Greenhouse gas molecules in the atmosphere prevent the heat from going into space.
The temperature of the earth increases.
The temperature continues to rise and melts the polar ice caps.
The temperature rises even faster.

The air absorbs the sun's energy and heats up.

The temperature of the air increases.

The temperature rises even faster.

The temperature continues to rise, causing the melting of polar ice caps.
This further accelerates the warming of the earth.

source_subject: How are clouds formed?
source_text:
Sunlight enters the atmosphere.
The light reaches the oceans.
The oceans are warmed.
Water evaporates.
Water vapor accumulates in the air.
As it cools, water condenses onto particles of dust in the air.
As enough water condenses, clouds are formed.
target_subject: How are clouds formed from volcanic eruptions?
target_text:
Volcanic eruptions release particles, gases and ash into the atmosphere.
The particles, gases and ash act as condensation nuclei for the formation of clouds.
As the gases and particles cool, water droplets form around them.
These droplets grow larger and eventually, enough droplets come together to form clouds.
target_mappings:
Sunlight : volcanic eruptions
Oceans : particles, gases and ash
Water vapor : water droplets
Dust : condensation nuclei

As enough water condenses, clouds are formed.
target_subject: How does precipitation happen?
target_text:
Air rises in the atmosphere due to differences in air pressure.
As the air rises, it cools and water vapor condenses onto particles of dust.
As enough water condenses, clouds are formed.
When the air can no longer rise, the clouds start to descend and eventually, precipitation is released.

Oceans : atmosphere
Water evaporates : water vapor condenses
Clouds : precipitation

target_text:
Fog is formed when warm, moist air is cooled.
The warm air is cooled by contact with the ground or by contact with a cold surface.
As the air cools, the water vapor in the air condenses and forms tiny droplets of water or ice crystals.
The tiny droplets of water or ice crystals form a cloud of fog near the ground.

source_subject: How are ravines formed?
source_text:
A stream or river must occur.
Through erosion, the stream cuts into the soil and bedrock.
Through continuous erosion, a deep gash is cut through.
After many years the river may dry up.
A dry ravine is left.
target_subject: How are valleys formed?
target_text:
A mountain range must exist.
Over time, weathering and erosion take place.
The wind and rain slowly break down the rocks of the mountain range.
Through continuous weathering, valleys are formed.
After many years the valleys become deeper and wider.
A deep valley is formed.

Dry ravine : deep valley

target_subject: How are crevices formed?
target_text:
An earthquake must occur.
The seismic activity causes the ground to shake and crack.
Continuous seismic activity causes large fissures to form in the ground.
When the seismic activity stops, a deep crevice is left in its wake.

erosion : seismic activity
ravine : crevice

target_text:

source_subject: How do animals help plants disburse seeds?
source_text:
Animals may come across vegetation.
The animal may consume or get seeds stuck in their fur.
The animal travels some distance someplace else.
The seeds are dropped or deposited off.
The seeds have a new place to proliferate and grow.

target_text:
Wind can pick up dust and other particles from the ground.
The particles are carried away by the wind and deposited elsewhere.
The particles may contain spores from fungi, bacteria, and other microorganisms.
The spores are dropped in new areas and may form colonies in the new environment.

source_subject: How do bats use echolocation?
source_text:
The bat sends out sound waves from their mouth or nose.
The sound waves hit an object.
Echoes are produced.
The echo returns to the bat's ears.
The bat hears the echo.
The bat can figure out where the object is located.

source_subject: How do bees pollinate plants?
source_text:
A bee lands on the flower.
Their feet slip into little grooves that hold pollen sacs.
When the bee flies off, it carries off the pollen sac.
The bee lands on another plant.
The pollen sac falls off and pollinates the plant.

A bird lands on a tree branch.
The bird slips its beak into little crevices of the tree.
The bird carries off small pieces of fruit or seeds.
The bird lands on another tree.
The fruit or seeds falls off and scatters on the ground nearby.

source_subject: How do caverns form?
source_text:
Some of the rock in the ground is made of limestone.
Over long periods of time rain can hit the limestone.
And cause a acidic reaction.
The limestone will slowly disintegrate.
A large gap with be where the limestone was.
Result in the cave.
target_subject: How do crevices form?
target_text:
The surface of the earth is made of many layers of rock.
Over long periods of time, water can seep into cracks between the layers of rock.
The water eventually turns into steam and causes the rocks to move and break apart.
The breaking apart of the rocks results in large crevices and caverns.

Acidic reaction : water turning into steam
Gap : crevices
Cave : caverns

target_subject: How do canyons form?
target_text:
The surface of the Earth is composed of different types of rocks.
When water comes into contact with a particular type of rock,
such as granite, it causes a chemical reaction to occur.
This reaction causes the rock to erode, resulting in the formation of canyons.
The water then flows through the canyon, creating a deep, narrow passage.

target_subject: How do valleys, gorges, and canyons form?
target_text:
When glaciers move, they leave behind large rocks that are called glacial erratics.
Over long periods of time, weathering can cause the rocks to break down into smaller pieces.
The small pieces of rock, combined with the movement of water and wind, can create large gaps in the land.
These gaps can form a valley, a gorge, or even a canyon.

The rock over the years carves through the rock.

As more rather rushes through the cave becomes a cavern.

Wind picks up dust and rocks from the surface.
The wind carries the dust and rocks and drops them on the ground.

The harder material is shaped and sculpted by the wind, forming sand dunes.

source_subject: How do green plants get the energy they need?
source_text:
Green is a color that gathers sunlight easily.
Sunlight is gathered by the leaves of the plant.
The sunlight is broken down into glucose through photosynthesis.
The glucose travels the plant.
The plant uses that glucose as energy to grow.
target_subject: How do solar panels get the energy they need?
target_text:
Solar panels are able to gather sunlight easily.
The sunlight is absorbed into the cells of the solar panel.
The absorbed sunlight is converted into electricity by photovoltaic cells.
The electricity is passed through the wires of the solar panel.
The electricity is then used to power the appliances.
target_mappings:

Sunlight : sunlight
Glucose : electricity
Photosynthesis : photovoltaic cells

source_subject: How do green plants get the energy they need?
source_text:
Green is a color that gathers sunlight easily.
Sunlight is gathered by the leaves of the plant.
The sunlight is broken down into glucose through photosynthesis.
The glucose travels the plant.
The plant uses that glucose as energy to grow.
target_subject: How do solar cells get energy?
target_text:
Solar cells are designed to absorb sunlight.
The sunlight is absorbed by the cells and converted into electricity.
The electricity travels through wires to the energy converter.
The energy converter converts the electricity into usable energy.
The energy can then be used to power homes, businesses and other appliances.

source_subject: How do lungs work?
source_text:
You breathe air in.
Air enters bronchial tubes.
Air is then split into the bronchioles of each lung.
Bronchioles have alveoli which are tiny air sacs.
Alveoli is surrounded by many small blood vessels.
Oxygen passes through alveoli into blood vessels.
Blood leaves the lungs as it travels through the body.
Blood carries carbon dioxide back to the lungs.
Carbon dioxide released when you exhale.
target_subject: How does the digestive system work?
target_text:
The stomach receives food from the esophagus.
The food is then broken down by stomach acid and digestive enzymes.
The food particles are further broken down into smaller particles.
The small particles are then passed through the walls of the stomach into the small intestine.
Nutrients are absorbed into the bloodstream through the walls of the small intestine.
Undigested food particles are passed into the large intestine and then expelled from the body.

Bronchial tubes : esophagus
Bronchioles : stomach acid and digestive enzymes
Alveoli : small intestine
Blood vessels : walls of the small intestine
Carbon dioxide : undigested food particles

The stomach secretes digestive juices to break down the water.
The water is then passed on to the small intestine,
where the nutrients are absorbed.
The water is then passed on to the large intestine,
where the remaining water is absorbed.
The waste products are then eliminated from the body through the rectum.

The carbon dioxide is exhaled.
target_subject: How does a solar panel works?
target_text:
Solar energy is captured by photovoltaic cells.
The photovoltaic cells transform the solar energy into electrical energy.
The electrical energy is carried by copper wires.
The electrical energy is directed to an inverter.
The inverter converts the energy into an alternating current.
The alternating current is stored in a battery or sent to the electrical grid.

target_subject: How does the heart work?
target_text:
Blood enters the heart through two veins.
The blood is then pumped to the lungs for oxygenation.
The oxygenated blood is then returned to the heart,
where it is pumped to the rest of the body.
The deoxygenated blood then returns to the heart through two other veins.
The heart pumps the deoxygenated blood to the lungs,
where it receives oxygen and expels carbon dioxide.
The oxygenated blood is then pumped back to the body.

target_subject: How does a computer work?

A computer receives input through the keyboard and mouse.
The input is sent to the processor, which interprets the input and carries out commands.

The data is then sent to the motherboard, which distributes the data to the other components of the computer.
The output is then displayed on the computer screen.

source_subject: How do minerals form?
source_text:
Magma cools inside the crust.
Magma crystalizes.
Lava cools on the surface.
Lava crystalizes.
Minerals dissolved in water crystlize.
target_subject: How do minerals enter the atmosphere?
target_text:
Volcanic gases cool in the atmosphere.
The gases condense and form clouds.
The clouds form droplets of water.
The droplets of water fall to the ground as rain, snow, or hail.
The water evaporates and enters the atmosphere, leaving behind minerals.

target_subject: How do meteorites form minerals?
target_text:
Asteroids travel through space.
Asteroids enter the Earth's atmosphere.
Asteroids heat up as it enters the atmosphere and some of it vaporizes.
The vaporized asteroids cool and crystalize.
The vaporized asteroids form a dust-like material called meteorite dust that falls back to the Earth.
Minerals are deposited from the meteorite dust.

target_subject: How do asteroids form minerals?
target_text:
Asteroids enter Earth's atmosphere.
The asteroids heat up and start to melt.
The molten material starts to cool and form solid rocks.
The solid rocks break up into smaller pieces due to air drag.
The smaller pieces cool further and the minerals inside them crystalize.

source_subject: How do minerals form?
source_text:
There are places inside Earth where rock will melt.
Melted rock inside the Earth is also called molten rock, or magma.
Magma moves up through Earth's crust, but it does not always reach the surface.
When magma erupts onto Earth's surface, it is known as lava.
As lava flows from volcanoes it starts to cool.
Minerals form when magma and lava cool.
target_subject: How are minerals brought to the Earth's surface?
target_text:
When water evaporates, the water molecules in it become gas molecules and they rise into the atmosphere.
As the molecules rise higher, they cool and condense into tiny droplets of liquid water.
These droplets form clouds, and they eventually fall back to Earth as rain.
As the raindrops fall, they collect dust particles, which become part of the droplet.
When the droplet reaches the ground, the minerals in the water become part of the soil.
target_mappings:

Lava : droplets of liquid water
Volcanoes : clouds
Cooling : falling raindrops

target_subject: How do metamorphic rocks form?
target_text:
There are places inside Earth where sedimentary rocks are exposed to high temperatures and pressures.
These rocks are subjected to chemical and physical processes that cause them to change their composition.
The sedimentary rocks are changed into metamorphic rocks through these processes.
The metamorphic rocks become harder and more resistant to weathering,
forming crystals which are the minerals that are found in the rock.

source_subject: How do plants obtain and use water?
source_text:
Plants absorb water from the ground through their root systems.
Using sunlight, the plant separates the hydrogen and oxygen molecules through the process of photosynthesis.
The plant releases the oxygen into the atmosphere.
Combines the hydrogen with carbon dioxide to create an intermediate.
The intermediate is used to produce glucose which is the plant's food.
target_subject: How do animals obtain and use water?
target_text:
Animals obtain water by drinking from a water source or eating food that contains water.
The water is then absorbed into the bloodstream and transported to cells throughout the body.
The cells then use the water to break down food molecules and create energy in the form of ATP.
Wastes are also removed from the cells and transported out of the body through urine and sweat.
target_mappings:

Photosynthesis : absorbed into the bloodstream
Oxygen : wastes
Hydrogen : urine and sweat

target_subject: How do animals obtain and use energy?
target_text:
Animals obtain energy from the food they consume.
Digestion separates the molecules into simple forms.
The simple forms of molecules, such as glucose, are absorbed into the bloodstream.
The glucose is broken down further by the body to create energy.
This energy is used by the body to perform various activities.

target_subject: How do animals obtain and use water?

The water is then transported throughout the body by the circulatory system.

source_subject: How do plants use animals to help disburse their seeds?
source_text:
Plants create light weight seeds.
The wind is able to blow the seeds off of the plants.
The wind carries the seeds through the air to other areas.
The seeds get caught in the fur of animals.
The animals move and lay down on the ground.
The seeds get deposited on the ground.
The seeds become plants.
target_subject: How do birds use other birds to help disburse their eggs?
target_text:
Birds create lightweight eggs.
The wind is able to move the eggs off of the bird's nest.
The wind carries the eggs through the air to other areas.
The eggs get caught in the feathers of birds.
The birds fly and rest in different locations.
The eggs get deposited on the ground.
The eggs hatch and become baby birds.

Fur of animals : Feathers of birds

source_subject: How do the lungs work?
source_text:
Air enters the lungs through bronchial tubes.
Air enters bronchioles.
Bronchioles have tiny air sacs called alveoli.
Alveoli surrounded by small blood vessels.
Oxygen absorbed by small blood vessels.
Vessels deliver oxygen to every cell in the body.
Blood brings carbon dioxide back to lungs.

target_subject: How does the digestive system work?
target_text:
Food enters the digestive system through the mouth.
Food is broken down into smaller pieces.
The small pieces pass into the small intestine.
The small intestine is lined with small projections called villi.
The villi absorb the nutrients from the food and deliver it to the bloodstream.
The bloodstream carries the nutrients to every cell in the body.
Wastes are brought back to the large intestine and removed from the body.

target_subject: How does the circulatory system works?
target_text:
The heart pumps blood to the body through arteries.
The arteries branch off into smaller vessels called arterioles.
The arterioles branch off even smaller vessels called capillaries.
The capillaries deliver the nutrients to the cells of the body.
The cells then absorb the nutrients and produce waste.
The waste is then collected by the capillaries and taken to the veins.
The veins take the waste back to the heart, which pumps it to the lungs.
The lungs expel the waste when we exhale.

source_subject: How do the lungs work?
source_text:
You breathe in.
Air goes through all the little branches in your lungs to fill up the air sacs, or alveoli.
Oxygen goes through the walls of the alveoli and into the capillaries.
The oxygen goes into the bloodstream.
Oxygen is left and carbon dioxide is picked up.
You breathe it out through your lungs.

You swallow food.
The food goes down your esophagus and into your stomach.

The food is moved further down the digestive system, where enzymes and acids break it down even more.
The food is then moved to the small intestine, where nutrients are absorbed into the bloodstream.
The waste is then moved to the large intestine, where excess water is removed before it is finally passed out.

Oxygen is left and carbon dioxide is picked up.
You breathe it out through your lungs.
target_subject: How do the digestive system works?
target_text:
You eat food.
The food is broken down in the stomach and small intestine and nutrients are absorbed.
The nutrients travel through the bloodstream and into the cells of the body.
The cells use the nutrients to generate energy and the leftovers are sent to the liver.
The liver processes the leftovers and sends them to the kidneys to be removed from the body.
target_mappings:
Air : food
Alveoli : stomach and small intestine
Capillaries : cells
Oxygen : nutrients
Carbon dioxide : leftovers
Lungs : kidneys

source_subject: How do the lungs work?
source_text:
Air is brought in through the mouth.
Passes through the lungs.
And into the bronchial tissue.
The carbon dioxide is removed.
The lungs bring the oxygen to the rest of the body.
target_subject: How does the digestive system work?
target_text:
Food is brought in through the mouth.
The food is chewed and mixed with saliva.
The food passes through the esophagus into the stomach.
The stomach churns the food and mixes it with digestive juices to break it down.
The nutrients are absorbed into the small intestine.
The waste is passed out of the body through the large intestine.

target_subject: How does the heart work?
target_text:
The heart pumps blood throughout the body.
Blood is brought in through the vena cava.
The blood passes into the right atrium.
The right atrium pumps the blood into the right ventricle.
The right ventricle pumps the blood to the lungs to be oxygenated.
The oxygenated blood is sent from the lungs to the left atrium.
The left atrium pumps the blood into the left ventricle.
The left ventricle pumps the blood to the rest of the body.

source_subject: How do you make ice cubes?
source_text:
Get an ice cube tray.
Fill the tray with cool water.
Place the tray in the freezer.
Leave the tray in the freezer for a few hours.
Take they tray out of the freezer.
Pop the ice cubes out of tray.
target_subject: How do you make fruit or vegetable cubes?
target_text:
Gather fruits or vegetables of your choice.
Chop them into small pieces.
Fill a blender or food processor with the chopped pieces.
Mix the pieces together until they form a puree.
Fill an ice cube tray with the puree.
Place the tray in the freezer.
Leave the tray in the freezer for a few hours.
Pop the cubes out of the tray.

source_subject: How do you make ice cubes?
source_text:
You find an empty ice cube tray.
You fill the tray with warm water.
You carefully place the tray on an even surface in a freezer that is at least 32 degree Farhenheit, the freezing point of water.
The water begins to get colder until it starts to freeze solid.
The water expands as it freezes, one of the few liquids that has greater volume as a solid.
Because you used warm water, the gasses in the water had evaporated out, so you will have nice clear ice cubes without cracks from the trapped gasses.
target_subject: How do you make cookies?
target_text:
You find a chocolate chip cookie dough recipe.
You measure and combine the ingredients in a bowl.
You roll the dough into balls.
You carefully place the cookie dough balls on a baking sheet.
You bake the cookies in an oven at the recommended temperature.
The cookies slowly expand and become golden brown.
The heat from the oven causes the baking soda in the recipe to react and the cookies become soft and chewy with a nice flavor.

source_subject: How does a battery-operated sewing machine work?
source_text:
Energy is stored in a battery.
The energy is released from the battery as electrical current.
The electrical current goes to a motor.
The motor makes the needle of the sewing machine go up and down.
The needle is pressed through the piece of clothing at a constant rate.
Thread is attached and used to stitch the clothing.

target_text:
A solar panel captures sunlight and converts it into electrical current.
The electrical current goes to a motor.
The motor powers the blades of a fan.
The blades rotate at a constant speed.
Air is circulated around the room by the blades.

source_subject: How does a coal-powered power station generate electricity?
source_text:
Coal is burned at a furnace.
The resulting heat energy is used to heat water.
The heated water is turned into steam.
The steam drives a generator.
Electricity is produced.
target_subject: How does a solar panel generate electricity?
target_text:
The sun's energy is captured by solar panels.
The solar panels convert the energy into electricity.
The electricity is directed to an inverter.
The inverter turns the direct current into usable alternating current.
The alternating current is fed into the electrical grid or stored for later use.

source_subject: How does a coal-powered power station generate electricity?
source_text:
Coal is mixed with hot air in a power station.
Water is sent through pipes in the power station.
The water pipes go through a firebox in the power station.
The coal is put in the air in the firebox.
The water heats up so it's very hot.
The water turns into steam.
The steam is pushed out of the pipes into a separate area.
The steam powers turbines.
Magnets in the turbines spin in wire coils.
Electricity is produced.

The water heats up so it's very hot.
The water turns into steam.

Electricity is produced.

target_subject: How does a wind-powered power station generate electricity?
target_text:
Wind is harnessed by a wind turbine in a wind farm.
The blades of the turbine capture the wind, causing the turbine to spin.
The spinning turbine is connected to a generator which produces electricity.
The generator is powered by the spinning turbine and the electricity is sent to the power grid.
The electricity can then be used to power homes and businesses.

target_subject: How does a wind turbine generate electricity?
target_text:
Wind is pushed through the blades of a wind turbine.
The wind turbine is mounted on a tower, which is usually tall to capture more wind.
The blades rotate a shaft, which is connected to a generator.
The generator produces a direct current (DC) electrical current.
The DC current is then converted into alternating current (AC) through an inverter.
The AC current is then sent to a transformer, which increases the voltage for transmission.
The transmission lines deliver the electricity to substations and then to homes.

source_subject: How does a steam engine work?
source_text:
A fuel is heated in an oven.
Above the oven is a tank of water that is sealed.
The tank of water begins to boil above the oven.
A the water boils steam is created.
The steam is denser than air so it needs a place to go.
The steam is forced out of the tank and into a piston.
The piston moves up.
The valve of the piston closes.
The valve on the next piston opens.
The steam fills the next piston, driving it up, and the other one down.
target_subject: How does a chimney work?
target_text:
A fuel is ignited in a furnace.
Above the furnace is a chimney that extends out of the building.
Heat from the combustion rises and exits out of the chimney.
The heat causes the air in the atmosphere to rise.
The rising air creates a low-pressure area in the furnace.
The low pressure causes air from outside the building to be drawn in.
The air is heated by the furnace and forced out of the building, creating a continuous flow of air.
target_mappings:
Oven : furnace
Tank of water : chimney
Steam : heat
Piston : atmosphere
Valve : low pressure

target_subject: How does a wind turbine work?
target_text:
A wind turbine captures wind energy in its blades.
The blades rotate a shaft, which is connected to a gearbox.
The gearbox multiplies the rotational force, causing a high-speed rotation.
The high-speed rotation drives a generator, which produces electricity.
The electricity is then directed to a transformer, which steps it up to a higher voltage for transmission.

target_subject: How does an electric motor work?
target_text:
A battery is charged in a charger.
The energy from the battery is stored in a capacitor.
The capacitor is filled with energy.
The energy is forced out of the capacitor and into a motor.
The motor spins, creating motion.
The motion is used to power a device.
The device is powered until the capacitor is empty.
The capacitor is then recharged and the process starts again.

source_subject: How does a virus cause disease?
source_text:
The flu virus has receptors, which are like viral Velcro, on the surface of the virus particle.
The receptors will lock onto a target cell using these chemical receptors on the surface, which docks onto the cell surface.
The receptors  then go into the cell.
The receptors use it like a factory.
The receptors take it over and make it produce thousands or in some cases millions of copies of new viruses.
The copies come streaming out of the cell.
The copies infect other cells to make more viruses, or they escape from the body and infect a new victim.
target_subject: How does a computer virus spread?
target_text:
A computer virus is a malicious software program that is designed to replicate itself and spread to other computers or devices.
The virus attaches itself to existing files and programs, using code that can be executed, and is then spread to other computers or devices when the file or program is opened or executed.
Once the virus is on a machine, it can start to execute code which can cause damage, steal data, or spread the virus to other devices.
The virus can be spread through email, downloads, or other files shared with other devices.
target_mappings:
Flu virus : computer virus
Receptors : malicious software
Target cell : existing files and programs
Cell surface : code
Factory : computers or devices
Copies : email, downloads, or other files

The copies come streaming out of the cell.
The copies infect other cells to make more viruses, or they escape from the body and infect a new victim.
target_subject: How does bacteria cause disease?
target_text:
Bacteria have pili, which are like bacterial Velcro, on the surface of their cells.
These pili will attach to other cells by using their chemical receptors on the surface, which docks onto the cell surface.
The pili  then go into the cell.
The pili use it like a factory.
The pili take it over and make it produce thousands or in some cases millions of copies of new bacteria.
The copies come streaming out of the cell.
The copies infect other cells to make more bacteria, or they escape from the body and infect a new victim.

target_subject: How does bacteria cause disease?
target_text:
Bacteria have a cell wall that helps them attach to and enter a host.
The cell wall helps them to latch onto a cell, entering the cell through a process called endocytosis.
Once the bacteria are inside the cell, they take over the cell and use it as a factory to produce more bacteria.
The new bacteria then leave the cell and enter new cells, either infecting them or escaping the body to infect another host.

source_subject: How does a virus infect an animal?
source_text:
A virus enters a host body.
The virus has receptors that lock onto a target cell.
The virus enters the cell.
The virus uses the cell like a factory to make new copies of the virus.
The new copies of the virus leave the cell.
Infect other cells.
The host gets sick as its cells are damaged.
target_subject: How does a parasite infect an animal?
target_text:
A parasite enters a host body.
The parasite has hooks or suction cups that attach to the skin.
The parasite penetrates the skin.
The parasite uses the body as a source of food and a place to reproduce.
The new parasites leave the body and seek new hosts.
The host gets sick as its resources are drained by the parasite.

source_subject: How does an electromagnet work?
source_text:
Electromagnet creates magnetic field with electricity.
Conductive copper wire is wrapped around a piece of metal.
An electric current gets introduced from power source.
Flows through the wire.
Magnetic field gets created in the wire.
And the metal gets magnetized.
When turned off it is no longer magnetic.
target_subject: How does an electric motor work?
target_text:
An electric motor uses an electric current to create a magnetic field.
The electric current flows through a coil of wire, which is wrapped around a metal core.
When the current flows through the coil, it creates a magnetic field which interacts with a second magnet, causing the core to rotate.
This rotation power is then used to generate mechanical energy.
When the electric current is switched off, the core no longer rotates.
target_mappings:
Electromagnet : electric motor
Conductive copper wire : coil of wire
Metal : metal core
Electric current : electric current

When turned off it is no longer magnetic.
target_subject: How does a solar panel work?
target_text:
A solar panel collects photons from sunlight.
The photons are absorbed by a semi-conductive material.
The photons are then converted into electrons which flow as a direct current.
The direct current is then converted into a usable alternating current by an inverter.
This alternating current can be fed into the electrical grid or stored for later use.

Electricity : photons
Conductive copper wire : semi-conductive material
Metal : electrons
Power source : inverter

target_subject: How does a loudspeaker work?
target_text:
A loudspeaker creates sound with electricity.
A coil of wire is attached to a diaphragm.
A current is sent from the amplifier to the coil.
The coil creates a magnetic field in the speaker.
The diaphragm vibrates and produces sound waves.
When the current stops, the diaphragm stops vibrating and no sound is created.
target_mappings:
Electromagnet : loudspeaker
Conductive copper wire : coil of wire
Metal : diaphragm
Electric current : current from amplifier
Magnetic field : magnetic field in speaker

source_subject: How does an electromagnet work?
source_text:
A conducting metal, like copper, is wrapped around a piece of metal.
An electrical source, like a battery, produces an electrical current.
The electrical current flows through the wire.
The electrical current creates a magnetic field around the wire, magnetizing the metal.
The magnetic field can be turned on and off by starting or stopping the electricity source.
target_subject: How does an induction motor work?
target_text:
An alternating current of electricity is passed through a coil of wire.
This creates a changing magnetic field and induces a current in a second coil of wire.
The current in the second coil is known as the induced current.
The current in the second coil will always be in opposite direction of the first, creating a repulsive force between the two coils.
This force can be used to move objects or as a source of power.
target_mappings:
Copper wire : coil of wire
Battery : alternating current
Magnetic field : changing magnetic field
Electricity source : induced current

target_subject: How does a hydroelectric turbine work?
target_text:
A turbine is placed in a flowing body of water, like a river or lake.
Water flows through the turbine, causing the blades to spin and produce mechanical energy.
This mechanical energy is transferred to a generator, which produces electricity.
The amount of electricity produced depends on the speed and volume of the water flowing through the turbine.
The electricity produced can be used to power equipment or be sent to the electrical grid.
target_mappings:
Conducting metal : turbine
Electric source : flowing body of water
Wire : blades
Magnetic field : generator
Electricity source : speed and volume of water

source_subject: How does an electromagnet work?
source_text:
A conducting metal, like copper, is wrapped around a piece of metal.
An electrical source, like a battery, produces an electrical current.
The electrical current flows through the wire.
The electrical current creates a magnetic field around the wire, magnetizing the metal.
The magnetic field can be turned on and off by starting or stopping the electricity source.
target_subject: How does a magnet work?
target_text:
A powerful magnet is placed near a piece of metal.
The metal is attracted to the magnet and sticks to it.
When the magnet is turned off, the metal is no longer held by the magnet and falls away.
This can be repeated by turning the magnet on and off.
target_mappings:
electrical source : powerful magnet
electrical current : magnet
magnetic field : attraction

source_subject: How does blood remove waste from the human body?
source_text:
Blood delivers oxygen in the body.
Proteins and acids are broken down in the liver.
The liver releases waste in the form of urea.
The blood carries the urea and carbon dioxide to the kidneys.
The kidneys strain the urea and salts needed from the blood.
The carbon dioxide by product is transported back to the lungs.
Carbon dioxide is exhaled by the lungs.
target_subject: How does a furnace heat a house?
target_text:
Heat is transferred to the house by a furnace.
The furnace breaks down the fuel, such as natural gas, propane, and oil, into combustible gases.
The combustible gases are ignited and create energy.
The energy heats the air, which is then moved through the house.
The waste from the combustion process is released from the house through the chimney.
target_mappings:
Oxygen : fuel
Proteins, acids : combustible gases
Urea : waste
Kidneys : chimney
Carbon dioxide : air

target_subject: How does a compost bin remove nutrients from organic waste?
target_text:
Organic waste is broken down in the compost bin.
The bin releases nutrients and minerals from the waste.
The nutrients and minerals are then strained from the bin.
The byproducts of the composting process are transported to the garden.
The byproducts are used as fertilizers for the plants.
The remaining waste is then returned to the compost bin for reprocessing.

target_subject: How does a water system filter water?
target_text:
Rainwater collects in a reservoir.
The reservoir filters the water, removing dirt and debris.
The water is then sent through a series of pipes.
The pipes contain a filter that sieves out any remaining debris.
The water passes through a chlorine filter to disinfect it.
The water is then pumped through the city's water system, providing fresh clean water to residents.

source_subject: How does coal get from the ground to a power station?
source_text:
A machine called a pulverizer grinds the coal into a fine powder.
The coal powder mixes with hot air, which helps the coal burn more efficiently, and the mixture moves to the furnace.
The burning coal heats water in a boiler, creating steam.
Steam released from the boiler powers an engine called a turbine, transforming heat energy from burning coal into mechanical energy that spins the turbine engine.
The spinning turbine is used to power a generator, a machine that turns mechanical energy into electric energy.
This happens when magnets inside a copper coil in the generator spin.
A condenser cools the steam moving through the turbine. As the steam is condensed, it turns back into water.
The water returns to the boiler, and the cycle begins again.
target_subject: How does oil get from the ground to a fuel station?
target_text:
Oil is extracted from the ground by a drill.
The oil is then transported to the refinery by a pipeline.
The oil goes through a distillation process to separate it into different components.
These components are then processed and reformed into useful products like gasoline and diesel.
The gasoline and diesel are transported to the fuel station and stored in tanks.
The customers then buy the fuel from the station, which is then pumped from the tanks into their vehicles.
target_mappings:
Pulverizer : drill
Furnace : refinery
Boiler : distillation process
Turbine : gasoline and diesel
Generator : fuel station
Condenser : tanks

source_subject: How does mold grow on bread?
source_text:
A mold spore floats through the air.
The spore lands on a piece of bread.
The spore grows hyphae into the bread.
The mold forms a colony.
Sporangiophores grow upward.
The mold sends out spores.
target_subject: How does a virus spread in a person?
target_text:
A virus particle travels through the air.
The virus particle lands on a person.
The particle enters the cells of the person.
The virus replicates itself in the cells.
The virus spreads from cell to cell.
Virions are released from the cells.

Mines are dug in the earth where ore is present.

source_subject: How does rain form?
source_text:
Water vapor gets into the atmosphere through a process called evaporation.
This then turns the water that is at the top of oceans, rivers and lakes into water vapor in the atmosphere using energy from the sun.
The water vapor rises in the atmosphere and there it cools down.
Water vapor rises in the atmosphere and there it cools down and forms tiny water droplets through something called condensation.
These then turn into clouds.
When they all combine together, they grow bigger and are too heavy to stay up there in the air.
This is when they will fall to the ground as rain, or maybe snow or hail by gravity.
target_subject: How does lightning form?
target_text:
Lightning is formed when electrical charges build up in the clouds.
These electrical charges are created when particles of ice and water bump into each other and become positively and negatively charged.
The positive and negative charges then separate, creating an electrical field.
When the electrical field is strong enough, lightning strikes.
The heat generated by the lightning then turns the water droplets in the clouds into steam, which then rises and cools, creating more water droplets through condensation.
The water droplets then combine to form heavy enough droplets to fall from the clouds as rain.
target_mappings:
Water vapor : electrical charges
Evaporation : particles of ice and water
Condensation : electrical field
Clouds : lightning

source_subject: How does rain form?

The water vapor rises in the atmosphere and there it cools down.
Water vapor rises in the atmosphere and there it cools down and forms tiny water droplets through something called condensation.
These then turn into clouds.
When they all combine together, they grow bigger and are too heavy to stay up there in the air.
This is when they will fall to the ground as rain, or maybe snow or hail by gravity.
target_subject: How does snow form?
target_text:
Dust particles get into the atmosphere through a process called wind erosion.
These dust particles are lifted from the ground and carried away by the wind.
The dust particles rise in the atmosphere and there they cool down and form tiny ice crystals through something called condensation nuclei.
These then turn into clouds.
When they all combine together, they grow bigger and are too heavy to stay up there in the air.
This is when they will fall to the ground as snow, ice or hail by gravity.

water vapor : dust particles
evaporation : wind erosion
water droplets : ice crystals

source_subject: How does rain form?
source_text:
Warm air from the surface rises into the higher cold air.
The water vapor in the air is condensed.
The condensed water and dust forms a cloud.
Wind in the cloud bounces the water droplets around.
The bouncing droplets join together.
The bigger droplets get heavy.
The heavy droplets fall.
As they fall, they join with more moisture in the air.
The droplets get larger.
Rain falls.
target_subject: How does snow form?
target_text:
Warm air from the surface rises into the higher cold air.
The water vapor in the air condenses into tiny ice crystals.
The ice crystals form a cloud.
Wind in the cloud causes the ice crystals to move.
The bouncing crystals join together to form snowflakes.
The snowflakes become heavy and fall to the ground as snow.
As the snowflakes fall, they collect more moisture from the atmosphere.
The snowflakes get heavier and eventually fall as snow.
target_mappings:
water droplets : ice crystals
moisture : moisture from the atmosphere
rain : snow

source_subject: How does recycling work?
source_text:
Items that can be reused are placed into recycling containers.
Recycling trucks pick up the items that are able to be reused.
The recyclable items travel to a recycling plant.
The items are sorted by what they are made of.
The items are broken down into small parts.
The small parts are melted to make new raw parts.
The raw parts are sold to manufactures to make new items.
target_subject: How does production work?
target_text:
Raw materials are extracted from the earth.
These raw materials are transported to factories.
The raw materials are sorted into different categories.
The raw materials are processed and assembled into usable products.
The products are packaged and shipped to stores.
The products are sold to customers.
target_mappings:
Recycling containers : raw materials
Recycling trucks : transport to factories
Recycling plants : factories
Small parts : raw materials
Raw parts : usable products

source_subject: How does recycling work?
source_text:
Items that can be reused are placed into recycling containers.
Recycling trucks pick up the items that are able to be reused.
The recyclable items travel to a recycling plant.
The items are sorted by what they are made of.
The items are broken down into small parts.
The small parts are melted to make new raw parts.
The raw parts are sold to manufactures to make new items.
target_subject: How does donating work?
target_text:
Items that can be reused are brought to a donation center.
Donation trucks pick up the items that are able to be reused.
The donated items travel to a donation center.
The items are sorted by type.
The items are collected and inspected.
The items are cleaned and repaired if needed.
The items are given to those in need or sold to second-hand shops.
target_mappings:
Recycling containers : donation center
Recycling trucks : donation trucks
Recycling plant : donation center
Raw parts : items
Manufactures : those in need / second-hand shops

target_subject: How does composting work?
target_text:
Items that can be composted are placed in compost bins.
Compost trucks pick up the items that can be composted.
The compostable items travel to a composting facility.
The items are sorted by what they are made of.
The items are broken down into small pieces.
The small pieces are broken down and decomposed to create compost.
The compost is then used as fertilizer for gardens and farms.
target_mappings:
Recycling containers : compost bins
Recycling trucks : compost trucks
Recycling plant : composting facility
Raw parts : compost
Manufactures : gardens and farms

source_subject: How does snow form?
source_text:
Water in the clouds becomes very cold.
The cold water forms ice crystals.
The ice crystals grow by absorbing surrounding water droplets.
Form snowflakes.
The snowflakes fall to the ground.
target_subject: How does rain form?
target_text:
Water in the atmosphere becomes very humid.
The humid air forms droplets of water.
The droplets of water grow by absorbing surrounding water vapor.
Form raindrops.
The raindrops fall to the ground.
target_mappings:
Ice crystals : droplets of water
Snowflakes : raindrops

source_subject: How does snow form?
source_text:
Water in the clouds becomes very cold.
The cold water forms ice crystals.
The ice crystals grow by absorbing surrounding water droplets.
Form snowflakes.
The snowflakes fall to the ground.
target_subject: How does hail form?
target_text:
Water vapor in the atmosphere condenses into liquid water droplets.
The liquid droplets become heavy and form rain.
The rain falls to the ground, and when the temperature is below freezing,
it forms ice crystals instead of droplets.
These ice crystals accumulate and form hail.
The hail falls to the ground.
target_mappings:
Ice crystals : liquid droplets
Snowflakes : hail

source_subject: How does snow form?
source_text:
Water in the clouds becomes very cold.
The cold water forms ice crystals.
The ice crystals grow by absorbing surrounding water droplets.
Form snowflakes.
The snowflakes fall to the ground.
target_subject: How does volcanic ash form?
target_text:
The air near a volcano becomes very hot.
The hot air rises and carries volcanic ash with it.
The ash is then cooled by the surrounding air and forms particles.
The particles stick together and form volcanic ash clouds.
The clouds eventually reach the ground.
target_mappings:
Water in the clouds : air near a volcano
Ice crystals : particles
Snowflakes : volcanic ash clouds

source_subject: How does the body control its blood sugar level?
source_text:
Blood sugar levels increase after a meal.
Cells in the pancreas release insulin.
Insulin causes the body to absorb glucose from the blood.
Blood sugar goes back to normal.
Blood sugar is too low.
The amount of insulin goes down.
Cells in the pancreas release glucagon.
The liver turns stored glycogen into glucose.
The liver releases the glucose into the blood.
Blood sugar goes back to normal.
target_subject: How does the body control its temperature level?
target_text:
Temperature levels increase due to increased sunlight.
Cells in the hypothalamus release hormones.
These hormones cause the body to produce sweat and increase heart rate.
Temperature goes back to normal.
Temperature levels decrease due to decreased sunlight.
The amount of hormones goes down.
Cells in the hypothalamus release endorphins.
The muscles contract to generate heat.
The heat is released into the environment.
Temperature goes back to normal.
target_mappings:
Blood sugar : temperature
Insulin : hormones
Glucose : sweat and heart rate
Glucagon : endorphins
Glycogen : muscles

target_subject: How does the thermostat control the temperature?
target_text:
The thermostat in the room is set to a certain temperature.
When the temperature in the room rises above the set temperature,
the thermostat sends a signal to the air conditioner.
The air conditioner starts to cool down the room by releasing cold air.
When the temperature in the room drops below the set temperature,
the thermostat sends a signal to the heater.
The heater starts to heat up the room by releasing warm air.
target_mappings:
Blood sugar : temperature
Insulin : air conditioner
Glucagon : heater
Liver : thermostat

target_subject: How does the body regulate its temperature?
target_text:
Body temperature rises after physical activity.
The hypothalamus in the brain detects the increased temperature.
The hypothalamus causes the body to sweat and cool down.
Body temperature goes back to normal.
Body temperature is too low.
The hypothalamus sends signals to the body to start shivering.
Muscles contract rapidly and generate heat.
The body releases hormones to conserve heat and reduce heat loss.
Body temperature goes back to normal.

source_subject: How does the body control its blood sugar level?
source_text:
The blood sugar drops in a body.
Cells in the pancrease release glucagon.
The liver in response turns the glucagon into glucose.
And releases it into the blood.
The blood sugar levels are restored.
target_subject: How does the body control its temperature level?
target_text:
The temperature in a room drops.
Cells in the brain release a hormone called thyroxine.
The thyroid in response turns the thyroxine into heat.
And releases it into the room.
The temperature levels are restored.

target_subject: How does the body control its body temperature?
target_text:
The body temperature decreases in a body.
The hypothalamus in the brain releases corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH).
The adrenal glands in response releases glucocorticoids.
Glucocorticoids cause shivering and increased metabolic activity.
The body temperature is restored.

The temperature in the body drops.
Cells in the brain release vasopressin.
The kidneys in response turns the vasopressin into antidiuretic hormone.

The body temperature is restored.

source_subject: How does the human auditory system work?
source_text:
The outer ear collects sound waves.
The sound waves travel from the outer ear to the middle ear.
The eardrum changes the sound waves into vibrations.
The hammer, anvil, and stirrup bones vibrate.
The sound moves to the inner ear.
The sound enters the liquid-filled cochlea.
The cochlea vibrates.
Small hairs in the cochlea move.
Nerve signals are created.
The brain understands the nerve signals as sound.
target_subject: How does the human visual system work?
target_text:
The antenna collects light waves.
The light waves travel from the antenna to the lens.
The lens changes the light waves into images.
The cornea, iris, and pupil change the shape of the lens.
The image moves to the retina.
The image enters the liquid-filled vitreous humor.
The vitreous humor vibrates.
Rods and cones in the retina move.
Nerve signals are created.
The brain interprets the nerve signals as images.
target_mappings:
Outer ear : antenna
Vibrations : images
Hammer, anvil, stirrup bones : cornea, iris, pupil
Cochlea : vitreous humor
Hairs : rods and cones

target_subject: How does the human visual system work?
target_text:
Light enters the eye through the pupil.
The light passes through the lens.
The lens focuses the light onto the retina.
The light is converted into electrical impulses.
The electrical impulses travel to the brain through the optic nerve.
The brain decodes the electrical impulses, allowing the person to see.

Vibrations : electrical impulses
Cochlea : retina
Nerve signals : optic nerve

Light enters the eye through the cornea.
The cornea bends the light and sends it to the lens.
The lens focuses the light onto the back of the eye.
The light is focused on the rods and cones in the back of the eye.
The rods and cones change the light into electrical signals.
The electrical signals travel down the optic nerve to the brain.
The brain interprets these signals as images.

source_subject: How does the human auditory system work?
source_text:
Sound enters the ears of a person.
The sound hits a drum that is inside the ear.
The drum inside the ear converts the sound to electrical impulses.
The electrical impulses are sent to the brain.
The brain can decode the impulses into sound.
target_subject: How does the human visual system work?
target_text:
Light enters the eyes of a person.
The light hits a lens that is inside the eye.
The lens inside the eye focuses the light to form an image on the retina.
The image is then converted into electrical impulses.
The electrical impulses are sent to the brain.
The brain can decode the impulses into an image.
target_mappings:

Ears : eyes
Drum : lens

The electrical signals are sent to the brain.
The brain can interpret the signals into vision.

source_subject: How does the stomach work?
source_text:
The saliva breaks down the chemicals in the food a bit, which helps make the food mushy and easy to swallow.
Your tongue helps out, pushing the food around while you chew with your teeth.
The esophagus moves food from the back of your throat to your stomach.
Strong muscles in the walls of the stomach and gastric juices break down food in your stomach.
Your stomach moves the food into the intestines to complete digestion.
target_subject: How does the eye work?
target_text:
The lens focuses light on the back of the eye.
The cells in the retina convert the light into electrical impulses.
The optic nerve carries these electrical impulses to the brain.
The brain decodes the electrical impulses into images.
The muscles in the eyes help control the direction of the gaze.
target_mappings:
Saliva : lens
Teeth : cells in the retina
Esophagus : optic nerve
Stomach : brain
Intestines : muscles in the eyes

Your stomach moves the food into the intestines to complete digestion.
target_subject: How does the voice work?
target_text:
The air passes through the vocal cords, which vibrate to create sound.
The tongue helps to shape the sound, and the lips and teeth can create different types of sounds.
The muscles in the throat and lungs help to control the pitch and tone of the sound.
The diaphragm is used to control the volume of the sound.
The sound then passes through the nose or mouth to be heard.
target_mappings:

chew with teeth : vibrate vocal cords
esophagus : muscles in throat and lungs
stomach : diaphragm

target_subject: How does the heart work?
target_text:
The lungs take in oxygen from the air.
The air passes through the respiratory system and is filtered by the nose and throat.
The oxygen enters the lungs and is passed into the blood,
which is then taken to the heart.
The heart pumps the oxygen-rich blood around the body.
The oxygen is distributed to the organs and tissues for energy production.

Saliva : lungs
Tongue : respiratory system
Esophagus : heart
Stomach : organs and tissues
Gastric juices : oxygen

source_subject: How does weathering cause rocks to break apart?
source_text:
When water freezes it becomes 10% bigger, or takes up 10% more space.
As water expands it puts great pressure on the walls of anything containing it, including any rocks which happen to be surrounding it.
The force of the pressure exerted on the rock surrounding it is enough to wedge the walls of the crack farther apart, thus expanding and deepening the crack.
Clay expends when wet like ice does.
This causes rock to break apart.
Some plants like mosses and lichens are capable of growing without soil on bare rock.
When they do this their roots penetrate pores and crevices and cause rocks to split apart as the roots force their way down through the rocks.
target_subject: How does corrosion cause metal to break apart?
target_text:
When temperatures drop, metal contracts.
As metal contracts it puts great pressure on the walls of anything containing it, including any rocks which happen to be surrounding it.
The force of the pressure exerted on the rock surrounding it is enough to wedge the walls of the crack farther apart, thus expanding and deepening the crack.
Salt can also cause metal to corrode, weakening it and causing it to break apart.
Chemical reactions can also cause metal to break apart.
When metal reacts with oxygen, water, and other elements, it can corrode and weaken, causing it to break apart.
target_mappings:
Water : metal
Freezing : temperatures dropping
Clay : salt
Mosses and lichens : chemical reactions

Some plants like mosses and lichens are capable of growing without soil on bare rock.

target_subject: How does climate change cause rocks to break apart?
target_text:
Extreme temperature changes can cause rocks to break apart.
When temperatures drop, the water in the rocks freeze and expands, putting pressure on the rocks.
The force of the pressure can be enough to wedge the walls of the cracks in the rock farther apart, which can cause the rocks to break apart.
In addition, some plants have roots that can penetrate the pores and crevices of rocks, forcing them apart and causing them to break apart.
