target_subject: How does thermal expansion cause rocks to break apart?
target_text:
Temperature changes cause rocks to expand and contract, putting stress on the rock and eventually causing it to crack and break apart.
The expansion and contraction of the rock is caused by a process called thermal expansion, in which the particles of the rock move farther apart when heated and closer together when cooled.
The expansion and contraction of the rock can also be caused by the presence of water.
Water can seep into cracks in the rock and freeze, causing the cracks to expand and the rock to break apart.

source_subject: How is sediment transported across the Earth?
source_text:
Sediment transport is the movement of solid particles (sediment).
The movement is due to a combination of gravity acting on the sediment, and/or the movement of the fluid in which the sediment is entrained.
Sediment transport occurs in natural systems where the particles are clastic rocks (sand, gravel, boulders, etc.), mud, or clay.
The fluid is air, water, or ice.
And the force of gravity acts to move the particles along the sloping surface on which they are resting.
Sediment transport due to fluid motion occurs in rivers, oceans, lakes, seas, and other bodies of water due to currents and tides.
Transport is also caused by glaciers as they flow.
target_subject: How is the atmosphere transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Atmospheric transport refers to the movement of gases and particles through the atmosphere.
The movement is caused by a combination of forces, including wind, pressure gradients, temperature gradients, and the Coriolis effect.
The gases and particles that make up the atmosphere are transported from the Earth's surface to the upper atmosphere, and from one region of the Earth to another.
The wind transfers gases and particles from one region to another, and the Coriolis effect causes them to move in a spiral pattern in the atmosphere.
target_mappings:
Sediment : gases and particles
Fluid : wind
Gravity : pressure gradients, temperature gradients, Coriolis effect
Rivers, oceans, lakes, seas : region of the Earth

Sediment transport due to fluid motion occurs in rivers, oceans, lakes, seas, and other bodies of water due to currents and tides.
Transport is also caused by glaciers as they flow.
target_subject: How is heat transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Heat transport is the movement of thermal energy from one place to another.
The movement is due to a combination of conduction, convection, and radiation.
Heat transport occurs in natural systems where the molecules are air, water, or ice.
The force of gravity acts to move the molecules along the sloping surface on which they are resting.
Heat transport due to fluid motion occurs in oceans, lakes, seas, and other bodies of water due to currents and tides.
Transport is also caused by winds or by the rotation of the Earth.

Sediment : Heat
Clastic rocks : molecules
Fluid : air, water, or ice
Gravity : force of gravity

target_subject: How is dust and pollen transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Wind transport is the movement of dust, pollen, and other particulates through the air.
The movement is driven by the force of the wind.
The force of the wind causes the dust and pollen to move through the atmosphere.
The particles can travel long distances and settle on the ground or in bodies of water.
Wind transport is important for the dispersal of seeds and the spread of airborne diseases.
Wind transport also affects climate by carrying heat and moisture to different parts of the world.
target_mappings:
Sediment : dust and pollen
Fluid : wind
Gravity : force of the wind
Currents and tides : long distances
Glaciers : settle on the ground or in bodies of water

source_subject: How is sediment transported across the Earth?
source_text:
Sediment becomes loose from the rest of the soil.
The sediment rolls down hill towards a river.
The heavy items sink to the bottom.
The lighter items float on the top and in convection cycles.
As the river flows the sediment is moved.
The sediment gets dumped through tributaries into lakes and the ocean.
The sediment keeps moving around the world in convection currents.
target_subject: How is water transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Heat from the sun evaporates water from the Earth's surface,
creating water vapor that rises into the atmosphere.
The air in the atmosphere moves around the world in convection currents.
As the air moves around the globe, it cools and the water vapor condenses,
forming clouds that eventually produce rain and snow.
The rain and snow then fall back to the Earth's surface, allowing for the
transport of water around the world.
target_mappings:
Sediment : water
River : atmosphere
Tributaries : convection currents
Lakes and oceans : rain and snow

target_subject: How do convection currents move air around the world?
target_text:
Heat from the sun rises from the Earth's surface.
As the air warms, it becomes lighter and rises.
As the air rises, it cools and falls back towards the Earth's surface.
This cycle of rising and falling air creates convection currents in the atmosphere.
The convection currents move the air around the world in spiraling patterns.
target_mappings:
Sediment : air
River : atmosphere
Tributaries : spiraling patterns
Lakes and ocean : Earth's surface

The sediment keeps moving around the world in convection currents.
target_subject: How is volcanic ash transported across the Earth?
target_text:
Volcanic ash is thrown into the air by eruptions.
The ash is carried by the wind, sometimes for thousands of miles, before it settles back down.
The heavier particles settle more quickly than the lighter particles.
The ash and other particles of sediment are carried by rivers, streams, and ocean currents, often for very long distances.
The sediment eventually accumulates in other areas, such as in ocean basins, or on the seafloor.
target_mappings:
Sediment : volcanic ash
River : wind
Tributaries : rivers, streams, and ocean currents
Convection cycles : lighter particles
Convection currents : ocean basins and the seafloor

source_subject: What causes an earthquake to occur?
source_text:
Energy builds up in the crust of the earth.
The energy causes the fault lines give way.
The earth's plates move.
The energy radiates outward from the fault in all directions.
The seismic waves shake the earth as they move through it.
target_subject: What causes a storm to occur?
target_text:
Pressure builds up in the atmosphere.
The pressure causes the winds to pick up.
The air currents move around the globe.
The pressure radiates outward from the air currents in all directions.
The heat and winds of the storm shake the environment as they move through it.
target_mappings:
Energy : Pressure
Crust of the earth : Atmosphere
Fault lines : Winds
Earth's plates : Air currents
Seismic waves : Heat and winds

The energy causes the fault lines give way.
The earth's plates move.

The seismic waves shake the earth as they move through it.
target_subject: What causes a storm to occur?
target_text:

source_text:
Magma is formed when rock melts inside the Earth's crust.
Magma rises.
Collects inside magma chambers underneath a volcano.
Pressure builds in the magma chambers as they fill.
Gain energy for eruption.
Some of the energy is converted into seismic activity (earthquakes).
If the magma building in the volcano is thick and sticky it will trap gases.
Results in an explosive eruption when the pressure becomes too intense.
If the magma is thin and runs.
The magma results in a low-pressure, slow-moving flow of magma instead of a violent eruption.
target_subject: What causes a tornado to form?
target_text:
A tornado is formed when warm, humid air meets cold, dry air.
The warm air rises and the cold air moves in to take its place.
The air begins to rotate and increases in speed.
The air then forms a funnel and the pressure inside the funnel drops.
The low pressure inside the funnel causes the wind to pick up speed even more.
The tornado can then form a destructive path of destruction.
If the funnel is weak it may dissipate quickly.
If the funnel is strong, the tornado can cause extensive damage.

target_text:

Air is pulled into the lungs.

source_subject: What do lungs do?
source_text:
You inhale.
The air enters the mouth and nose.
The diaphragm contracts.
Air fills all the sacks in the lungs.
Oxygen passes through the sacks into capillaries.
The blood is passed to the blood in the capillaries.
The blood carries the oxygen to the heart.
The heart pumps the oxygenated blood to the body.
target_subject: How does the digestive system work?
target_text:
A person drinks a glass of water.
The water passes through the throat and into the esophagus.
The esophagus contracts and pushes the water down to the stomach.
The stomach is filled with acid and enzymes to break down the water.
The water is then transported to the small intestine.
The small intestine absorbs the water and sends it to the bloodstream.
The water is distributed to the different parts of the body.

source_subject: What do lungs do?
source_text:
He air we breathe contains oxygen and other gases.
Once in the lungs, oxygen is moved into the bloodstream and carried through your body.
At each cell in your body, oxygen is exchanged for a waste gas called carbon dioxide.
Your bloodstream then carries this waste gas back to the lungs where it is removed from the blood stream and then exhaled.
Your lungs and respiratory system automatically perform this vital process, called gas exchange.
target_subject: What do plants do?
target_text:
The soil contains nutrients and other minerals.
Once these nutrients enter a plant, they are moved around the plant through its vascular system.
At each cell in the plant, the nutrients are exchanged for oxygen and water.
The plant's vascular system then carries these products to the leaves, where photosynthesis takes place.
This process of nutrient exchange is essential for the plant's growth and survival.
target_mappings:
Oxygen : nutrients
Carbon dioxide : oxygen
Lungs : vascular system
Respiratory system : plant

source_subject: How does rust form?
source_text:
Water comes into contact with something made of iron.
The water combines with carbon dioxide in the air to form carbonic acid.
As the acid is formed, the iron starts to dissolve.
Some of the water breaks down into hydrogen and oxygen.
The free oxygen and dissolved iron bond together.
They form iron oxide, which is rust.
target_subject: How does corrosion form?
target_text:
Salt comes into contact with something made of aluminum.
The salt combines with oxygen and moisture in the air to form aluminum oxide.
As the oxide is formed, the aluminum starts to corrode.
Some of the salt breaks down into sodium and chloride ions.
The free oxygen and dissolved aluminum bond together.
They form aluminum hydroxide, which is corrosion.
target_mappings:

Carbon dioxide : oxygen and moisture
Carbonic acid : aluminum oxide
Hydrogen and oxygen : sodium and chloride ions
Iron oxide : aluminum hydroxide

target_subject: How does salt crystallize?
target_text:
Salt crystallizes when it comes into contact with water.
The salt molecules break down and separate, attaching to the water molecules.
The salt then dissolves, leaving behind the sodium and chloride ions in the water.
The sodium and chloride ions then attract more water molecules, forming hydrated salt.
The salt crystallizes when the water evaporates, leaving behind a layer of salt that coats the surface.

source_subject: How does a greenhouse stay warm?
source_text:
Sunlight passes through the glass into the greenhouse.
The plants and floor absorb the the sunlight.
The absorbed sunlight is converted to heat.
The heat cannot escape the glass.
The heat is trapped in the greenhouse.
The hot air rises.
The colder air at the top is pushed to the bottom.
The colder air is then warmed by the floor and the plants.
target_subject: How does a refrigerator stay cool?
target_text:
Cold air enters the refrigerator through an intake pipe.
The refrigerant absorbs the cold air and evaporates.
The evaporated refrigerant is pushed through a compressor,
which increases the pressure and temperature of the refrigerant.
The hot refrigerant is then passed through a condenser,
which releases the heat and cools the refrigerant back to a liquid.
The cooled liquid refrigerant is then passed through an expansion valve,
which reduces pressure and temperature and sends the cold air back into the refrigerator.
target_mappings:

Glass : intake pipe
Heat : refrigerant
Greenhouse : refrigerator
Hot air : evaporated refrigerant
Cold air : cooled liquid refrigerant

source_subject: Describe the steps in launching a satelite into space.
source_text:
You must decide the purpose of the satellite.
You must draw up a plan to what kind of orbit the satellite will travel.
You make preparations for the rocket that will travel into space.
Prepare the crew that will send it there.
You begin the countdown date for the rocket.
And then you send the rocket carrying the satellite into space.
Once in orbit the satellite will be placed where it was planned.
target_subject: Describe the steps in launching a payload with a hot air balloon.
target_text:
You must decide the purpose of the air balloon.
You must draw up a plan to what kind of altitude the air balloon will travel.
You make preparations for the hot air balloon that will travel into the sky.
Prepare the crew that will send it there.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a mushroom.
source_text:
Spores are dispersed into the air by a mature mushroom.
The spores fall to the ground.
The spores germinate.
The spores begin to grow mycelium.
The mycelium begin to sprout a bud.
A new mushroom is formed.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a flower.
target_text:
A flower produces pollen.
The pollen is dispersed into the air by the wind.
The pollen falls to the ground.
The pollen is taken in by the stigma of a flower.
The flower ovules are fertilized by the pollen.
A seed is formed.
This seed is dispersed by animals and the wind.

Spores are carried by the wind.
Land in a hospitable growing environment.

The mushroom starts growing.
The adult mushroom produce spores of its own to repeat the process.

source_subject: Describe the life cycle of a mushroom.
source_text:
A mushroom gives off gills lined with basidia.
The basidia gives off spores.
The spores germinate.
The spores create Hyphae.
Multiple Hyphae meet and converge.
They join with Mycelium.
A hyphal knot forms in the ground.
A primordia shoots out of the ground.
A mushroom cap is formed.
target_subject: Describe the life cycle of a pine tree.
target_text:
A pine tree produces cones and pollen.
The pollen is dispersed into the air.
The pollen germinates and produces a sperm.
The sperm combines with an egg to produce an embryo.
The embryo develops into a seed.
The seed is dispersed by the wind and finds a suitable environment.
The seed germinates and a seedling is formed.
The seedling grows into an adult tree.

source_subject: How does lightning occur?
source_text:
There is a rain cloud in the sky.
Small bits of ice within the cloud bump each other.
The collisions create electrical charge.
Lighter, positively charged particles sink to the bottom of the cloud.
Heavier, negatively charges particles rise to the top.
When the positive and negative charges grow large enough, a giant spark, called lightning occurs.
target_subject: How does lightning occur?
target_text:
The Earth is surrounded by a layer of charged particles, called the ionosphere.
The particles are continually being pushed and pulled by the sun's radiation.
When the particles build up, it can cause a large electric field to form between two points.
When the electric field reaches a certain strength, a giant spark, called a lightning bolt, will occur.
target_mappings:
Rain cloud : ionosphere
Ice : charged particles
Positively charged particles : pushed by sun's radiation
Negatively charged particles : pulled by sun's radiation

Lighter, positively charged particles sink to the bottom of the cloud.
Heavier, negatively charges particles rise to the top.
When the positive and negative charges grow large enough, a giant spark, called lightning occurs.
target_subject: How does a dust devil occur?
target_text:
A dust storm occurs when strong winds carry a large amount of dust and sand particles into the atmosphere.
The particles crash into each other, creating static electricity.
The static electricity causes lighter particles to rise and heavier particles to sink.
When the static electricity builds up enough, a spark occurs, which is known as a dust devil.
target_mappings:
Rain cloud : dust storm
Ice : dust and sand particles
Lightning : dust devil

There is a rain cloud in the sky.
Small bits of ice within the cloud bump each other.

Lighter, positively charged particles sink to the bottom of the cloud.
Heavier, negatively charges particles rise to the top.
When the positive and negative charges grow large enough, a giant spark, called lightning occurs.
target_subject: How does a thunderstorm form?
target_text:
A supercell thunderstorm develops when warm and cold air masses meet.
The warm air rises, forming an updraft.
The updraft carries water droplets up and into the cold air.
The droplets freeze, becoming ice particles.
As the ice particles bump against each other, an electrical charge is created.
Positively charged particles sink to the bottom and negatively charged particles rise to the top.
When the positive and negative charges grow large enough, a giant spark, called lightning, occurs.
target_mappings:
rain cloud : supercell thunderstorm
ice : ice particles
lightning : lightning

source_subject: How does lightning occur?
source_text:
Ice forms inside a cloud.
Ice inside the cloud bumps around and causes electrostatic charges.
The cloud becomes a thundercloud.
Electrostatic energy builds and forms a strong negative charge.
Positive energy is attracted to the negative energy in the cloud.
This positive energy gathers on the ground.
The positive energy connects with the negative energy and forms lightning.
target_subject: How does a tornado form?
target_text:
A tornado forms inside a storm cloud.
The wind inside the cloud starts to spin, forming a vortex of air.
The vortex of air starts to suck in air from the surrounding area.
Air from the ground is drawn into the vortex, bringing with it moisture and heat.
As the air rises, it cools and condenses, forming clouds and eventually releasing rain.
The air continues to spin, creating a powerful rotating column of air known as a tornado.
target_mappings:
Ice : air
electrostatic charges : moisture and heat
positive energy : air from the ground
negative energy : vortex of air

The positive energy connects with the negative energy and forms lightning.
target_subject: How does lightning occur?
target_text:
Dust particles move around in the atmosphere.
The particles bump into each other and form electrostatic charges.
The particles form into a dust storm.
The electrostatic energy builds and creates a strong negative charge.
The negative charge attracts positive charges from the ground.
The positive and negative charges connect, creating a spark and forming a lightning bolt.

target_subject: How does a thunderstorm occur?
target_text:

Moisture in the air condenses into water droplets and forms clouds.
The water droplets freeze and form ice crystals.
The ice crystals bump around and cause electrostatic charges.
The cloud becomes a thundercloud.

This positive energy gathers on the ground.
The positive energy connects with the negative energy and forms a thunderstorm.

source_subject: Describe the process of DNA replication.
source_text:
The dna strand of a cell decides to replicate.
Chemicals in the strand break up the helix.
The helix is split into two.
The helix forms as the basis of a new dna strand.
The cell replicates.

target_text:
A computer is programmed to execute a task.
The program is loaded into the computer's memory.
The computer reads the instructions from the program.
The instructions are broken down into individual commands.
The commands are executed by the processor.
The task is completed by the computer.

The cell replicates.
target_subject: Describe the process of protein synthesis.
target_text:
A protein is synthesized in the cell.
The protein is constructed in the ribosome using the genetic code from the mRNA.
The amino acid sequence is determined by the codons in the mRNA.
The ribosome builds the protein by connecting the amino acids in the correct order.
The protein is then released from the ribosome.

helix : mRNA
DNA strand : ribosome
cell : amino acids

target_subject: Describe the process of viral reproduction.
target_text:
A virus comes into contact with a healthy cell.
The virus binds to the cell's membrane.
The virus injects its genetic material into the cell.
The genetic material takes over the cell's machinery.
The virus reproduces itself through the cell's processes.
The cell releases the new viruses to carry on the cycle.
target_mappings:
DNA strand : virus
Helix : cell's membrane
Replication : injects its genetic material
Cell : cell's machinery

source_subject: Describe the process of DNA replication.
source_text:
DNA replication is initiated by proteins.
The hydrogen bonds that hold together a strand of DNA are broken.
A polymerase reads each side of the strand.
Adds complimentary nucleotides.
Once all the bases are matched, the new DNA strand is formed.
DNA ligase seals the new pieces into two new strands.
target_subject: Describe the process of translation.
target_text:
Translation starts with the assembly of ribosomes.
The small and large subunits of the ribosome come together around an mRNA molecule.
The mRNA molecule is read in triplets, each triplet code is called a codon.
Transfer RNA molecules bring amino acids to the ribosome that match the codon.
The amino acids are joined together to form a polypeptide.
The polypeptide is released and folded into a protein.

Nucleotides : codons

New DNA strand : polypeptide

target_text:
Protein synthesis is initiated by tRNA molecules.
mRNA reads the codons of the strand.
tRNA carries the necessary amino acids to the mRNA molecule.
A ribosome pairs each amino acid with the codon.
Once all amino acids are paired, the new protein strand is formed.
Peptide bonds connect the amino acids together.

source_subject: How does a coal-fired power plant work?
source_text:
Coal is put in a coal-fired steam station.
Water is put in pipes in the coal-fired steam station.
The coal is crushed.
The coal is moved into a boiler along with hot air.
The water is moving through pipes in the boiler.
The steam from the water is blown against a turning mechanism.
The force of the steam makes the mechanism turn.
The mechanism generates electricity.
target_subject: How does a wind farm works?
target_text:
Wind turbines are set up in a wind farm.
The turbines capture the kinetic energy of the wind and convert it into electricity.
The wind passes through the blades of the turbines, which cause them to spin.
The blades are connected to a shaft which is connected to a generator.
The generator converts the kinetic energy from the spinning blades into electrical energy.
The electrical energy is collected and sent to the power grid.
target_mappings:
Coal-fired steam station : wind farm
Coal : wind
Boiler : turbines
Steam : kinetic energy
Turning mechanism : blades
Generator : generator

The electricity is then sent to the grid and can be used by consumers.

target_subject: How does a solar panel system work?
target_text:
Solar panels are installed on the roof of a building.
The solar panels absorb energy from the sun.
The energy is captured and then sent to an inverter.

The alternating current is then sent to a breaker panel.
The breaker panel sends the energy to various outlets in the building.

source_subject: What are the steps involved in growing a pumpkin?
source_text:
First you dig a whole.
You place a pumpkin seed in the hole.
You put some dirt over the seed.
You water the seed.
The seed will sprout.
A vine will grow.
The vine will flower.
Pumpkins will appear where the flowers were.
target_subject: What are the steps involved in growing a fruit?
target_text:
First you plant a seed in the ground.
You add some compost or fertilizer.
You water the seed.
The seed will sprout.
The sprout will grow into a plant.
The plant will flower.
Fruits will appear where the flowers were.

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A star forms.
The star does not have enough mass to become a neutron star.
The star goes through a change in its core and bonds helium to carbon and oxygen.
The star becomes a red giant.
A mass of carbon and oxygen builds up in the center of the star.
The star sheds its outside layers and becomes a nebula.
The star leaves behind the core which becomes a dwarf star.
target_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
target_text:
A supernova occurs.
The star does not have enough mass to become a black hole.
The star undergoes a change in its core and combines hydrogen and helium.
The star becomes a supergiant.
A mass of hydrogen and helium accumulates in the center of the star.
The star ejects its outer layers and becomes a supernova remnant.
The star leaves behind its core which becomes a white dwarf star.
target_mappings:
Star : supernova
Neutron star : black hole
Helium to carbon and oxygen : hydrogen and helium
Red giant : supergiant
Nebula : supernova remnant

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A star forms.
The star does not have enough mass to become a neutron star.
The star goes through a change in its core and bonds helium to carbon and oxygen.
The star becomes a red giant.
A mass of carbon and oxygen builds up in the center of the star.
The star sheds its outside layers and becomes a nebula.
The star leaves behind the core which becomes a dwarf star.
target_subject: How is a supermassive black hole formed?
target_text:
A black hole forms.
The black hole is created by the collapse of a massive star.
The star collapses until it reaches a singularity.
This singularity has an extremely high density and has a gravitational pull so strong that nothing can escape, not even light.
The star's outer layers are flung away, leaving behind a core of matter.
The core is so dense that it continues to pull in more matter from its surroundings.
A stellar remnant is left behind, forming a supermassive black hole.
target_mappings:
star : massive star
neutron star : singularity
red giant : stellar remnant
carbon and oxygen : core of matter
nebula : supermassive black hole

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A star forms.

The star goes through a change in its core and bonds helium to carbon and oxygen.
The star becomes a red giant.
A mass of carbon and oxygen builds up in the center of the star.
The star sheds its outside layers and becomes a nebula.
The star leaves behind the core which becomes a dwarf star.
target_subject: How is a supermassive black hole formed?
target_text:
A black hole forms.
The black hole is incredibly dense and has a strong gravitational pull.
Matter is pulled into the black hole, creating an accretion disk around it.
This disk is heated by the friction of the matter being pulled in,
causing it to emit high-energy radiation.
As the black hole continues to pull in matter, it grows larger.
The black hole eventually stops pulling in matter and is left with a supermassive core.
This core is the black hole's final form, known as a supermassive black hole.
target_mappings:
star : black hole
neutron star : supermassive black hole
helium to carbon and oxygen : matter
red giant : accretion disk
carbon and oxygen : supermassive core

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A star burns in space.
Eventually it burns all its hydrogen.
Becomes a red giant.
Once the red giant burns itself out.
The core of the star collapses.
The gasses will start to disperse.
Only the core is left.
A white dwarf has been formed.
target_subject: How is a neutron star formed?
target_text:
A nebula is formed from a large cloud of gas and dust.
Gravity pulls the gas and dust together.
The gas and dust become more and more dense.
Eventually the gas and dust form a protostar.
The protostar continues to collapse and heat up until thermonuclear fusion begins.
The thermonuclear fusion creates a star.
As the star ages, it uses up its hydrogen.
Once all the hydrogen has been used up, the star collapses into a neutron star.
target_mappings:
Star : nebula
Red giant : protostar
White dwarf : neutron star

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A star burns in space.
Eventually it burns all its hydrogen.
Becomes a red giant.
Once the red giant burns itself out.
The core of the star collapses.
The gasses will start to disperse.
Only the core is left.
A white dwarf has been formed.
target_subject: How is a black dwarf star formed?
target_text:
A nebula forms in space from gas and dust.
Gravity causes the gas and dust to come together.
The material in the nebula starts to get hot and form a protostar.
The protostar continues to heat up until it becomes a main sequence star.
When the main sequence star runs out of fuel, it starts to cool and shrinks into a red dwarf.
Eventually, the red dwarf will cool down and become a black dwarf.
target_mappings:
Star : nebula
Hydrogen : gas and dust
Red giant : protostar
Core : main sequence star
Gases : red dwarf
White dwarf : black dwarf

A star burns in space.

Becomes a red giant.
Once the red giant burns itself out.
The core of the star collapses.
The gasses will start to disperse.
Only the core is left.
A white dwarf has been formed.
target_subject: How is a neutron star formed?
target_text:
A nebula forms in space when a group of dust, gas and other space particles are drawn together by gravity.
The center of the nebula heats up and the dust and gas particles rotate around the center, becoming denser and denser.
As the core becomes denser, nuclear fusion starts and a star is born.
Eventually, the star will burn out, its core collapses and the outer layers of the star will disperse into space.
All that is left is a dense core, known as a neutron star.
target_mappings:
Star : nebula
Hydrogen : dust and gas particles
Red giant : nuclear fusion
White dwarf : neutron star

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A red giant burns mass.
This mass creates high core temperatures.
The mass decreases.
The red giant can no longer fuse the carbon and oxygen in its center.
The gravity of the star can no longer hold the outside layers.
The layers break away.
Only the inner core remains.
This inner core is known as a white dwarf.
target_subject: How is a neutron star formed?
target_text:
A supernova explosion occurs when a large star runs out of fuel.
The core of the star collapses, causing a massive amount of energy to be released.
The shockwave from the explosion pushes the outer layers of the star away.
The collapsed core is left behind and is called a neutron star.
The gravitational force of the neutron star is so great that it is able to prevent further collapse.
target_mappings:
Red giant : large star
Mass : fuel
High core temperatures : massive amount of energy
White dwarf : neutron star

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A red giant burns mass.
This mass creates high core temperatures.
The mass decreases.
The red giant can no longer fuse the carbon and oxygen in its center.
The gravity of the star can no longer hold the outside layers.
The layers break away.
Only the inner core remains.
This inner core is known as a white dwarf.
target_subject: How is a neutron star formed?
target_text:
A massive star runs out of fuel and collapses under its own gravity.
The core temperatures become extremely high.
The star's mass decreases and it can no longer hold onto its outer layers.
The outer layers break away, leaving only the core.
The core is incredibly dense and is known as a neutron star.
target_mappings:
Red giant : massive star
Carbon and Oxygen : fuel
White dwarf : neutron star

source_subject: How is a white dwarf star formed?
source_text:
A red giant burns mass.
This mass creates high core temperatures.
The mass decreases.
The red giant can no longer fuse the carbon and oxygen in its center.
The gravity of the star can no longer hold the outside layers.
The layers break away.
Only the inner core remains.
This inner core is known as a white dwarf.
target_subject: How is a neutron star formed?
target_text:
A stellar nebula is composed of dust, hydrogen, helium, and other gases.
As the nebula contracts due to gravitational pull, the core temperature rises.
The core temperature is high enough to fuse hydrogen into helium.
The fusion creates a star.
After the star has used up most of its hydrogen fuel, it begins to cool and expand, becoming a red giant.
The gravity of the red giant is no longer strong enough to hold the outer layers, and they are pushed away in a large explosion.
The remaining core of the star is known as a neutron star.
target_mappings:
Red giant : stellar nebula
Mass : dust, hydrogen, helium, and other gases
Carbon and oxygen : hydrogen
White dwarf : neutron star

source_subject: How do vaccinations work?
source_text:
You receive a vaccination through an injection or a nasal spray.
The vaccine contains a weakened version of the virus or bacteria responsible for the disease.
The body's immune system reacts to the virus or bacteria.
The immune system creates antibodies to fight the virus or bacteria.
The antibodies remain in the body.
The antibodies are ready to fight the disease if the person is infected with the disease.
target_subject: How do medications work?
target_text:
You take a medication orally or through an injection.
The medication contains a weakened version of the toxin or bacteria responsible for the disease.
The body's immune system reacts to the toxin or bacteria.
The immune system creates antibodies to fight the toxin or bacteria.
The antibodies remain in the body.
The antibodies are ready to fight the disease if the person is exposed to the toxin or bacteria again.
target_mappings:
Vaccination : medication
Injection/nasal spray : orally/injection
Virus/bacteria : toxin/bacteria

target_subject: How do medications work?
target_text:
You take a medication in pill form or through injection.

source_subject: How does a bird build a nest?
source_text:
The bird picks a tree.
The bird collects twigs and other refuse.
The bird makes a flat base with twigs.
The bird makes sides with twigs and other things.
The bird adds softer material to the inside.
The nest is done.
target_subject: How does a beaver build a dam?
target_text:
A beaver selects a tree.
The beaver cuts the tree down using its sharp incisors.
The beaver drags the tree to the pond and builds a dam.
The beaver uses the tree to form walls and holds the dam together with mud and stones.
The beaver adds vegetation and mud to reinforce the dam.
The dam is done.
target_mappings:

source_subject: How does a bird build a nest?
source_text:
A bird picks a spot high spot, often in a tree.
The bird collects bits of sticks and grass.
The sticks and grasses are placed between support branches.
Leaves, mud and spider webs are added to the sticks.
The mud, leaves and webs glue the sticks together.
The solid nest supports the eggs.
target_subject: How does a bee build a hive?
target_text:
A bee finds a hollow space, often in a tree.
The bee gathers nectar and pollen from flowers.
The nectar and pollen are placed between the walls of the hollow space.
Propolis, a sticky resin, is added to the nectar and pollen.
The propolis binds the nectar and pollen together.
The sturdy comb supports the eggs.
target_mappings:

Mud, leaves and webs : propolis
Nest : comb

target_subject: How does a bee build a honeycomb?
target_text:
A bee selects a suitable spot, often in a tree.
The bee collects wax and pollen from the hive.
The wax and pollen are mixed together and shaped into a hexagon.
The hexagon cells are lined with wax and filled with pollen and nectar.
The walls are built up and the cells are capped with wax.
The completed comb provides shelter and food for the hive.
target_mappings:

Leaves, mud and spider webs : wax
Nest : hexagon cells
Eggs : pollen and nectar

source_subject: How does pollination happen?
source_text:
A flowering plant has stamen and pistils.
An insect ot bird lands on the plant.
Some of the pollen sticks to it.
The insect or bird travels to another plant of the same species.
The pollen is tranferred to the new plant.
target_subject: How does seed dispersal happen?
target_text:
A seed dispersal method is the wind.
The plant produces dry seeds with wings or fluffy hairs.
The wind carries the seeds away from the original plant.
The seeds are carried to a new location, far from the original plant.
The seeds land on the ground and take root in the new location.
target_mappings:

Insect or bird : wind
Pollen : seeds

target_subject: How does bee reproduction happen?
target_text:
A bee hive is composed of a queen bee and worker bees.
The worker bees collect nectar and pollen from flowers.
The nectar and pollen are stored in the hive.
The queen bee lays eggs.
The worker bees feed the larvae with the nectar and pollen.
The bee hive reproduces and grows.

target_subject: How does a bee hive works?
target_text:
A bee hive contains a queen bee, worker bees and drones.
The worker bees are responsible for gathering nectar and pollen from flowers.

The nectar and pollen is then used to make honey and feed the hive.
The pollen is also spread to other flowers, aiding in the pollination process.

source_subject: Describe how to make pancakes.
source_text:
Mix pancake mix with water.
Heat a griddle.
Pour a circle of batter in the griddle.
When most of the bubbles pop on the surface, flip.
Cook to desired color.
Apply butter, syrup and enjoy.
target_subject: Describe how to make cookies.
target_text:
Mix cookie dough with eggs.
Preheat the oven.
Place heaping spoonfuls of dough on a baking sheet.
Bake in the oven until golden brown.
Let cool, then apply frosting and decorations.
Enjoy!

source_subject: Describe the typical steps in making coffee.
source_text:
The carafe is filled with water.
The water is poured into the machine at the back.
Coffee beans are put into a grinder.
The grinder is activated.
A filter is put into the coffee maker.
The ground coffee is put into the filter.
Sometimes a bit of salt is added to the grounds to bring out flavor.
The top of the machine is closed.
The power is turned on.
The water passes through the grounds and becomes coffee.
target_subject: Describe the typical steps in making tea.
target_text:
The teapot is filled with water.
The water is brought to a boil.
Tea leaves are put into a strainer.
The strainer is placed into the teapot.
A bit of sugar is sometimes added to the pot.
The boiling water is poured over the tea leaves.
The tea steeps for a few minutes.
The strainer is removed and the tea is ready to drink.
target_mappings:
Carafe : teapot
Grinder : strainer
Filter : strainer
Grounds : tea leaves
Salt : sugar

target_subject: Describe the typical steps in making tea.

The coffee pot is filled with water.
Water is poured into the well of the machine.
A filter is placed in the basket.
Ground coffee is measured into the filter.
Turning on the machine starts the water heating.
The hot water rises up.
The water drops into the ground coffee.
The hot water passes through the grounds.
The coffee drips into the pot from the basket.

The tea steeps in the hot water.
The teabag is removed.

A martini glass is chilled by filling it with ice and water.

source_subject: How does a desalination plant remove salt from water?
source_text:
Place the water in a pot.
Cover the pot with a slightly too large cover.
Place a larger pot under the first.
Heat water to evaporation.
Water vapor will collect on the lid.
Drip into the second pot as fresh water.
Salt is left behind in the original pot.
target_subject: How does a reverse osmosis plant remove salt from water?
target_text:
Salt water is pumped into a membrane.
The membrane separates the salt from the water.
The water passes through the membrane, while the salt is left behind.
The now purified water is collected in a separate chamber,
while the salt is left in the original chamber.
target_mappings:
pot : membrane
water : salt water
evaporation : reverse osmosis
fresh water : purified water

source_subject: How does a desalination plant remove salt from water?
source_text:
Place the water in a pot.
Cover the pot with a slightly too large cover.
Place a larger pot under the first.
Heat water to evaporation.
Water vapor will collect on the lid.
Drip into the second pot as fresh water.
Salt is left behind in the original pot.
target_subject: How does reverse osmosis remove salt from water?
target_text:
A desalination plant separates salt and other minerals from seawater or brackish water
through reverse osmosis. The saline water is forced through a semi-permeable membrane
at high pressure which allows the water, but not the salt, to pass through.
The water is collected while the salt and other minerals are left behind and disposed of.
target_mappings:
Water : saline water
Pot : semi-permeable membrane
Lid : high pressure
Second pot : collected water
Salt : salt and other minerals

source_subject: How does a desalination plant remove salt from water?
source_text:
Place the water in a pot.
Cover the pot with a slightly too large cover.
Place a larger pot under the first.
Heat water to evaporation.
Water vapor will collect on the lid.
Drip into the second pot as fresh water.
Salt is left behind in the original pot.
target_subject: How does reverse osmosis work?
target_text:
Salt water is placed in a membrane chamber.
The chamber is divided in two parts by a semi-permeable membrane.
Pressure is applied on the salty side, pushing the salt water molecules through the membrane.
The membrane filters out the salt molecules, allowing the clean water molecules to pass through.
The clean water passes through the membrane and is collected in a separate chamber.
target_mappings:
Water : salt water
Pot : membrane chamber
Cover : semi-permeable membrane
Second pot : separate chamber

source_subject: How do kidneys filter blood?
source_text:
Blood carried into kidney by the renal artery.
Nephrons in the kidney filter the blood.
The waste that is filtered out mixes with water.
Become urine.
Ureters carry urine out of the kidneys.
target_subject: How do lungs filter air?
target_text:
Air is carried into the lungs by the bronchial tubes.
Alveoli in the lungs filter the air.
The waste that is filtered out mixes with water.
Becomes mucus.
The bronchial tubes carry the mucus out of the lungs.
target_mappings:

Renal artery : bronchial tubes
Nephrons : alveoli
Urine : mucus

target_subject: How do the lungs filter air?

Air is brought into the lungs through the trachea.
The air is then passed through tiny bronchioles.
The bronchioles filter out dust and other particles.
The clean air is then brought into the alveoli.
The alveoli absorb the oxygen from the air and expel carbon dioxide.
The air is then exhaled from the lungs.

source_subject: What causs a volcano to erupt?
source_text:
Magma rises from deep in the earth.
The magma goes into volcanos.
The volcanos pressure the magma upwards.
The pressure causes the magma to push through the surface of the volcano.
The lava cools.
The lava forms new rock.
New magma is pressured to the surface of the volcano.
The volcano bursts through the rock the formed after the last eruption.
target_subject: How does electricity flow through a power grid?
target_text: Electrical Engineering
target_mappings:
Electricity is generated by a power plant.
The electricity is sent through a power line.
The power line is under pressure from the electricity.
The pressure causes the electricity to flow through the power line.
The electricity is then sent to a transformer.
The transformer increases the voltage of the electricity.
The increased voltage is sent to homes and businesses.

volcano : power plant
pressure : power line
lava : transformer
new rock : homes and businesses

target_subject: How does a hydraulic system work?
target_text: Mechanical Engineering
target_mappings:
Pressure builds up in a hydraulic system.
The pressure is created by the hydraulic fluid entering the system.
The pressure causes the fluid to flow through the pipes.
The pressure is released when the fluid exits the system, causing the system to move or perform work.

target_subject: What causes a flood?
target_text: Civil Engineering
target_mappings:
A river flows into a reservoir.
The reservoir pressure causes the water to push through a dam.
The pressure causes the water to push above the structure of the dam.
The water cools and forms new sediment.
The new sediment is carried by the river downstream.
The river eventually reaches a point where the sediment is too much and a flood occurs.

A virus enters the body.
The virus penetrates the cells of the body.
The cells become infected with the virus.
The virus replicates itself inside the cells, causing the cells to burst.
The virus is then released from the cells and can spread to other cells and other people.

target_subject: What causes a volcano to erupt?
target_text: Earth Science
target_mappings:
Magma rises from deep in the earth.
The pressure from the magma builds up in the magma chamber.
When the pressure becomes too great, the magma is forced upwards and out of the volcano.
The rising magma and pressure can cause fractures in the rock, allowing more magma to flow.
The magma then flows out of the volcano and hardens, forming new rock.
The pressure in the magma chamber continues to build until the next eruption.
